103730_11_ITEM7_P13_S2	Due to our quick reaction to the recession, we mitigated the loss of volume that we experienced through significant reductions of fixed costs and inventories, we continued to generate positive cash flows from operations during the recession, and following several quarters of experiencing losses we began to recover from the global economic recession and produced positive net earnings beginning in the thir d fiscal quarter of 2009.
103730_11_ITEM7_P14_S0	We utilize several financial metrics to evaluate the performance and assess the future direction of our business.
103730_11_ITEM7_P14_S1	These key financial measures and metrics include net revenues, gross profit margin, operating margin, segment operating income, end-of-period backlog, and the book-to-bill ratio.
103730_11_ITEM7_P14_S2	We also monitor changes in inventory turnover and average selling prices ( ASP ).
103730_11_ITEM7_P15_S0	Gross profit margin is computed as gross profit as a percentage of net revenues.
103730_11_ITEM7_P15_S1	Gross profit is generally net revenues less costs of products sold, but also deducts certain other period costs, particularly losses on purchase commitments and inventory write-downs.
103730_11_ITEM7_P15_S2	Losses on purchase commitments and inventory write-downs have the impact of reducing gross profit margin in the period of the charge, but result in improved gross profit margins in subsequent periods by reducing costs of products sold as inventory is used.
103730_11_ITEM7_P16_S0	Gross profit margin is clearly a function of net revenues, but also reflects our cost management programs and our ability to contain fixed costs.
103730_11_ITEM7_P17_S0	Operating margin is computed as gross profit less operating expenses as a percentage of net revenues.
103730_11_ITEM7_P17_S1	We evaluate business segment performance on segment operating margin.
103730_11_ITEM7_P17_S2	Only dedicated, direct selling, general, and administrative expenses of the segments are included in the calculation of segment operating income.
103730_11_ITEM7_P17_S3	Segment operating margin is computed as operating income less items such as restructuring and severance costs, asset write-downs, goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible asset impairments, inventory write-downs, gain or losses on purchase commitments, global operations, sales and marketing, information systems, finance and administrative groups, and other items, expressed as a percentage of net revenues.
103730_11_ITEM7_P17_S4	We believe that evaluating segment performance excluding such items is meaningful because it provides insight with respect to intrinsic operating results of the segment.
103730_11_ITEM7_P18_S0	Operating margin is clearly a function of net revenue s, but also reflects our cost management programs and our ability to contain fixed costs.
103730_11_ITEM7_P19_S0	End-of-period backlog is one indicator of future revenues.
103730_11_ITEM7_P19_S1	We include in our backlog only open orders that we expect to ship in the next twelve months.
103730_11_ITEM7_P19_S2	If demand falls below customers forecasts, or if customers do not control their inventory effectively, they may cancel or reschedule the shipments that are included in our backlog, in many instances without the payment of any penalty.
103730_11_ITEM7_P19_S3	Therefore, the backlog is not necessarily indicative of the results to be expected for future periods.
103730_11_ITEM7_P20_S0	An important indicator of demand in our industry is the book-to-bill ratio, which is the ratio of the amount of product ordered during a period as compared with the product that we ship during that period.
103730_11_ITEM7_P20_S1	A book-to-bill ratio that is greater than one indicates that our backlog is building and that we are likely to see increasing revenues in future periods.
103730_11_ITEM7_P20_S2	Conversely, a book-to-bill ratio that is less than one is an indicator of declining demand and may foretell declining revenues.
103730_11_ITEM7_P21_S0	We focus on our inventory turnover as a measure of how well we are managing our inventory.
103730_11_ITEM7_P22_S0	We define inventory turnover for a financial reporting period as our costs of products sold for the four fiscal quarters ending on the last day of the reporting period divided by our average inventory (computed using each fiscal quarter-end balance) for this same period.
103730_11_ITEM7_P22_S1	The inventory balance used for computation of this ratio includes tantalum inventories in excess of a one year supply, which are classified as other assets in the consolidated balance sheet.
103730_11_ITEM7_P22_S2	See Note 14 to our consolidated financial statements.
103730_11_ITEM7_P23_S0	A higher level of inventory turnover reflects more efficient use of our capital.
103730_11_ITEM7_P24_S0	Pricing in our industry can be volatile.
103730_11_ITEM7_P24_S1	We analyze trends and changes in average selling prices to evaluate likely future pricing.
103730_11_ITEM7_P25_S0	The erosion of average selling prices of established products is typical for semiconductor products.
103730_11_ITEM7_P25_S1	We attempt to offset this deterioration with ongoing cost reduction activities and new product introductions.
103730_11_ITEM7_P25_S2	Our specialty passive components are more resistant to average selling price erosion.
103730_11_ITEM7_P26_S0	The quarter-to-quarter trends in these financial metrics can also be an important indicator of the likely direction of our business.

103730_11_ITEM7_P34_S0	As part of our growth strategy, we seek to expand through targeted acquisitions of other manufacturers of electronic components that have established positions in major markets, reputations for product quality and reliability, and product lines with which we have substantial marketing and technical expertise.
103730_11_ITEM7_P34_S1	This includes exploring opportunities to acquire targets to gain market share, penetrate different geographic markets, enhance new product development, round out our product lines, or grow our high margin niche market businesses.
103730_11_ITEM7_P34_S2	Acquisitions of passive components businesses would likely be made to strengthen and broaden our position as a specialty product supplier; acquisitions of discrete semiconductor businesses would be made to increase market share and to generate synergies.
103730_11_ITEM7_P34_S3	To limit our financial exposure, we have implemented a policy not to pursue acquisitions if our post-acquisition debt would exceed 2.5x our pro forma earn ings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization ( EBITDA ).
103730_11_ITEM7_P34_S4	For these purposes, we will calculate pro forma EBITDA as the adjusted EBITDA of Vishay and the target for Vishay s four preceding fiscal quarters, with a pro forma adjustment for savings which management estimates would have been achieved had the target been acquired by Vishay at the beginning of the four fiscal quarter period.

103730_11_ITEM7_P45_S0	We place a strong emphasis on controlling our costs.
103730_11_ITEM7_P46_S0	The erosion of average selling prices of established products, particularly our semiconductor products, that is typical of our industry and inflation drive us to continually seek ways to reduce our variable costs.
103730_11_ITEM7_P46_S1	Our variable cost reduction efforts include expending capital to increase automation and maximize the efficiency in our production facilities, consolidating materials purchasing across regions and divisions to achieve economies of scale, materials substitution, maintaining an appropriate mix of in-house production and subcontractor production, increasing wafer size and shrinking dies to maximize efficiency in our semiconductor production processes, and other yield improvement activities.
103730_11_ITEM7_P47_S0	Our cost management strategy also includes a focus on controlling fixed costs.
103730_11_ITEM7_P47_S1	After the spin-off of VPG, we seek to maintain selling, general, and administrative expenses at current quarterly levels, excluding foreign currency exchange effects and substantially independent of sales volume changes.
103730_11_ITEM7_P47_S2	Our fixed cost control efforts include automating administrative processes through the expansion of IT systems, gradually migrating to common IT systems across our organization, streamlining our legal entity structure, and reducing our external resource needs by utilizing more cost-effective in-house personnel, while utilizing external resources when day-to-day expertise is not required in-house.
103730_11_ITEM7_P48_S0	Historically, our primary cost reduction technique was through the transfer of production to the extent possible from high-labor-cost countries, such as the United States and Western Europe, to lower-labor-cost countries, such as the Czech Republic, Israel, India, Malaysia, Mexico, the People s Republic of China, and the Philippines.
103730_11_ITEM7_P48_S1	The percentage of our total headcount in lower-labor-cost countries is a measure of the extent to which we were successful in implementing this program.
103730_11_ITEM7_P48_S2	This percentage was 76.5% at the end of 2010 as compared to 74.6% at the end of both 2009 and 2008, and 57% when this program began in 2001.
103730_11_ITEM7_P49_S0	We believe that our workforce is now appropriately located to serve our customers, while maintaining lower manufacturing costs.
103730_11_ITEM7_P50_S0	Between 2001 and 2007, we recorded, in the consolidated statements of operations, restructuring and severance costs totaling $223 million and related asset write-downs totaling $81 million in order to reduce our cost structure going forward.
103730_11_ITEM7_P50_S1	We also incurred significant costs to restructure and integrate acquired businesses, which was included in the cost of the acquisitions under then-applicable GAAP.
103730_11_ITEM7_P51_S0	In response to the economic downturn which began during the latter half of 2008 and continued into 2009, we undertook significant measures to cut costs.
103730_11_ITEM7_P51_S1	This included a strict adaptation of manufacturing capacity to sellable volume, limiting the building of product for inventory, headcount reductions in virtually every facility and every country in which we operated, temporary layoffs and shutdowns, minimizing the use of foundries and subcontractors in order to maximize the load of our owned facilities, as well as selected plant closures.
103730_11_ITEM7_P51_S2	We closed two facilities in the United States and consolidated manufacturing for these product lines into other facilities.
103730_11_ITEM7_P51_S3	We also consolidated our optoelectronics packaging facilities in Asia.
103730_11_ITEM7_P51_S4	We successfully closed a film capaci tor plant in Shanghai and increased production on existing equipment in Loni, India to replace the production volume of the closed plant.
103730_11_ITEM7_P52_S0	We incurred restructuring and severance costs of $62.5 million during the year ended December 31, 2008, including $28.6 million during the fourth fiscal quarter of 2008, and incurred additional restructuring and severance costs of $37.9 million during the year ended December 31, 2009.
103730_11_ITEM7_P52_S1	These costs were incurred as part of our goal to reduce manufacturing and SG A fixed costs in 2009 by $200 million compared to the year ended December 31, 2008 in response to the global economic downturn.
103730_11_ITEM7_P52_S2	Our fixed costs for the year ended December 31, 2009 decreased by $176 million versus the comparable prior year.
103730_11_ITEM7_P52_S3	Of these amounts, approximately 45% reduced costs of products sold and approximately 55% reduced SG A expenses.
103730_11_ITEM7_P52_S4	Some of our cost reductions realized in 2009 were the result of temporary measures, which we replaced with more permanent actions, and certain components of our costs, while fixed in that they do not vary with changes in volum e, are subject to volatility.
103730_11_ITEM7_P52_S5	This would include, for example, the effect of certain assets that are marked-to-market through the statement of operations, and certain transactions in foreign currencies.
103730_11_ITEM7_P52_S6	Accordingly, there is no assurance that all of the cost reductions achieved in 2009 will be maintained in future periods.
103730_11_ITEM7_P53_S0	We have realized, and expect to continue to realize, significant annual net cost savings associated with our restructuring activities.
103730_11_ITEM7_P53_S1	Since the latter half of 2008, we drastically reduced our break-even point by approximately $450 million.
103730_11_ITEM7_P53_S2	While streamlining and reducing fixed overhead, we exercised caution so that we will not negatively impact our customer service or our ability to further develop products and processes.
103730_11_ITEM7_P53_S3	The risks associated with our cost reduction programs are further detailed in Item 1A, Risk Factors.
103730_11_ITEM7_P54_S0	We did not initiate any new restructuring projects in 2010 and thus did not record any restructuring and severance expenses during the year.
103730_11_ITEM7_P55_S0	Because we believe that our manufacturing footprint is suitable to serve our customers and end markets, we do not anticipate any material restructuring expenses in 2011.
103730_11_ITEM7_P55_S1	However, the recurrence of a significant economic downturn may require us to implement additional restructuring initiatives.
103730_11_ITEM7_P56_S0	Our long-term strategy is to grow through the integration of acquired businesses, and GAAP requires plant closure and employee termination costs that we incur in connection with our acquisition activities to be recorded as expenses in our consolidated statement of operations, as such expenses are incurred.
103730_11_ITEM7_P56_S1	For this reason, we expect to have some level of future restructuring expenses if we were to complete an acquisition.
103730_11_ITEM7_P57_S0	We have substantial manufacturing operations in Israel, where we benefit from the government s grants and tax incentive programs.
103730_11_ITEM7_P57_S1	These benefits take the form of government grants and reduced tax rates that are lower than those in the United States.
103730_11_ITEM7_P57_S2	These programs have contributed substantially, predominantly in prior years, to our growth and profitability.
103730_11_ITEM7_P58_S0	The current benefits derived under these programs are not material to our consolidated results.
103730_11_ITEM7_P58_S1	Because of our significant presence in Israel, the availability of these incentive programs could have a significant positive effect on us if we relocate manufacturing capacity or develop new product lines in Israel.
103730_11_ITEM7_P58_S2	However, there are no current plans that would allow us to earn significant additional benefits.
103730_11_ITEM7_P59_S0	Effective January 2011, the corporate tax rate in Israel will decrease.
103730_11_ITEM7_P60_S0	Certain metals used in the manufacture of our products are traded on active markets, and can be subject to significant price volatility.
103730_11_ITEM7_P60_S1	Our policy is to enter into short-term commitments to purchase defined portions of annual consumption of these metals if market prices decline below budget.
103730_11_ITEM7_P60_S2	For much of 2008, these metals were trading near all-time record-high prices.
103730_11_ITEM7_P60_S3	During the fourth quarter of 2008, as metals prices declined significantly from these record-high prices, we entered into commitments to purchase a portion of our estimated 2009 metals needs, principally for copper and palladium.
103730_11_ITEM7_P60_S4	After entering into these commitments, the market prices for these metals continued to decline.
103730_11_ITEM7_P60_S5	As a result, we recorded losses on these adverse purchase commitments during the fourth quarter of 2008 totaling $6.0 million.
103730_11_ITEM7_P61_S0	Our Siliconix subsidiary maintains long-term foundry agreements with subcontractors to ensure access to external front-end capacity.
103730_11_ITEM7_P62_S0	In 2004, Siliconix signed a definitive long-term foundry agreement for semiconductor manufacturing with Tower Semiconductor (the 2004 Tower agreement ), pursuant to which Siliconix would purchase semiconductor wafers from and transfer certain technologies to Tower Semiconductor.
103730_11_ITEM7_P62_S1	Fab 1 facility over a seven to ten year period.
103730_11_ITEM7_P63_S0	The 2004 Tower agreement specified minimum quantities per month and a fixed quantity for the term of the agreement.
103730_11_ITEM7_P63_S1	Siliconix was required to pay for any short-fall in minimum order quantities specified under the agreement through the payment of penalties equal to unavoidable fixed costs.
103730_11_ITEM7_P64_S0	In March 2008, Siliconix and Tower entered into an amended and restated foundry agreement (the 2008 Tower agreement ).
103730_11_ITEM7_P64_S1	Pursuant to the 2008 Tower agreement, Tower continued to manufacture wafers covered by the 2004 Tower agreement, but at lower quantities and at lower prices, through 2009.
103730_11_ITEM7_P64_S2	Tower also manufactures wafers for other product lines acquired as part of the PCS acquisition through 2012.
103730_11_ITEM7_P65_S0	Siliconix must pay for any short-fall in the reduced minimum order quantities specified under the 2008 Tower agreement through the payment of penalties equal to unavoidable fixed costs.
103730_11_ITEM7_P66_S0	The foundry agreement with Tower was further amended in March 2009, further reducing the quantity of commitments.
103730_11_ITEM7_P66_S1	As consideration, Siliconix paid $3 million to Tower, which was recorded as a component of cost of products sold.
103730_11_ITEM7_P66_S2	A portion of this payment would be refunded if orders exceed the minimum order commitment.
103730_11_ITEM7_P66_S3	As of December 31, 2010, we have been refunded the full amount of this payment, which has been recorded as a reduction of costs of products sold.
103730_11_ITEM7_P66_S4	In 2010, Siliconix amended its agreement with Tower to extend through the second fiscal quarter of 2015.
103730_11_ITEM7_P67_S0	We are exposed to foreign currency exchange rate risks, particularly due to transactions in currencies other than the functional currencies of certain subsidiaries.
103730_11_ITEM7_P67_S1	While we have in the past used forward exchange contracts to hedge a portion of our projected cash flows from these exposures, we generally have not done so in recent periods.
103730_11_ITEM7_P68_S0	GAAP requires that entities identify the functional currency of each of their subsidiaries and measure all elements of the financial statements in that functional currency.
103730_11_ITEM7_P69_S0	A subsidiary s functional currency is the currency of the primary economic environment in which it operates.
103730_11_ITEM7_P69_S1	In cases where a subsidiary is relatively self-contained within a particular country, the local currency is generally deemed to be the functional currency.
103730_11_ITEM7_P69_S2	However, a foreign subsidiary that is a direct and integral component or extension of the parent company s operations generally would have the parent company s currency as its functional currency.
103730_11_ITEM7_P69_S3	We have both situations among our subsidiaries.
103730_11_ITEM7_P70_S0	We finance our operations in Europe and certain locations in Asia in local currencies, and accordingly, these subsidiaries utilize the local currency as their functional currency.
103730_11_ITEM7_P70_S1	For those subsidiaries where the local currency is the functional currency, assets and liabilities in the consolidated balance sheets have been translated at the rate of exchange as of the balance sheet date.
103730_11_ITEM7_P70_S2	Translation adjustments do not impact the results of operations and are reported as a separate component of stockholders equity.
103730_11_ITEM7_P71_S0	For those subsidiaries where the local currency is the functional currency, revenues and expenses are translated at the average exchange rate for the year.
103730_11_ITEM7_P71_S1	While the translation of revenues and expenses into U.S. dollars does not directly impact the consolidated statement of operations, the translation effectively increases or decreases the U.S. dollar equivalent of revenues generated and expenses incurred in those foreign currencies.
103730_11_ITEM7_P71_S2	The dollar generally was stronger in the year ended December 31, 2010 compared to the prior year, with the translation of foreign currency revenues and expenses into U.S. dollars decreasing reported revenues and expenses versus the comparable prior year periods.
103730_11_ITEM7_P72_S0	Our operations in Israel and most significant locations in Asia are largely financed in U.S. dollars, and accordingly, these subsidiaries utilize the U.S. dollar as their functional currency.
103730_11_ITEM7_P72_S1	For those foreign subsidiaries where the U.S. dollar is the functional currency, all foreign currency financial statement amounts are remeasured into U.S. dollars.
103730_11_ITEM7_P72_S2	Exchange gains and losses arising from remeasurement of foreign currency-denominated monetary assets and liabilities are included in the results of operations.
103730_11_ITEM7_P72_S3	While these subsidiaries transact most business in U.S. dollars, they may have significant costs, particularly payroll-related, which are incurred in the local currency.
103730_11_ITEM7_P72_S4	The cost of products sold and selling, general, and administrative expense for the year ended December 31, 2010 have been slightly favorably impacted (compared to the prior year) by local currency transactions of subsidiaries which use the U.S. dollar as their fun ctional currency.
103730_11_ITEM7_P73_S0	See Item 7A for additional discussion of foreign currency exchange risk.
103730_11_ITEM7_P74_S0	Our significant accounting policies are summarized in Note 1 to our consolidated financial statements.
103730_11_ITEM7_P74_S1	We identify here a number of policies that entail significant judgments or estimates.
103730_11_ITEM7_P75_S0	We recognize revenue on product sales during the period when the sales process is complete.
103730_11_ITEM7_P75_S1	This generally occurs when products are shipped to the customer in accordance with terms of an agreement of sale, title and risk of loss have been transferred, collectibility is reasonably assured, and pricing is fixed or determinable.
103730_11_ITEM7_P75_S2	For a small percentage of sales where title and risk of loss passes at point of delivery, we recognize revenue upon delivery to the customer, assuming all other criteria for revenue recognition are met.
103730_11_ITEM7_P76_S0	We historically have had agreements with distributors that provided limited rights of product return.
103730_11_ITEM7_P76_S1	We have modified these arrangements to allow distributors a limited credit for unsaleable products, which we term a scrap allowance.
103730_11_ITEM7_P76_S2	Consistent with industry practice, we also have a stock, ship and debit program whereby we consider, and grant at our discretion, requests by distributors f or credits on previously purchased products that remain in distributors inventory, to enable the distributors to offer more competitive pricing.
103730_11_ITEM7_P76_S3	In addition, we have contractual arrangements whereby we provide distributors with protection against price reductions that we initiate after the sale of product to the distributor and prior to resale by the distributor.
103730_11_ITEM7_P77_S0	We record end of period accruals for each of the programs based upon our estimate of future credits under the programs that will be attributable to sales recorded through the end of the period.
103730_11_ITEM7_P77_S1	We calculate reductions of revenue attributable to each of the programs during any period by computing the change in the accruals from the prior period and adding the credits actually given to distributors during the period under the programs.
103730_11_ITEM7_P77_S2	These procedures require the exercise of significant judgments, but we believe they enable us to reasonably estimate future credits under the programs.
103730_11_ITEM7_P78_S0	Recording and monitoring of these accruals takes place at our subsidiaries and divisions, with input from sales and marketing personnel and review, assessment, and, if necessary, adjustment by corporate management.
103730_11_ITEM7_P78_S1	While our subsidiaries and divisions utilize different methodologies based on their individual experiences, all of the methodologies take into account certain elements that management considers relevant, such as sales to distributors during the relevant period, inventory levels at the distributors, current and projected market trends and conditions, recent and historical activity under the relevant programs, changes in program policies, and open requests for credits.
103730_11_ITEM7_P78_S2	In our judgment, the different methodologies provide us with equally reliable estimates upon which to base our accruals.
103730_11_ITEM7_P78_S3	We do not track the credits that we record against specific products sold from distributor inventories, so as to directly compare revenue redu ction for credits recorded during any period with credits ultimately awarded in respect of products sold during that period.
103730_11_ITEM7_P78_S4	Nevertheless, we believe that we have an adequate basis to assess the reasonableness and reliability of our estimates.
103730_11_ITEM7_P79_S0	We recognize royalty revenue in accordance with agreed upon terms when performance obligations are satisfied, the amount is fixed or determinable, and collectibility is reasonably assured.
103730_11_ITEM7_P80_S0	We earn royalties at the point of sale of products which incorporate licensed intellectual property.
103730_11_ITEM7_P80_S1	The amount of royalties recognized is determined based on our licensees periodic reporting to us and judgments and estimates by Vishay management that we believe are reasonable.
103730_11_ITEM7_P80_S2	However, it is possible that actual results may differ from our estimates.
103730_11_ITEM7_P81_S0	Our accounts receivable represent a significant portion of our current assets.
103730_11_ITEM7_P81_S1	We are required to estimate the collectibility of our receivables and to establish allowances for the amount of receivables that will prove uncollectible.
103730_11_ITEM7_P81_S2	We base these allowances on our historical collection experience, the length of time our receivables are outstanding, the financial circumstances of individual customers, and general business and economic conditions.
103730_11_ITEM7_P82_S0	Due to Vishay s large number of customers and their dispersion across many countries and industries, we have limited exposure to concentrations of credit risk.
103730_11_ITEM7_P83_S0	We value our inventories at the lower of cost or market, with cost determined under the first-in, first-out method and market based upon net realizable value.
103730_11_ITEM7_P83_S1	The valuation of our inventories requires our management to make market estimates.
103730_11_ITEM7_P83_S2	For work in process goods, we are required to estimate the cost to completion of the products and the prices at which we will be able to sell the products.
103730_11_ITEM7_P83_S3	For finished goods, we must assess the prices at which we believe the inventory can be sold.
103730_11_ITEM7_P83_S4	Inventories are also adjusted for estimated obsolescence and written down to net realizable value based upon estimates of future demand, technology developments and market conditions.
103730_11_ITEM7_P84_S0	Certain metals used in the manufacture of our products are traded on active markets, and can be subject to significant price volatility.
103730_11_ITEM7_P84_S1	Our policy is to enter into short-term commitments to purchase defined portions of annual consumption of these metals if market prices decline below budget.
103730_11_ITEM7_P84_S2	We record losses and related liabilities when the contractually obligated purchase price under our purchase commitments exceed quoted market prices for the metals.
103730_11_ITEM7_P85_S0	After entering into commitments to purchase a portion of our estimated 2009 metals needs, principally for copper and palladium, the market prices for these metals declined below our contractually obligated purchase price.
103730_11_ITEM7_P85_S1	As a result, we recorded losses on these adverse purchase commitments during the fourth quarter of 2008.
103730_11_ITEM7_P85_S2	These losses, which aggregate to $6.0 million, are recorded on a separate line in the consolidated statement of operations.
103730_11_ITEM7_P86_S0	Our restructuring activities are designed to reduce both fixed and variable costs in our existing and acquired entities.
103730_11_ITEM7_P86_S1	Restructuring costs, including acquisition-related restructuring costs, are expensed during the period in which we determine that we will incur those costs, and all of the requirements for accrual are met.
103730_11_ITEM7_P86_S2	We did not initiate any new restructuring projects in 2010 and thus did not record any restructuring and severance expenses during the year.
103730_11_ITEM7_P86_S3	In 2009 and 2008, we recorded restructuring and severance costs of approximately $37.9 million and $62.5 million, respectively.
103730_11_ITEM7_P87_S0	Because these costs are recorded based upon estimates, our actual expenditures for the restructuring activities may differ from the initially recorded costs.
103730_11_ITEM7_P87_S1	If this happens, we will have to adjust our estimates in future periods, either by recording additional expenses in future periods, if our initial estimates were too low, or by reversing part of the charges that we recorded initially, if our initial estimates were too high.
103730_11_ITEM7_P88_S0	Goodwill represents the excess of the cost of a business acquired over the fair value of the related net assets at the date of acquisition.
103730_11_ITEM7_P88_S1	Goodwill is not amortized but rather tested for impairment at least annually.
103730_11_ITEM7_P88_S2	These impairment tests must be performed more frequently whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the asset might be impaired.
103730_11_ITEM7_P89_S0	GAAP prescribes a two-step method for determining goodwill impairment.
103730_11_ITEM7_P89_S1	In the first step, we determine the fair value of the reporting unit and compare the fair value to the net book value of the reporting unit.
103730_11_ITEM7_P89_S2	The fair value of the reporting unit is determined using various valuation techniques, including a comparable companies market multiple approach and a discounted cash flow analysis (an income approach).
103730_11_ITEM7_P89_S3	The comparable companies utilized in our evaluation are generally the members of our peer group included in the presentation of our stock performance graph in Item 5 of our Annual Report on Form 10-K.
103730_11_ITEM7_P90_S0	In step two, we determine the implied fair value of goodwill in the same manner as if we had acquired those business units.
103730_11_ITEM7_P90_S1	Specifically, we must allocate the fair value of the reporting unit to all of the assets of that unit, including any unrecognized intangible assets, in a hypothetical calculation that would yield the implied fair value of goodwill.
103730_11_ITEM7_P90_S2	The impairment loss is measured as the difference between the book value of the goodwill and the implied fair value of the goodwill computed in step two.
103730_11_ITEM7_P91_S0	Fair value of reporting units, and the underlying assets and liabilities of those reporting units, is measured at a point in time, and reflects specific market conditions as of the measurement date.
103730_11_ITEM7_P92_S0	We performed our annual impairment test as of the first day of the fourth fiscal quarter.
103730_11_ITEM7_P92_S1	In light of a sustained decline in market capitalization that we and our peer group companies experienced in each successive quarter of 2008, and other factors, we determined that impairment tests were necessary as of the end of the second, third, and fourth fiscal quarters of 2008, and recorded goodwill impairment charges in each of those quarters.
103730_11_ITEM7_P92_S2	The interim test performed as of the last day of the third fiscal quarter of 2008, was effectively our annual impairment test for 2008.
103730_11_ITEM7_P92_S3	Subsequent to recording these impairment charges, there was no remaining goodwill recorded on the consolidated balance sheet.
103730_11_ITEM7_P92_S4	In total, we recorded goodwill impairment charg es aggregating $1,696.2 million in year ended December 31, 2008.
103730_11_ITEM7_P93_S0	The determination of the fair value of the reporting units and the allocation of that value to individual assets and liabilities within those reporting units requires us to make significant estimates and assumptions.
103730_11_ITEM7_P93_S1	These estimates and assumptions primarily include, but are not limited to: the selection of appropriate peer group companies; control premiums appropriate for acquisitions in the industries in which we compete; the discount rate; terminal growth rates; and forecasts of revenue, operating income, depreciation and amortization, and capital expenditures.
103730_11_ITEM7_P94_S0	The allocation requires several analyses to determine fair value of assets and liabilities including, among others, completed technology, tradenames, in-process research and development, customer relationships, and certain property and equipment (valued at replacement costs).
103730_11_ITEM7_P95_S0	Due to the inherent uncertainty involved in making these estimates, actual financial results could differ from those estimates.
103730_11_ITEM7_P95_S1	In addition, changes in assumptions concerning future financial results or other underlying assumptions could have a significant impact on either the fair value of the reporting unit or the amount of the goodwill impairment charge.
103730_11_ITEM7_P96_S0	The goodwill impairment charge is noncash in nature and did not affect our liquidity, cash flows from operating activities, or debt covenants, and will not have a material impact on future operations.
103730_11_ITEM7_P97_S0	We assess the impairment of our long-lived assets, other than goodwill and tradenames, including property and equipment, long-term prepaid assets, and identifiable intangible assets subject to amortization, whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable.
103730_11_ITEM7_P98_S0	Long-lived assets are grouped at the lowest level of independent cash flows and evaluated as a group.
103730_11_ITEM7_P98_S1	Factors we consider important, which could trigger an impairment review, include significant changes in the manner of our use of the assets, changes in historical or projected operating performance, and significant negative economic trends.
103730_11_ITEM7_P99_S0	The carrying value of a long-lived asset group is considered impaired when the total projected undiscounted cash flows from such asset group are separately identifiable and are less than the carrying value.
103730_11_ITEM7_P99_S1	In that event, a loss is recognized based on the amount by which the carrying value exceeds the f air market value of the long-lived asset group, primarily determined using discounted future cash flows.
103730_11_ITEM7_P100_S0	Indefinite-lived intangible assets (which for us are comprised entirely of tradenames) are not amortized, but similar to goodwill, are tested for impairment at least annually.
103730_11_ITEM7_P100_S1	These tests are performed more frequently if there are triggering events.
103730_11_ITEM7_P101_S0	The fair value of the tradenames is measured as the discounted cash flow savings realized from owning such tradenames and not having to pay a royalty for their use.
103730_11_ITEM7_P102_S0	Prior to completing the interim assessment of goodwill for impairment during the second, third, and fourth fiscal quarters of 2008, we performed a recoverability test of certain long-lived assets and certain indefinite-lived intangible assets.
103730_11_ITEM7_P102_S1	As a result of those assessments, we recorded indefinite-lived intangible asset impairment charges totaling $27 million during the third fiscal quarter of 2008.
103730_11_ITEM7_P102_S2	There was no impairment identified through the annual impairment tests completed in 2010 or 2009.
103730_11_ITEM7_P103_S0	We did not record any fixed asset write-downs during the year ended December 31, 2010.
103730_11_ITEM7_P103_S1	During the years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008, we recorded asset write-downs of $0.7 million and $5.1 million, respectively.
103730_11_ITEM7_P103_S2	Fixed asset write-downs included amounts to reduce the carrying value of certain buildings which had been vacated as part of our restructuring activities, based on expected future selling prices or the present value of expected rental receipts.
103730_11_ITEM7_P103_S3	Fixed asset write-downs also included charges to write down certain equipment to salvage value after we determined that it would not be used at other Vishay locations subsequent to the completion of our restructuring plans.
103730_11_ITEM7_P104_S0	The evaluation of the recoverability of long-lived assets, and the determination of their fair value, requires us to make significant estimates and assumptions.
103730_11_ITEM7_P104_S1	These estimates and assumptions primarily include, but are not limited to: the identification of the asset group at the lowest level of independent cash flows and the principal asset of the group; the discount rate; terminal growth rates; and forecasts of revenue, operating income, depreciation and amortization, and capital expenditures.
103730_11_ITEM7_P105_S0	The evaluation of the fair value of indefinite-lived trademarks also requires us to make significant estimates and assumptions.
103730_11_ITEM7_P105_S1	These estimates and assumptions primarily include, but are not limited to: the assumed market-royalty rate; the discount rate; terminal growth rates; and forecasts of revenue.
103730_11_ITEM7_P106_S0	Due to the inherent uncertainty involved in making these estimates, actual results could differ from those estimates.
103730_11_ITEM7_P106_S1	In addition, changes in underlying assumptions would have a significant impact on the conclusion that an asset group s carrying value is recoverable, that an indefinite-lived asset is not impaired, or the determination of any impairment charge if it was determined that the asset values were indeed impaired.
103730_11_ITEM7_P107_S0	Accounting for defined benefit pension and other postretirement plans involves numerous assumptions and estimates.
103730_11_ITEM7_P107_S1	The discount rate at which obligations could effectively be settled and the expected long-term rate of return on plan assets are two critical assumptions in measuring the cost and benefit obligations of our pension and other postretirement benefit plans.
103730_11_ITEM7_P107_S2	Other important assumptions include the anticipated rate of future increases in compensation levels, estimated mortality, and for postretirement medical plans, increases or trends in health care costs.
103730_11_ITEM7_P107_S3	Management reviews these assumptions at least annually.
103730_11_ITEM7_P107_S4	We use independent actuaries to assist us in formulating assumptions and making estimates.
103730_11_ITEM7_P107_S5	These assumptions are updated periodically to reflect the actual experience and expectations on a plan specific basis as appropriate.
103730_11_ITEM7_P108_S0	Our defined benefit plans are concentrated in the United States, Germany, and the Republic of China (Taiwan).
103730_11_ITEM7_P108_S1	Plans in these countries comprise approximately 95% of our retirement obligations at December 31, 2010.
103730_11_ITEM7_P109_S0	In the U.S., we utilize published long-term high quality bond indices to determine the discount rate at the measurement date.
103730_11_ITEM7_P109_S1	In Germany and the Republic of China (Taiwan), we utilize published long-term government bond rates to determine the discount rate at the measurement date.
103730_11_ITEM7_P109_S2	We utilize bond yields at various maturity dates that reflect the timing of expected future benefit payments.
103730_11_ITEM7_P109_S3	We believe the discount rates selected are the rates at which these obligations could effectively be settled.
103730_11_ITEM7_P110_S0	Within the U.S., we establish strategic asset allocation percentage targets and appropriate benchmarks for significant asset classes with the aim of achieving a prudent balance between return and risk.
103730_11_ITEM7_P110_S1	Many of our non-U.S. plans are unfunded based on local laws and customs.
103730_11_ITEM7_P110_S2	For those non-U.S. plans that do maintain investments, their asset holdings are primarily cash and fixed income securities, based on local laws and customs.
103730_11_ITEM7_P111_S0	We set the expected long-term rate of return based on the expected long-term average rates of return to be achieved by the underlying investment portfolios.
103730_11_ITEM7_P111_S1	In establishing this rate, we consider historical and expected returns for the asset classes in which the plans are invested, advice from pension consultants and investment advisors, and current economic and capital market conditions.
103730_11_ITEM7_P111_S2	The expected return on plan assets is incorporated into the computation of pension expense.
103730_11_ITEM7_P111_S3	The difference between this expect ed return and the actual return on plan assets is deferred.
103730_11_ITEM7_P112_S0	The net deferral of past asset losses (gains) affects the calculated value of plan assets and, ultimately, future pension expense (income).
103730_11_ITEM7_P113_S0	We expect net periodic pension cost in 2011 to approximate net periodic pension cost recognized in 2010.
103730_11_ITEM7_P114_S0	During the fourth fiscal quarter of 2008, we adopted amendments to our principal U.S. defined benefit pension plans, such that effective January 1, 2009, the plans were frozen.
103730_11_ITEM7_P114_S1	Pursuant to these amendments, no new employees may participate in the plans, no further participant contributions will be required or permitted, and no further benefits shall accrue after December 31, 2008.
103730_11_ITEM7_P114_S2	As a result of these amendments, net periodic pension cost for 2010 and 2009 did not include any service cost, thus partially offsetting the increases due to increased amortization of actuarial losses and lower expected returns on plan assets.
103730_11_ITEM7_P115_S0	To mitigate the loss in benefits of these employees, effective January 1, 2009, we increased the company-match portion of our 401(k) defined contribution savings plan for employees impacted by the pension freeze.
103730_11_ITEM7_P116_S0	We believe that the current assumptions used to estimate plan obligations and annual expenses are appropriate.
103730_11_ITEM7_P116_S1	However, if economic conditions change or if our investment strategy changes, we may be inclined to change some of our assumptions, and the resulting change could have a material impact on the consolidated statements of operations and on the consolidated balance sheet.
103730_11_ITEM7_P117_S0	We are subject to income taxes in the U.S. and numerous foreign jurisdictions.
103730_11_ITEM7_P117_S1	Significant judgment is required in evaluating our tax positions and determining our provision for income taxes.
103730_11_ITEM7_P118_S0	During the ordinary course of business, there are many transactions and calculations for which the ultimate tax determination is uncertain.
103730_11_ITEM7_P118_S1	We establish reserves for tax-related uncertainties based on estimates of whether, and the extent to which, additional taxes will be due.
103730_11_ITEM7_P118_S2	These reserves are established when we believe that certain positions might be challenged despite our belief that our tax return positions are fully supportable.
103730_11_ITEM7_P118_S3	We adjust these reserves in light of changing facts and circumstances and the provision for income taxes includes the impact of reserve provisions and changes to reserves that are considered appropriate.
103730_11_ITEM7_P119_S0	These accruals are based on management s best estimate of potential tax exposures.
103730_11_ITEM7_P119_S1	When particular matters arise, a number of years may elapse before such matters are audited and finally resolved.
103730_11_ITEM7_P119_S2	Favorable resolution of such matters could be recognized as a reduction to our effective tax rate in the year of resolution.
103730_11_ITEM7_P119_S3	Unfavorable resolution of any particular issue could increase the effective tax rate and may require the use of cash in the year of resolution.
103730_11_ITEM7_P120_S0	We file U.S. federal income tax returns, as well as income tax returns in multiple U.S. state and foreign jurisdictions.
103730_11_ITEM7_P120_S1	The U.S. Internal Revenue Service concluded its examinations of Vishay s U.S. federal tax returns for all tax years through 2002.
103730_11_ITEM7_P120_S2	Because of net operating losses, our U.S. federal tax returns for 2003 and later years remain subject to examination.
103730_11_ITEM7_P120_S3	Examinations of most principal subsidiaries in Israel through the 2007 tax year were concluded in 2010.
103730_11_ITEM7_P120_S4	The tax returns of significant non-U.S. subsidiaries are currently under examination in Germany (2005 through 2008), India (2004 through 2009), China (2006 through 2009), and the Republic of China (Taiwan) (2000 through 2008).
103730_11_ITEM7_P120_S5	We and our subsidiaries are also subject to income taxes in other taxing jurisdictions in the U.S. and around the world, many of which are still open to examinations.
103730_11_ITEM7_P121_S0	We account for uncertainty in income tax positions using the minimum recognition threshold a tax position is required to meet before being recognized in the financial statements as prescribed in GAAP.
103730_11_ITEM7_P121_S1	For a tax benefit to be recognized, a tax position must be more likely than not to be sustained upon examination by taxing authorities.
103730_11_ITEM7_P122_S0	We have recorded deferred tax assets representing future tax benefits, but may not be able to realize these future tax benefits in certain jurisdictions.
103730_11_ITEM7_P122_S1	Significant judgment is required in determining the expected future realizability of these deferred tax assets.
103730_11_ITEM7_P122_S2	We periodically evaluate the realizability of our deferred tax assets by assessing the valuation allowance and by adjusting the amount of such allowance, if necessary.
103730_11_ITEM7_P122_S3	The factors used to assess the likelihood of realization include deferred tax liabilities, our forecast of future taxable income, and available tax planning strategies that could be implemented to realize the net deferred tax assets.
103730_11_ITEM7_P123_S0	In 2010, we reversed $57.9 million of valuation allowances in the U.S. and Israel, resulting in a one-time tax benefit.
103730_11_ITEM7_P123_S1	In January 2011, a new tax law was enacted in Israel which effectively lowers the corporate income tax rate on certain types of income earned after December 31, 2 010.
103730_11_ITEM7_P123_S2	Accordingly, our deferred tax assets in Israel will be written down to reflect the lower tax rate, and we anticipate a one-time tax expense in the first fiscal quarter of 2011 of approximately $10 million.

103730_11_ITEM7_P124_S1	Accordingly, no provision has been made for U.S. federal and state income taxes on these foreign earnings.
103730_11_ITEM7_P124_S2	Upon distribution of those earnings in the form of dividends or otherwise, we would be subject to U.S. income taxes (subject to an adjustment for foreign tax credits), state income taxes, incremental foreign income taxes, and withholding taxes payable to various foreign countries.

103730_11_ITEM7_P178_S3	Accordingly, our effective tax rate is generally less than the U.S. statutory tax rate.

103730_11_ITEM7_P179_S1	Under applicable accounting guidance, we may not recognize deferred tax assets for loss carryforwards in jurisdictions where there is a recent history of cumulative losses, where there is no taxable income in the carryback period, where there is insufficient evidence of future earnings to overcome the loss history and where there is no other positive evidence, such as the likely reversal of taxable temporary differences, that would result in the utilization of loss carryforwards for tax purposes.

103730_11_ITEM7A_P0_S0	We are exposed to certain financial risks, including fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, interest rates, and commodity prices.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P0_S1	We manage our exposure to these market risks through internally established policies and procedures and, when deemed appropriate, through the use of derivative financial instruments.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P0_S2	Our policies do not allow speculation in derivative instruments for profit or execution of derivative instrument contracts for which there are no underlying exposures.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P0_S3	We do not use financial instruments for trading purposes and we are not a party to any leveraged derivatives.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P0_S4	We monitor our underlying market risk exposures on an ongoing basis and believe that we can modify or adapt our hedging strategies as needed.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P1_S0	We are exposed to changes in interest rates as a result of our borrowing activities and our cash balances.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P1_S1	On a selective basis, we have in the past entered into interest rate swap or cap agreements to reduce the potential negative impact that increases in interest rates could have on our outstanding variable rate debt.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P1_S2	As of December 31, 2010, 2009, and 2008 we did not have any outstanding interest rate swap or cap agreements.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P2_S0	We are exposed to changes in interest rates on our exchangeable notes due 2102.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P2_S1	The exchangeable notes, of which $95 million are outstanding, bear interest at LIBOR (reset quarterly).
103730_11_ITEM7A_P3_S0	The interest paid on our credit facility is based on a LIBOR spread.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P3_S1	At December 31, 2010, we had $240 million outstanding under the revolving credit facility.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P3_S2	The present amounts outstanding under the revolving credit commitment bears interest at LIBOR plus 1.65%.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P4_S0	Our convertible senior debentures due 2040 bear interest at a fixed rate, and accordingly are not subject to interest rate fluctuation risks.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P5_S0	At December 31, 2010, we have $897.3 million of cash and cash equivalents, which earns interest at various variable rates.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P6_S0	Based on the debt and cash positions at December 31, 2010, we would expect a 50 basis point increase or decrease in interest rates to increase or decrease our annualized net earnings by approximately $2.1 million.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P7_S0	See Note 6 to our consolidated financial statements for additional information about our long-term debt.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P7_S1	Also see Economic Outlook and Impact on Operations and Future Financial Results included in Item 7, Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations for additional discussion of market risks.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P8_S0	We are exposed to foreign currency exchange rate risks, particularly due to market values of transactions in currencies other than the functional currencies of certain subsidiaries.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P8_S1	From time to time, we utilize forward contracts to hedge a portion of projected cash flows from these exposures.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P8_S2	As of December 31, 2010, we did not have any outstanding foreign currency forward exchange contracts.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P9_S0	Our significant foreign subsidiaries are located in Germany, Israel, and Asia.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P9_S1	We finance our operations in Europe and certain locations in Asia in local currencies.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P9_S2	Our operations in Israel and most significant locations in Asia are largely financed in U.S. dollars, but these subsidiaries also have significant transactions in local currencies.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P9_S3	Our exposure to foreign currency risk is mitigated to the extent that the costs incurred and the revenues earned in a particular currency offset one another.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P9_S4	Our exposure to foreign currency risk is more pronounced in Israel, the Czech Republic, and China because the percentage of expenses denominated in Israeli shekels, Czech koruna, and Chinese renminbi to total expenses is much greater than the percentage of sales denominated in Israeli shekels, Czech koruna, and Chinese renminbi to total sales.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P9_S5	Therefore, if the Israeli shekel, Czech koruna, and Chinese renminbi strengthen against all or most of our other major currencies, our operating profit is reduced.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P9_S6	We also have a higher percentage of Euro-denominated sales than expenses.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P9_S7	Therefore, when the Euro strengthens against all or most of our other major currencies, our operating profit is increased.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P9_S8	Accordingly, we monitor several important cross-rates.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P10_S0	We have performed sensitivity analyses as of December 31, 2010 and 2009, using a model that measures the change in the values arising from a hypothetical 10% adverse movement in foreign currency exchange rates relative to the U.S. dollar, with all other variables held constant.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P10_S1	The foreign currency exchange rates we used were based on market rates in effect at December 31, 2010 and 2009.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P10_S2	The sensitivity analyses indicated that a hypothetical 10% adverse movement in foreign currency exchange rates would impact our net earnings by approximately $19.9 million and $6.4 million at December 31, 2010 and December 31, 2009, respectively, although individual line items in our consolidated statement of operations would be materially affected.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P10_S3	For example, a 10% weakening in all foreign currencies would increase the U.S. dollar equivalent of operating income generated in foreign currencies, which would be offset by foreign exchange losses of our f oreign subsidiaries that have significant transactions in U.S. dollars or have the U.S. dollar as their functional currency.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P11_S0	A change in the mix of the currencies in which we transact our business could have a material effect on the estimated impact of the hypothetical 10% movement in the value of the U.S. dollar.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P11_S1	Furthermore, the timing of cash receipts and disbursements could result in materially different actual results versus the hypothetical 10% movement in the value of the U.S. dollar, particularly if there are significant changes in exchange rates in a short period of time.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P12_S0	Although most materials incorporated in our products are available from a number of sources, certain materials are available only from a relatively limited number of suppliers or are subject to significant price volatility.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P12_S1	Our results of operations may be materially and adversely affected if we have difficulty obtaining these raw materials, the quality of available raw materials deteriorates, or there are significant price changes for these raw materials.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P12_S2	The determination that any of the raw materials used in our products are conflict minerals originating from the Democratic Republic of the Congo could increase the probability that we will encounter the challenges noted above, incur additional expenses to comply with government regulations, and face public scrutiny.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P12_S3	For periods in which the prices of these raw materials are rising, we may be unable to pass on the increased cost to our customers which would result in decreased margins for the products in which they are used.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P12_S4	For periods in which the prices are declining, we may be required to write down our inventory carrying cost of these raw materials, since we record our inventory at the lower of cost or market.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P12_S5	Depending on the extent of the difference between market price and our carrying cost, this write-down could have a material adverse effect on our net earnings.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P12_S6	We also may need to record losses for adverse purchase commitments for these materials in periods of declining prices.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P13_S0	Silicon wafers are the most important raw material for the manufacturing of our semiconductor products.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P14_S0	Silicon wafers are manufactured from high-purity silicon, a metalloid.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P14_S1	There have at times been industry-wide shortages of high-purity silicon resulting primarily from growing demand of the electronic component and solar power industries, and limited growth in high-purity silicon manufacturing capacities.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P14_S2	Shifts in demand for high-purity silicon and in turn, silicon wafers, have resulted in significant fluctuation in prices of silicon wafers.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P15_S0	We are a major consumer of the world s annual production of tantalum, a metal used in the manufacturing of tantalum capacitors.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P15_S1	There are few suppliers that process tantalum ore into capacitor grade tantalum powder.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P15_S2	We acquire tantalum powder and wire from all of them under short-term commitments.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P15_S3	See Note 14 to our consolidated financial statements for information on our previous long-term tantalum purchase commitments, which expired in 2006.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P16_S0	Palladium, a metal used to produce multi-layer ceramic capacitors, is currently found primarily in South Africa and Russia.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P16_S1	Palladium is a commodity metal that is subject to price volatility.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P16_S2	We periodically enter into short-term commitments to purchase palladium.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P17_S0	Certain metals used in the manufacture of our products, such as copper, are traded on active markets, and can be subject to significant price volatility.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P17_S1	Our policy is to enter into short-term commitments to purchase defined portions of annual consumption of these metals if market prices decline below budget.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P17_S2	For much of 2008, these metals were trading near all-time record-high prices.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P17_S3	During the fourth quarter of 2008, as metals prices declined significantly from these record-high prices, we entered into commitments to purchase a portion of our estimated 2009 metals needs, principally for copper and palladium.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P17_S4	After entering into these commitments, the market prices for these metals continued to decline.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P17_S5	As a result, we recorded losses on these adverse purchase commitments during the fourth quarter of 2008.
103730_11_ITEM7A_P18_S0	We estimate that a 10% increase or decrease in the costs of raw materials subject to commodity price risk would decrease or increase our net earnings by $12.5 million, assuming that such changes in our costs have no impact on the selling prices of our products and that we have no pending commitments to purchase metals at fixed prices.

103730_11_ITEM15_P62_S0	The Board of Directors and Stockholders of Vishay Intertechnology, Inc.:
103730_11_ITEM15_P63_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Vishay Intertechnology, Inc. as of December 31, 2010 and 2009, and the related consolidated statements of operations, stockholders equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2010.
103730_11_ITEM15_P63_S1	These financial statements are the responsibility of the Company s management.
103730_11_ITEM15_P63_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits.
103730_11_ITEM15_P64_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
103730_11_ITEM15_P64_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
103730_11_ITEM15_P65_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
103730_11_ITEM15_P65_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
103730_11_ITEM15_P65_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
103730_11_ITEM15_P66_S0	In our opinion, the financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the consolidated financial position of Vishay Intertechnology, Inc. at December 31, 2010 and 2009, and the consolidated results of its operations and its cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2010, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
103730_11_ITEM15_P67_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), Vishay Intertechnology, Inc. s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2010, based on criteria established in Internal Control-Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission and our report dated February 25, 2011 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.
103730_11_ITEM15_P68_S0	The Board of Directors and Stockholders of Vishay Intertechnology, Inc.:
103730_11_ITEM15_P69_S0	We have audited Vishay Intertechnology Inc. s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2010, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (the COSO criteria).
103730_11_ITEM15_P69_S1	Vishay Intertechnology Inc. s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting, and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting included in the accompanying Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting.
103730_11_ITEM15_P69_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
103730_11_ITEM15_P70_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
103730_11_ITEM15_P70_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
103730_11_ITEM15_P70_S2	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
103730_11_ITEM15_P70_S3	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
103730_11_ITEM15_P71_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
103730_11_ITEM15_P71_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
103730_11_ITEM15_P72_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
103730_11_ITEM15_P72_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
103730_11_ITEM15_P73_S0	In our opinion, Vishay Intertechnology, Inc. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2010, based on the COSO criteria .

103730_11_ITEM15_P76_S0	Vishay Intertechnology, Inc. ( Vishay or the Company ) is a global manufacturer and supplier of discrete semiconductors and passive electronic components, including power MOSFETs, power integrated circuits, transistors, diodes, optoelectronic components, resistors, capacitors, and inductors.
103730_11_ITEM15_P76_S1	Semiconductors and electronic components manufactured by the Company are used in virtually all types of electronic products, including those in the industrial, computer, automotive, consumer electronics products, telecommunications, power supplies, military/aerospace, and medical industries.
103730_11_ITEM15_P77_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States ( GAAP ) requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes.
103730_11_ITEM15_P77_S1	Actual results could differ significantly from those estimates.
103730_11_ITEM15_P78_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Vishay and all of its subsidiaries in which a controlling financial interest is maintained.
103730_11_ITEM15_P78_S1	For those consolidated subsidiaries in which the Company s ownership is less than 100 percent, the outside stockholders interests are shown as noncontrolling interest in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
103730_11_ITEM15_P78_S2	Investments in affiliates over which the Company has significant influence but not a controlling interest are carried on the equity basis.
103730_11_ITEM15_P78_S3	Investments in affiliates over which the Company does not have significant influence are accounted for by the cost method.

103730_11_ITEM15_P79_S0	In connection with the preparation of the consolidated financial statements and in accordance with GAAP, the Company evaluated subsequent events after the balance sheet date of December 31, 2010 through the date these financial statements were issued through the filing of this annual report on Form 10-K with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.
103730_11_ITEM15_P80_S0	The Company recognizes revenue on product sales during the period when the sales process is complete.
103730_11_ITEM15_P80_S1	This generally occurs when products are shipped to the customer in accordance with terms of an agreement of sale, title and risk of loss have been transferred, collectibility is reasonably assured, and pricing is fixed or determinable.
103730_11_ITEM15_P80_S2	For a small percentage of sales where title and risk of loss passes at point of delivery, the Company recognizes revenue upon delivery to the customer, assuming all other criteria for revenue recognition are met.
103730_11_ITEM15_P81_S0	The Company historically has had agreements with distributors that provided limited rights of product return.
103730_11_ITEM15_P81_S1	The Company has modified these arrangements to allow distributors a limited credit for unsaleable products, which it terms a scrap allowance.
103730_11_ITEM15_P81_S2	Consistent with industry practice, the Company also has a stock, ship and debit program whereby it considers requests b y distributors for credits on previously purchased products that remain in distributors inventory, to enable the distributors to offer more competitive pricing.
103730_11_ITEM15_P81_S3	In addition, the Company has contractual arrangements whereby it provides distributors with protection against price reductions initiated by the Company after product is sold by the Company to the distributor and prior to resale by the distributor.
103730_11_ITEM15_P82_S0	The Company records a reduction of revenue during each period, and records a related accrued expense for the period, based upon its estimate of product returns, scrap allowances, stock, ship and debit credits, and price protection credits that will be attributable to sales recorded through the end of the period.
103730_11_ITEM15_P82_S1	The Company makes these estimates based upon sales levels to its distributors during the period, inventory levels at the distributors, current and projected market conditions, and historical experience under the programs.
103730_11_ITEM15_P82_S2	While the Company utilizes a number of different methodologies to estimate the accruals, all of the methodologies take into account sales levels to distributors during the relevant period, inventory levels at the distributors, current and projected market trends and conditions, recent and historical activity under the relevant programs, changes in program policies, and open requests for credits.
103730_11_ITEM15_P83_S0	T hese procedures require the exercise of significant judgments.
103730_11_ITEM15_P83_S1	The Company believes that it has a reasonable basis to estimate future credits under the programs.
103730_11_ITEM15_P84_S0	Royalty revenues, included in net revenues on the consolidated statements of operations, were $5,781,000, $5,710,000, and $2,996,000 for the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009, and 2008, respectively.
103730_11_ITEM15_P84_S1	The Company records royalty revenue in accordance with agreed upon terms when performance obligations are satisfied, the amount is fixed or determinable, and collectibility is reasonably assured.
103730_11_ITEM15_P85_S0	Vishay earns royalties at the point of sale of products which incorporate licensed intellectual property.
103730_11_ITEM15_P85_S1	Accordingly, the amount of royalties recognized is determined based on periodic reporting to Vishay by its licensees, and based on judgments and estimates by Vishay management, which management considers reasonable.

103730_11_ITEM15_P89_S0	The provision for income taxes is determined using the asset and liability approach of accounting for income taxes.
103730_11_ITEM15_P89_S1	Under this approach, deferred taxes represent the future tax consequences expected to occur when the reported amounts of assets and liabilities are recovered or paid.
103730_11_ITEM15_P90_S0	The provision for income taxes represents income taxes paid or payable for the current year plus the change in deferred taxes during the year.
103730_11_ITEM15_P90_S1	Deferred taxes result from differences between the financial and tax bases of the Company s assets and liabilities and are adjusted for changes in tax rates and tax laws when changes are enacted.
103730_11_ITEM15_P90_S2	Valuation allowances have been established for deferred tax assets which the Company believes do not meet GAAP criteria of more likely than not.
103730_11_ITEM15_P90_S3	This criterion requires a level of judgment regarding future taxable income, which may be revised due to changes in market conditions, tax laws, or other factors.
103730_11_ITEM15_P90_S4	If the Company s assumptions and estimates change in the future, valuation allowances established may be increased, resulting in increased tax expense.
103730_11_ITEM15_P90_S5	Conversely, if the Company is ultimately able to utilize all or a portion of the deferred tax assets for which a valuation allowance has been established, then the related portion of the valuation allowance can be released, resulting in decreased tax expense.

103730_11_ITEM15_P91_S1	Accordingly, no provision has been made for U.S. federal and state income taxes on these foreign earnings.
103730_11_ITEM15_P91_S2	Upon distribution of those earnings in the form of dividends or otherwise, the Company would be subject to U.S. income taxes (subject to an adjustment for foreign tax credits), state income taxes, incremental foreign income taxes, and withholding taxes payable to the various foreign countries.

103730_11_ITEM15_P102_S0	GAAP prescribes a two-step method for determining goodwill impairment.
103730_11_ITEM15_P102_S1	In the first step, the Company determines the fair value of the reporting unit and compares that fair value to the net book value of the reporting unit.
103730_11_ITEM15_P102_S2	The fair value of the reporting unit is determined using various valuation techniques, including a comparable companies market multiple approach and a discounted cash flow analysis (an income approach).
103730_11_ITEM15_P103_S0	If the net book value of the reporting unit were to exceed the fair value, the Company would then perform the second step of the impairment test, which requires allocation of the reporting unit s fair value to all of its assets and liabilities in a manner similar to a purchase price allocation, with any residual fair value being allocated to goodwill.
103730_11_ITEM15_P103_S1	An impairment charge will be recognized only when the implied fair value of a reporting unit s goodwill is less than its carrying amount.
103730_11_ITEM15_P104_S0	As more fully described in Note 3, in light of a sustained decline in market capitalization that Vishay and its peer group companies experienced in 2008, and other factors, Vishay determined that an impairment test was necessary as of the end of the second, third, and fourth fiscal quarters of 2008, and recorded goodwill impairment charges in each of those quarters.
103730_11_ITEM15_P105_S0	The Company s required annual impairment test was completed as of the first day of the fourth fiscal quarter of each year.
103730_11_ITEM15_P105_S1	The interim impairment test performed as of September 27, 2008, the last day of the 2008 third fiscal quarter, was effectively the Company s annual impairment test for 2008.
103730_11_ITEM15_P105_S2	Subsequent to recording the goodwill impairment charges in 2008, there was no remaining goodwill recorded on the consolidated balance sheet.
103730_11_ITEM15_P106_S0	The fair value of the tradenames is measured as the discounted cash flow savings realized from owning such tradenames and not having to pay a royalty for their use.
103730_11_ITEM15_P107_S0	Also as more fully described in Note 3, prior to completing the interim assessment of goodwill for impairment during the second, third, and fourth quarters of 2008, the Company performed interim impairment tests for certain indefinite-lived intangible assets.
103730_11_ITEM15_P107_S1	As a result of those assessments, the Company recorded impairment charges during the third fiscal quarter of 2008 related to certain tradenames.
103730_11_ITEM15_P108_S0	The required annual impairment test of tradenames is completed as of the first day of the fourth fiscal quarter of each year.
103730_11_ITEM15_P108_S1	The interim impairment test performed as of September 27, 2008, the last day of the 2008 fiscal third quarter, was effectively the Company s annual impairment test for 2008.
103730_11_ITEM15_P108_S2	There was no impairment identified through the annual impairment tests completed in 2010 or 2009.
103730_11_ITEM15_P109_S0	Upon determining that an intangible asset classified as indefinite-lived is impaired, the Company reassesses the useful life of the impaired assets and begins to amortize the remaining carrying value over that useful life if it is determined that the asset no longer has an indefinite useful life.
103730_11_ITEM15_P110_S0	The carrying value of long-lived assets held-and-used, other than goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets, is evaluated when events or changes in circumstances indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable or the useful life has changed.
103730_11_ITEM15_P110_S1	The carrying value of a long-lived asset group is considered impaired when the total projected undiscounted cash flows from such asset group are separately identifiable and are less than the carrying value.
103730_11_ITEM15_P110_S2	In that event, a loss is recognized based on the amount by which the carrying value exceeds the fair market value of the long-lived asset group.
103730_11_ITEM15_P111_S0	Fair market value is determined primarily using present value techniques based on projected cash flows from the asset group.
103730_11_ITEM15_P111_S1	Losses on long-lived assets held-for-sale, other than goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets, are determined in a similar manner, except that fair market values are reduced for disposal costs.
103730_11_ITEM15_P112_S0	Other assets include investments in marketable securities which are classified as available-for-sale.

103730_11_ITEM15_P136_S0	Spin-off of Vishay Precision Group, Inc.
103730_11_ITEM15_P137_S0	On October 27, 2009, Vishay announced that it intended to spin off its measurements and foil resistors businesses into an independent, publicly-traded company to be named Vishay Precision Group, Inc.
103730_11_ITEM15_P138_S0	On June 15, 2010, the Board of Directors of Vishay approved the spin-off of VPG and on July 6, 2010, Vishay completed the spin-off through a tax-free stock dividend to Vishay s stockholders.
103730_11_ITEM15_P138_S1	Vishay s common stockholders received 1 share of VPG common stock for every 14 shares of Vishay common stock they held on the record date, June 25, 2010, and Vishay s Class B common stockholders received 1 share of VPG Class B common stock for every 14 shares of Vishay Class B common stock they held on the record date.
103730_11_ITEM15_P138_S2	Upon completion of the spin-off certain executive officers received bonuses aggregating approximately $2.1 million, which are reflected in the results of the year ended December 31, 2010.
103730_11_ITEM15_P139_S0	Until July 6, 2010, VPG was part of Vishay and its assets, liabilities, results of operations, and cash flows are included in the amounts reported in these consolidated financial statements for periods prior to the completion of the spin-off.
