103730_13_ITEM15_P364_S0	The fair value measurement accounting guidance establishes a valuation hierarchy of the inputs used to measure fair value.
103730_13_ITEM15_P364_S1	This hierarchy prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value into three broad levels.
103730_13_ITEM15_P364_S2	The following is a brief description of those three levels:
103730_13_ITEM15_P365_S0	Level 1: Observable inputs such as quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
103730_13_ITEM15_P366_S0	Level 2: Inputs other than quoted prices that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly or indirectly.
103730_13_ITEM15_P366_S1	These include quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities in active markets and quoted prices for identical or similar assets or liabilities in markets that are not active.
103730_13_ITEM15_P367_S0	Level 3: Unobservable inputs that reflect the Company's own assumptions.
103730_13_ITEM15_P368_S0	An asset or liability's classification within the hierarchy is determined based on the lowest level input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
103730_13_ITEM15_P369_S0	The following table provides the financial assets and liabilities carried at fair value measured on a recurring basis as of December 31, 2012 and 2011:
103730_13_ITEM15_P370_S0	The Company maintains non-qualified trusts, referred to as "rabbi" trusts, to fund payments under deferred compensation and non-qualified pension plans.
103730_13_ITEM15_P370_S1	Rabbi trust assets consist primarily of marketable securities, classified as available-for-sale, and company-owned life insurance assets.
103730_13_ITEM15_P370_S2	The marketable securities held in the rabbi trusts are valued using quoted market prices on the last business day of the year.
103730_13_ITEM15_P370_S3	The company-owned life insurance assets are valued in consultation with the Company's insurance brokers using the value of underlying assets of the insurance contracts.
103730_13_ITEM15_P370_S4	The fair value measurement of the marketable securities held in the rabbi trust is considered a Level 1 measurement and the measurement of the company-owned life insurance assets is considered a Level 2 measurement within the fair value hierarchy.
103730_13_ITEM15_P371_S0	The Company maintains defined benefit retirement plans in certain of its U.S. and non-U.S. subsidiaries.
103730_13_ITEM15_P371_S1	The assets of the plans are measured at fair value.
103730_13_ITEM15_P372_S0	Equity securities held by the U.S. defined benefit retirement plans consist of various mutual funds and exchange traded funds that are valued based on quoted market prices on the last business day of the year.
103730_13_ITEM15_P372_S1	The fair value measurement of the mutual funds and exchange traded funds securities is considered a Level 1 measurement within the fair value hierarchy.
103730_13_ITEM15_P373_S0	Fixed income securities held by the U.S. defined benefit retirement plans consist of exchange traded funds, investments in a group annuity contract, and a short-term investment fund.
103730_13_ITEM15_P373_S1	The exchange traded funds are valued based on quoted market prices on the last business day of the year.
103730_13_ITEM15_P373_S2	The fair value measurement of the exchange traded funds securities is considered a Level 1 measurement within the fair value hierarchy.
103730_13_ITEM15_P374_S0	The group annuity contract consists of a general asset account and a pooled separate account.
103730_13_ITEM15_P374_S1	Units of the general asset account are valued based on a discounted cash flow model using the current yields of similar instruments with comparable durations and similar credit risk.
103730_13_ITEM15_P374_S2	The pooled separate accounts are valued based on the value of the underlying bond funds, which are valued at quoted market prices on the last business day of the year, with adjustments made to reflect the nature of how the investment is held.
103730_13_ITEM15_P375_S0	The fair value measurement of the group annuity contract is considered a Level 2 measurement within the fair value hierarchy.
103730_13_ITEM15_P376_S0	The short-term investment fund strictly invests in short-term investments, including commercial paper, certificates of deposit, U.S. government agency and instrumentality obligations, U.S. government obligations, corporate notes, and funding agreements.
103730_13_ITEM15_P376_S1	The maturity date of all investments held by the short-term investment fund is within one year from the financial statement date.
103730_13_ITEM15_P376_S2	There are no redemption restrictions on the plan's investment.
103730_13_ITEM15_P377_S0	The fair value of the short-term investment fund has been estimated using the net asset value per share of the investment.
103730_13_ITEM15_P377_S1	The fair value measurement of the short-term investment fund is considered a Level 2 measurement within the fair value hierarchy.
103730_13_ITEM15_P378_S0	Real estate investments held by the U.S. defined benefit retirement plans consist of real estate investment trust securities that are valued at quoted market prices on the last business day of the year.
103730_13_ITEM15_P378_S1	The fair value measurement of the real estate investments is considered a Level 1 measurement within the fair value hierarchy.
103730_13_ITEM15_P379_S0	Equity securities held by the non-U.S. defined benefit retirement plans consist of equity securities that are valued based on quoted market prices on the last business day of the year.
103730_13_ITEM15_P379_S1	The fair value measurement of the equity securities is considered a Level 1 measurement within the fair value hierarchy.
103730_13_ITEM15_P380_S0	Fixed income securities held by the non-U.S. defined benefit retirement plans consist of government bonds in the Philippines and India and corporate notes that are valued based on quoted market prices on the last business day of the year.
103730_13_ITEM15_P380_S1	The fair value measurement of the fixed income securities is considered a Level 1 measurement within the fair value hierarchy.
103730_13_ITEM15_P381_S0	Cash held by the U.S. and non-U.S. defined benefit retirement plans consists of demand deposits on account in various financial institutions to fund current benefit payments.
103730_13_ITEM15_P381_S1	The carrying amount of the cash approximates its fair value.

103730_13_ITEM15_P382_S1	The investments are valued based on quoted market prices on the last business day of the year.
103730_13_ITEM15_P382_S2	The fair value measurement of the investments is considered a Level 1 measurement within the fair value hierarchy.
103730_13_ITEM15_P383_S0	The convertible senior debentures, due 2040, due 2041, and due 2042, issued by the Company on November 9, 2010, May 13, 2011, and May 31, 2012, respectively, contain embedded derivative features that GAAP requires to be bifurcated and remeasured each reporting period.
103730_13_ITEM15_P383_S1	Each quarter, the change in the fair value of the embedded derivative features, if any, is recorded in the consolidated statements of operations.
103730_13_ITEM15_P384_S0	The Company uses a derivative valuation model to derive the value of the embedded derivative features.
103730_13_ITEM15_P384_S1	Key inputs into this valuation model are the Company's current stock price, risk-free interest rates, the stock dividend yield, the stock volatility, and the debentures' credit spread over London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR).
103730_13_ITEM15_P384_S2	The first three aforementioned inputs are based on observable market data and are considered Level 2 inputs while the last two aforementioned inputs are unobservable and thus require management's judgment and are considered Level 3 inputs.
103730_13_ITEM15_P385_S0	The fair value measurement is considered a Level 3 measurement within the fair value hierarchy.
103730_13_ITEM15_P386_S0	The fair value of the long-term debt, excluding the derivative liability, at December 31, 2012 and 2011 is approximately $686,800 and $533,900, respectively, compared to its carrying value, excluding the derivative liability, of $391,628 and $398,068, respectively.
103730_13_ITEM15_P386_S1	The Company estimates the fair value of its long-term debt using a combination of quoted market prices for similar financing arrangements and expected future payments discounted at risk-adjusted rates, which are considered level 2 inputs.

103730_13_ITEM15_P387_S1	The short-term investments are accounted for as held-to-maturity debt instruments, at amortized cost, which approximates their fair value.
103730_13_ITEM15_P387_S2	The investments are funded with excess cash not expected to be needed for operations prior to maturity; therefore, the Company believes it has the intent and ability to hold the short-term investments until maturity.

(the "Company") on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2012 as filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on the date hereof (the "Report"), I, Lori Lipcaman, Chief Financial Officer of the Company, certify, pursuant to 18 U.S.C. section 1350, as adopted pursuant to section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, that:

103730_14_ITEM1_P0_S0	Vishay Intertechnology, Inc. ("Vishay," the "Company," "we," "us," or "our") is a leading global manufacturer and supplier of discrete semiconductors and passive components.
103730_14_ITEM1_P0_S1	Semiconductors include MOSFETs, diodes, and optoelectronic components.
103730_14_ITEM1_P0_S2	Passive components include resistive products, capacitors, and inductors.
103730_14_ITEM1_P0_S3	Discrete semiconductors and passive components are essential elements of virtually every type of electronic circuit.
103730_14_ITEM1_P0_S4	They support the microprocessor chips and other integrated circuits ("ICs") that coordinate and control the functions of electronic devices and equipment.
103730_14_ITEM1_P0_S5	We offer our customers "one-stop shop" access to one of the most comprehensive electronic component product lines of any manufacturer in the United States, Europe, and Asia.
103730_14_ITEM1_P1_S0	Our semiconductor components are used for a wide variety of functions, including power control, power conversion, power management, signal switching, signal routing, signal blocking, signal amplification, two-way data transfer, one-way remote control, and circuit isolation.
103730_14_ITEM1_P1_S1	Our passive components are used to restrict current flow, suppress voltage increases, store and discharge energy, control alternating current ("AC") and voltage, filter out unwanted electrical signals, and perform other functions.
103730_14_ITEM1_P1_S2	Our components are used in virtually every type of product that contains electronic circuitry, in the industrial, computing, automotive, consumer, telecommunications, power supplies, military, aerospace, and medical markets.
103730_14_ITEM1_P2_S0	In the 1950's, the late Dr. Felix Zandman, Vishay's founder, was issued patents for his PhotoStress coatings and instruments, used to reveal and measure the distribution of stresses in structures such as airplanes and cars under live load conditions.
103730_14_ITEM1_P2_S1	His research in this area led him to develop Bulk Metal foil resistors ultra-precise, ultra-stable resistors with performance far beyond any other resistor available to date.
103730_14_ITEM1_P3_S0	In 1962, Dr. Zandman, with a loan from the late Alfred P. Slaner, founded Vishay to develop and manufacture Bulk Metal foil resistors.
103730_14_ITEM1_P3_S1	Concurrently, J.E. Starr developed foil resistance strain gages, which also became part of Vishay.
103730_14_ITEM1_P3_S2	Throughout the 1960's and 1970's, Vishay established itself as a technical and market leader in foil resistors, PhotoStress products, and strain gages.
103730_14_ITEM1_P3_S3	These products were included with the measurements and foil resistor businesses that we spun off into an independent, publicly-traded company named Vishay Precision Group, Inc. ("Vishay Precision Group" or "VPG") through a tax-free stock dividend to our stockholders on July 6, 2010.
103730_14_ITEM1_P4_S0	In 1985, Vishay began to expand its product line through various strategic acquisitions, including the resistor companies Dale Electronics, Draloric Electronic, and Sfernice.
103730_14_ITEM1_P4_S1	In the early 1990's, Vishay applied its acquisition strategy to the capacitor market, with the major acquisitions of Sprague Electric, Roederstein, and Vitramon.
103730_14_ITEM1_P4_S2	In 2002, Vishay acquired BCcomponents, the former passive components business of Philips Electronics and Beyschlag, which greatly enhanced Vishay's global market position in passive components.
103730_14_ITEM1_P4_S3	Over the years, we have made several smaller passive components acquisitions to gain market share, penetrate different geographic markets, enhance new product development, round out our product lines, or grow our high margin niche businesses.
103730_14_ITEM1_P4_S4	These include Electro-Films, Cera-Mite, and Spectrol in 2000; Tansitor and North American Capacitor Company (Mallory) in 2001; the thin film interconnect business of Aeroflex in 2004; Phoenix do Brasil in 2006; the wet tantalum capacitor business of KEMET Corporation in 2008; the resistor businesses of Huntington Electric in 2011; HiRel Systems in 2012; and MCB Industrie in 2013.
103730_14_ITEM1_P5_S0	In the late 1990's, Vishay began expanding its product lines to include discrete semiconductors.
103730_14_ITEM1_P6_S0	In 1998, Vishay acquired the Semiconductor Business Group of TEMIC, which included Telefunken and an 80.4% interest in Siliconix, producers of MOSFETs, RF transistors, diodes, optoelectronics, and power and analog switching integrated circuits.
103730_14_ITEM1_P7_S0	Vishay's next semiconductor acquisition came in 2001, with the purchase of the infrared components business of Infineon Technologies, which was followed the same year by Vishay's acquisition of General Semiconductor, a leading global manufacturer of rectifiers and diodes.
103730_14_ITEM1_P7_S1	In 2005, Vishay made a successful tender offer for the minority interest in Siliconix.
103730_14_ITEM1_P7_S2	In 2007, Vishay acquired the Power Control Systems business of International Rectifier, further enhancing our product offerings.
103730_14_ITEM1_P7_S3	These acquisitions propelled Vishay into the top ranks of discrete semiconductor manufacturers.
103730_14_ITEM1_P8_S0	We continue to implement the vision, strategy, and culture articulated by Dr. Zandman as we continue to work tirelessly to enhance value for our stockholders.
103730_14_ITEM1_P9_S0	Vishay was incorporated in Delaware in 1962 and maintains its principal executive offices at 63 Lancaster Avenue, Malvern, Pennsylvania 19355-2143.
103730_14_ITEM1_P9_S1	Our telephone number is (610) 644-1300.
103730_14_ITEM1_P10_S0	We were founded based on the inventions of Dr. Felix Zandman and we continue to emphasize technological innovation as a driver of growth.
103730_14_ITEM1_P10_S1	Many of our products and manufacturing techniques, technologies, and packaging methods have been invented, designed, and developed by Dr. Zandman, our engineers, and our scientists.
103730_14_ITEM1_P10_S2	We are currently a worldwide technology and market leader in wirewound and other power resistors, leaded film resistors, thin film SMD resistors, wet and conformal-coated tantalum capacitors, capacitors for power electronics, power rectifiers, low-voltage power MOSFETs, and infrared components.
103730_14_ITEM1_P11_S0	We maintain strategically placed application and product support centers where proximity to customers and our manufacturing locations enables us to more easily gauge and satisfy the needs of local markets.
103730_14_ITEM1_P11_S1	The breadth of our product portfolio along with the proximity of our field application engineers to customers provides increased opportunities to have our components selected and designed into new end products by customers in all relevant market segments.
103730_14_ITEM1_P11_S2	We also maintain research and development personnel and promote programs at a number of our production facilities to develop new products and new applications of existing products, and to improve manufacturing processes and technologies.
103730_14_ITEM1_P11_S3	We plan to grow our business and increase earnings per share, in part, through accelerating the development of new products and technologies and increasing design-in opportunities by expanding our technical resources for providing solutions to customers.
103730_14_ITEM1_P12_S0	We are a leading manufacturer in our industry, with a broad product portfolio, access to a wide range of end markets and sales channels, and geographic diversity.
103730_14_ITEM1_P12_S1	We have solid, well-established relationships with our customers and strong distribution channels.
103730_14_ITEM1_P12_S2	Our senior management team is highly experienced, with deep industry knowledge.
103730_14_ITEM1_P12_S3	Over the past two decades, our management team has successfully restructured our company and integrated several acquisitions.
103730_14_ITEM1_P12_S4	We can adapt our operations to changing economic conditions, as demonstrated by our ability to remain profitable and generate cash through the volatile economic cycle of the recent past.
103730_14_ITEM1_P13_S0	We have one of the broadest product lines of discrete semiconductors and passive components among our competitors.
103730_14_ITEM1_P13_S1	Our broad product portfolio allows us to penetrate markets in all industry segments and all regions, which reduces our exposure to a particular end market or geographic location.

103730_14_ITEM1_P15_S0	Since 1985, we have expanded our product line through various strategic acquisitions, growing from a small manufacturer of precision resistors and resistance strain gages to one of the world's largest manufacturers and suppliers of a broad line of electronic components.
103730_14_ITEM1_P15_S1	We have successfully integrated the acquired companies within our existing management and operational structure, reducing selling, general, and administrative expenses through the integration or elimination of redundant sales and administrative functions, creating manufacturing synergies, while improving customer service.

103730_14_ITEM1_P15_S4	These acquisitions accounted for 3.4% of 2013 revenues and have margins above our corporate average.

103730_14_ITEM1_P16_S1	We expect the benefits of our restructuring and other cost cutting measures in prior periods and continued cost control activities (see "Cost Management" included in Item 7, "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations") to contribute to our "free cash" generation going forward.

103730_14_ITEM1_P30_S0	We design, manufacture, and market electronic components that cover a wide range of functions and technologies.
103730_14_ITEM1_P31_S0	We promote our ability to provide "one-stop shop" service to customers, whereby they can streamline their design and purchasing processes by ordering multiple types of products from Vishay.
103730_14_ITEM1_P31_S1	Our technical sales force consisting of field application engineers offers customers the complete breadth of the Vishay portfolio for their applications.
103730_14_ITEM1_P31_S2	We aim to use this broad portfolio to increase opportunities to have our components selected and "designed in" to new end products.
103730_14_ITEM1_P32_S0	Our products can be divided into two general classes: semiconductors and passive components.
103730_14_ITEM1_P32_S1	Semiconductors are sometimes referred to as "active components" because they require power to function whereas passive components do not require power to function.
103730_14_ITEM1_P32_S2	Our semiconductor and passive components products are further categorized based on their functionality for financial reporting purposes.
103730_14_ITEM1_P32_S3	See Note 15 to our consolidated financial statements for additional information on revenues, income, and total assets by segment.
103730_14_ITEM1_P33_S0	Our semiconductor products include MOSFETs, Diodes, and Optoelectronic Components.
103730_14_ITEM1_P34_S0	Semiconductors are typically used to perform functions such as switching, amplifying, rectifying, routing, or transmitting electrical signals, power conversion, and power management.
103730_14_ITEM1_P35_S0	Our MOSFETs business includes both the commodity and non-commodity markets in which we believe that we enjoy a good reputation and strong brand recognition (Siliconix).
103730_14_ITEM1_P36_S0	MOSFETs function as solid-state switches to control power in multiple applications, including mobile phones, notebook and desktop computers, tablet computers, digital cameras, televisions, DC/DC and AC/DC switch mode power supplies, solar inverters, automotive and industrial systems.
103730_14_ITEM1_P36_S1	We are a leader in low-voltage TrenchFET MOSFETs and also offer high-voltage MOSFETs.
103730_14_ITEM1_P36_S2	Our MOSFETs product line includes low- and medium-voltage TrenchFET MOSFETs, high-voltage planar MOSFETs, high voltage Super Junction MOSFETs, power integrated circuits (power ICs), and integrated function power devices.
103730_14_ITEM1_P36_S3	We are one of the technology leaders in MOSFETs, with a tradition of innovation in wafer design, packaging, and performance.
103730_14_ITEM1_P37_S0	Our Diodes business is a solid business with a strong market presence in both the commodity and non-commodity markets.
103730_14_ITEM1_P37_S1	The products that comprise our Diodes business represent our broadest product line and include rectifiers, small signal diodes, protection diodes, thyristors/SCRs and power modules.
103730_14_ITEM1_P38_S0	The primary application of rectifiers, found inside the power supplies of virtually all electronic equipment, is to derive DC power from the AC supply.
103730_14_ITEM1_P38_S1	Vishay is the worldwide leader in rectifiers, having a broad technology base and a good position in automotive, industrial, computing and consumer markets.
103730_14_ITEM1_P38_S2	Our rectifier innovations include TMBS using Trench MOS barrier Schottky rectifier technology, which reduces power loss and improves the efficiency of end systems and eSMP , the best in class high-current density surface mount packages.
103730_14_ITEM1_P39_S0	Our wide selection of small signal diodes consist of the following functions: switching, tuning, band-switching, RF attenuation and voltage regulation (Zener).
103730_14_ITEM1_P39_S1	They are available in various glass and plastic packaging options and generally are used in electronic circuits, where small currents and high frequencies are involved.
103730_14_ITEM1_P40_S0	Vishay is also one of the market leaders for TVS (transient voltage suppressor) diodes.
103730_14_ITEM1_P40_S1	The portfolio of protection diodes includes ESD protection and EMI filter.
103730_14_ITEM1_P41_S0	Our thyristors or SCR (silicon-controlled rectifiers) are very popular in the industrial high-voltage AC power control applications.
103730_14_ITEM1_P41_S1	The fast growing markets of solar inverter and HEV/EV are the focus of our power modules business (IGBT or MOSFET modules).
103730_14_ITEM1_P41_S2	These modules can be customized to fit in different customer design requirements.
103730_14_ITEM1_P42_S0	Our Optoelectronic Components business has a strong market presence in both the commodity and non-commodity markets.
103730_14_ITEM1_P43_S0	Optoelectronic components emit light, detect light, or do both.
103730_14_ITEM1_P43_S1	Our broad range of standard and customer specific optoelectronic components includes infrared ("IR") emitters and detectors, IR remote control receivers, optocouplers, solid-state relays, optical sensors, light-emitting diodes ("LEDs"), 7-segment displays, and IR data transceiver modules (IrDA ).
103730_14_ITEM1_P43_S2	Our IR remote control receivers are designed for use in infrared remote control, data transmission, and light barrier applications in end products including televisions, set-top boxes, notebook computers, and audio systems.
103730_14_ITEM1_P43_S3	We are the leading manufacturer of IR remote control receivers.
103730_14_ITEM1_P43_S4	Our optocouplers electrically isolate input and output signals.
103730_14_ITEM1_P43_S5	Uses include switch-mode power supplies, consumer electronics, telecommunications equipment, solar inverters, and industrial systems.
103730_14_ITEM1_P44_S0	Our IR data transceiver modules are used for short range, two-way, high-speed, and secure wireless data transfer between electronic devices such as home medical appliances, mobile phones, industrial data loggers, and metering.
103730_14_ITEM1_P44_S1	Our LEDs are designed for backlighting and illumination in automotive and other applications.
103730_14_ITEM1_P44_S2	Our LEDs include ultra-bright as well as small surface-mount packages, with products available in all standard colors including white.
103730_14_ITEM1_P45_S0	Our passive components include resistors, capacitors, and magnetics such as inductors and transformers.
103730_14_ITEM1_P45_S1	Passive components are used to store electrical charges, to limit or resist electrical current, and to help in filtering, surge suppression, measurement, timing, and tuning applications.
103730_14_ITEM1_P46_S0	Our Resistors and Inductors business is our original business.
103730_14_ITEM1_P46_S1	We maintain the broadest portfolio of resistor products worldwide.
103730_14_ITEM1_P46_S2	The business is solid, predictable, and growing at relatively stable selling prices.
103730_14_ITEM1_P46_S3	We are a market leader with a strong technology base, many specialty products, and strong brand recognition (such as our Dale, Draloric, Beyschlag, Sfernice, and HiRel Systems brands).
103730_14_ITEM1_P46_S4	We focus on higher value markets in specialized industries, while maintaining a complete portfolio of commodity products.
103730_14_ITEM1_P46_S5	We do not aim to be the volume leader in commodity markets.
103730_14_ITEM1_P47_S0	Resistors are basic components used in all forms of electronic circuitry to adjust and regulate levels of voltage and current.
103730_14_ITEM1_P47_S1	They vary widely in precision and cost, and are manufactured from numerous materials and in many forms.
103730_14_ITEM1_P48_S0	Linear resistive components are classified as variable or fixed, depending on whether or not their resistance is adjustable.
103730_14_ITEM1_P49_S0	Non-linear resistors function by varying in resistance under influence of temperature (thermistors) or voltage (varistors).
103730_14_ITEM1_P49_S1	They can be used in temperature-measuring applications or as current or voltage-limiting devices.
103730_14_ITEM1_P50_S0	We manufacture virtually all types of fixed resistors, both in discrete and network forms, as well as many variable types.
103730_14_ITEM1_P51_S0	Vishay resistor innovations include Power Metal Strip technology.
103730_14_ITEM1_P51_S1	These resistors feature very low resistance and are used to measure changes in current flow (current sensing) or divert current flow (shunting).
103730_14_ITEM1_P52_S0	Inductors use an internal magnetic field to change AC current phase and resist AC current.
103730_14_ITEM1_P52_S1	Inductor applications include controlling AC current and voltage, filtering out unwanted electrical signals, and energy storage.
103730_14_ITEM1_P52_S2	Vishay inductor innovations include IHLP low-profile, high-current inductor technology with industry-leading specifications, which is patented and generates royalty revenue.
103730_14_ITEM1_P52_S3	Our low-profile, high-current inductors save circuit board space and power in voltage regulator module ("VRM") and DC to DC converter applications.
103730_14_ITEM1_P52_S4	In addition, we are a worldwide leader in custom magnetic solutions focusing on high performance and high reliability.
103730_14_ITEM1_P52_S5	This field has been substantially strengthened, with the 2012 acquisition of HiRel Systems, broadening our portfolio, customer, and market segment reach.
103730_14_ITEM1_P53_S0	Our Capacitors business consists of a broad range of reliable, high-quality products.
103730_14_ITEM1_P53_S1	We have a strong presence worldwide in specialty markets based on our product performance and reliability and strong brand recognition (including our Sprague, Vitramon, Roederstein, BCcomponents, and ESTA brands).
103730_14_ITEM1_P53_S2	We focus on higher value markets in specialized industries, while maintaining a complete portfolio of commodity products.
103730_14_ITEM1_P53_S3	We do not aim to be the volume leader in commodity markets.
103730_14_ITEM1_P54_S0	Capacitors are used in almost all electronic circuits.
103730_14_ITEM1_P54_S1	They store energy and discharge it when needed.
103730_14_ITEM1_P55_S0	Important applications for capacitors include electronic filtering for linear and switching power supplies; decoupling and bypass of electronic signals for integrated circuits and circuit boards; and frequency control, timing and conditioning of electronic signals for a broad range of applications.
103730_14_ITEM1_P56_S0	We manufacture products based on all major capacitor technologies: tantalum (molded chip tantalum, coated chip tantalum, solid through-hole tantalum, and wet tantalum), ceramic (multilayer chip and ceramic disc), film, power, heavy-current, and aluminum electrolytic.
103730_14_ITEM1_P56_S1	Our capacitors range from tiny surface-mount devices for hearing aids and mobile devices to large power correction capacitors used in renewable energy, heavy industry, and electrical power grids.
103730_14_ITEM1_P56_S2	We are a recognized technology leader in many product ranges, securing our strong position in military and medical markets, and in a wide range of industrial and automotive applications.
103730_14_ITEM1_P56_S3	Our wet tantalum and MicroTan technologies are market leaders.
103730_14_ITEM1_P57_S0	We have qualified certain of our products under various military specifications approved and monitored by United States government agencies, and under certain European military specifications.
103730_14_ITEM1_P57_S1	Qualification levels are based in part upon the rate of failure of products.
103730_14_ITEM1_P57_S2	In order to maintain the classification level of a product, we must continuously perform tests on the product and the results of these tests must be reported to the government agencies.
103730_14_ITEM1_P57_S3	If the product fails to meet the requirements for the applicable classification level, the product's classification may be reduced to a lower level.
103730_14_ITEM1_P58_S0	During the time that the classification level is reduced for a product with military application, net revenues and earnings attributable to that product may be adversely affected.
103730_14_ITEM1_P59_S0	In order to better serve our customers, we maintain production facilities in locations where we market the bulk of our products, such as the United States, Germany, and Asia.
103730_14_ITEM1_P59_S1	To optimize production efficiencies, we have whenever practicable established manufacturing facilities in countries, such as the Czech Republic, Hungary, India, Israel, Malaysia, Mexico, the People's Republic of China, and the Philippines, where we can benefit from lower labor and tax costs and also benefit from various government incentives, including grants and tax relief.
103730_14_ITEM1_P60_S0	One of our most sophisticated manufacturing operations is the production of power semiconductor components.
103730_14_ITEM1_P60_S1	This manufacturing process involves two phases of production: wafer fabrication and assembly (or packaging).
103730_14_ITEM1_P61_S0	Wafer fabrication subjects silicon wafers to various thermal, metallurgical, and chemical process steps that change their electrical and physical properties.
103730_14_ITEM1_P61_S1	These process steps define cells or circuits within numerous individual devices (termed "dies" or "chips") on each wafer.
103730_14_ITEM1_P61_S2	Assembly is the sequence of production steps that divides the wafer into individual chips and encloses the chips in structures (termed "packages") that make them usable in a circuit.
103730_14_ITEM1_P61_S3	Both wafer fabrication and assembly phases incorporate wafer level and device level electrical testing to ensure that device design integrity has been achieved.
103730_14_ITEM1_P62_S0	In the United States, our manufacturing facilities are located in California, Minnesota, Nebraska, New Hampshire, New York, Rhode Island, South Dakota, Vermont, and Wisconsin.
103730_14_ITEM1_P62_S1	In Asia, our main manufacturing facilities are located in the People's Republic of China, the Republic of China (Taiwan), India, and Malaysia.
103730_14_ITEM1_P62_S2	In Europe, our main manufacturing facilities are located in Germany, France, and the Czech Republic.
103730_14_ITEM1_P62_S3	We have substantial manufacturing facilities in Israel (see "Israeli Operations" below).
103730_14_ITEM1_P62_S4	We also have manufacturing facilities in Austria, Dominican Republic, Hungary, Italy, Mexico, the Netherlands, Portugal, and the Philippines.
103730_14_ITEM1_P62_S5	Over the past several years, we have invested substantial resources to increase the efficiency of our plants, which we believe will further reduce production costs.
103730_14_ITEM1_P63_S0	The majority of our manufacturing operations have received ISO 9001 certification and others are actively pursuing such approval.
103730_14_ITEM1_P64_S0	ISO 9001 is a comprehensive set of quality program standards developed by the International Standards Organization.
103730_14_ITEM1_P65_S0	See Note 15 to our consolidated financial statements for financial information by geographic area.
103730_14_ITEM1_P66_S0	Although most materials incorporated in our products are available from a number of sources, certain materials, including plastics and metals, are available only from a relatively limited number of suppliers or are subject to significant price volatility.
103730_14_ITEM1_P67_S0	Silicon wafers are the most important raw material for the manufacturing of our semiconductor products.
103730_14_ITEM1_P68_S0	Silicon wafers are manufactured from high-purity silicon, a metalloid.
103730_14_ITEM1_P68_S1	There have at times been industry-wide shortages of high-purity silicon resulting primarily from growing demand of the electronic component and solar power industries, and limited growth in high-purity silicon manufacturing capacities.
103730_14_ITEM1_P68_S2	Shifts in demand for high-purity silicon and in turn, silicon wafers, have resulted in significant fluctuation in prices of silicon wafers.
103730_14_ITEM1_P69_S0	We are a major consumer of the world's annual production of tantalum, a metal used in the manufacturing of tantalum capacitors.
103730_14_ITEM1_P69_S1	There are few suppliers that process tantalum ore into capacitor grade tantalum powder.
103730_14_ITEM1_P69_S2	We acquire tantalum powder and wire from all of them under short-term commitments.
103730_14_ITEM1_P70_S0	Certain materials, in addition to tantalum and including tin, tungsten, and gold are available only from a relatively limited number of suppliers, the source for which may be in the Democratic Republic of the Congo or an adjoining country.
103730_14_ITEM1_P70_S1	We are conducting due diligence on the source and custody of such materials.
103730_14_ITEM1_P71_S0	Palladium, a metal used to produce multi-layer ceramic capacitors, is currently found primarily in South Africa and Russia.
103730_14_ITEM1_P71_S1	Palladium is a commodity metal that is subject to price volatility.
103730_14_ITEM1_P71_S2	We periodically enter into short-term commitments to purchase palladium.
103730_14_ITEM1_P72_S0	Certain metals used in the manufacture of our products, such as copper, are traded on active markets, and can be subject to significant price volatility.
103730_14_ITEM1_P72_S1	Our policy is to enter into short-term commitments to purchase defined portions of annual consumption of these metals if market prices decline below budget.
103730_14_ITEM1_P73_S0	We have substantial manufacturing operations in Israel, where we benefit from the government's grant and tax incentive programs.
103730_14_ITEM1_P73_S1	These programs have contributed substantially, predominantly in previous years, to our growth and profitability.
103730_14_ITEM1_P74_S0	The current benefits derived under these programs are not material to our consolidated results.
103730_14_ITEM1_P74_S1	Because of our significant presence in Israel, the availability of these incentive programs could have a significant positive effect on us if we relocate manufacturing capacity or develop new product lines there.
103730_14_ITEM1_P74_S2	However, there are no substantial plans that would allow us to earn additional benefits.
103730_14_ITEM1_P75_S0	We could be materially adversely affected if events were to occur in the Middle East that interfered with our operations in Israel.
103730_14_ITEM1_P75_S1	However, we have not experienced any material interruption in our Israeli operations during our 43 years of operations there, in spite of several Middle East crises, including wars.
103730_14_ITEM1_P76_S0	We manufacture both standardized products and those designed and produced to meet customer specifications.
103730_14_ITEM1_P76_S1	We maintain an inventory of standardized components and monitor the backlog of outstanding orders for our products.
103730_14_ITEM1_P77_S0	We include in our backlog only open orders that we expect to ship in the next twelve months.
103730_14_ITEM1_P78_S0	Many of our customers encounter uncertain and changing demand for their products.
103730_14_ITEM1_P78_S1	They typically order products from us based on their forecasts.
103730_14_ITEM1_P78_S2	If demand falls below customers' forecasts, or if customers do not control their inventory effectively, they may cancel or reschedule the shipments included in our backlog, in many instances without the payment of any penalty.
103730_14_ITEM1_P78_S3	Therefore, our backlog at any point in time is not necessarily indicative of the results to be expected for future periods.
103730_14_ITEM1_P79_S0	We sell our products to original equipment manufacturers ("OEMs"), electronic manufacturing services ("EMS") companies, which manufacture for OEMs on an outsourcing basis, and independent distributors that maintain large inventories of electronic components for resale to OEMs and EMS companies.
103730_14_ITEM1_P79_S1	The distribution of sales by customer type for 2013 is shown below:
103730_14_ITEM1_P80_S0	Our sales organizations are regionally based.
103730_14_ITEM1_P80_S1	While our sales and support procedures are typically similar across all regions, we remain flexible in our ability to offer programs tailored to our customers' specific support requirements in each local area.
103730_14_ITEM1_P80_S2	The aim of our sales organizations is supporting our customers across all product lines, developing new design wins, negotiating pricing and contracts, and providing general commercial support as would normally be expected of a large multi-national sales force.
103730_14_ITEM1_P81_S0	We have an established Strategic Global Account program, which provides each of our top customers with a dedicated Strategic Global Account Manager.
103730_14_ITEM1_P81_S1	Our Strategic Global Account Managers are typically highly experienced salesmen or saleswomen who are capable of providing key customers with the coordination and management visibility required in a complex multi-product business relationship.
103730_14_ITEM1_P81_S2	They typically coordinate the sales, pricing, contract, logistic, quality, and other aspects of the customer's business requirements.
103730_14_ITEM1_P82_S0	The Strategic Global Account Manager normally is the focal point of communication between Vishay and our main customers.
103730_14_ITEM1_P82_S1	We maintain a similar program for our strategic distributors as well.
103730_14_ITEM1_P83_S0	We work with our customers so that our products are incorporated into the design of electronic equipment at the earliest stages of development and to provide technical and applications support.
103730_14_ITEM1_P83_S1	In addition to our staff of direct field sales personnel, independent manufacturers' representatives, and distributors, our Business Development group maintains teams of dedicated Field Application Engineers ("FAEs") to assist our customers in solving technical problems and in developing products to meet specific customer application needs using our entire product portfolio to provide support for our customers' engineering needs.
103730_14_ITEM1_P83_S2	Organized by market segment, our Business Development FAEs bring specific knowledge of component applications in their areas of expertise in the automotive, telecommunications, computer, consumer/entertainment, industrial, peripherals, digital consumer, and other market segments.
103730_14_ITEM1_P83_S3	With the ultimate goal of a Vishay "design-in" the process by which our customers specify a Vishay component in their products this program offers our customers enhanced access to all Vishay technologies while at the same time increasing design wins, and ultimately sales, for us.
103730_14_ITEM1_P83_S4	Most importantly, the process is closely monitored via a proprietary database developed by our Business Development group.
103730_14_ITEM1_P83_S5	Our database captures specific design activities and allows for real-time measurement of new business potential for our management team.
103730_14_ITEM1_P84_S0	Our top 30 customers have been relatively stable despite not having long-term commitments to purchase our products.
103730_14_ITEM1_P84_S1	With selected customers, we have signed longer term (greater than one year) contracts for specific products.
103730_14_ITEM1_P84_S2	Net revenues from our top 30 customers represent approximately 70% of our total net revenues.
103730_14_ITEM1_P84_S3	No single customer comprises more than 10% of our total net revenues.
103730_14_ITEM1_P85_S0	In certain areas we also work with sales representatives.
103730_14_ITEM1_P85_S1	The commission expense for these sales representatives is not material.

103730_14_ITEM1_P86_S1	Our primary competitors by product type include:
103730_14_ITEM1_P87_S0	MOSFETs: Fairchild Semiconductor, Infineon, International Rectifier, NXP Semiconductors, ON Semiconductor, Rohm, STMicroelectronics, Toshiba.
103730_14_ITEM1_P88_S0	Diodes: Diodes Inc., Infineon, NXP Semiconductors, ON Semiconductor, STMicroelectronics.
103730_14_ITEM1_P89_S0	Optoelectronic Components: Avago, OSRAM Opto Semiconductors, Rohm, Sharp, Toshiba.

103730_14_ITEM1_P91_S0	Capacitors: AVX, KEMET, Murata, Nichicon, Panasonic, TDK-EPCOS, Yageo.
103730_14_ITEM1_P92_S0	There are many other companies that produce products in the markets in which we compete.
103730_14_ITEM1_P93_S0	Our competitive position depends on our ability to maintain a competitive advantage on the basis of product quality, know-how, proprietary data, market knowledge, service capability, technological innovation, business reputation, and price competitiveness.
103730_14_ITEM1_P93_S1	Our sales and marketing programs aim to compete by offering our customers a broad range of world-class technologies and products, superior global sales and distribution support, and a secure and multi-location source of product supply.
103730_14_ITEM1_P94_S0	Many of our products and manufacturing techniques, technologies, and packaging methods have been invented, designed, and developed by Dr. Felix Zandman, our engineers, and our scientists.
103730_14_ITEM1_P94_S1	We maintain strategically placed design centers where proximity to customers enables us to more easily gauge and satisfy the needs of local markets.
103730_14_ITEM1_P94_S2	These design centers are located predominantly in the United States, Germany, Italy, Israel, the People's Republic of China, France, and the Republic of China (Taiwan).
103730_14_ITEM1_P95_S0	We also maintain research and development personnel and promote programs at a number of our production facilities to develop new products and new applications of existing products and to improve manufacturing processes and technologies.
103730_14_ITEM1_P95_S1	This decentralized system encourages product development at individual manufacturing facilities, closer to our customers.
103730_14_ITEM1_P96_S0	We have made a significant investment in securing intellectual property protection for our technology and products.
103730_14_ITEM1_P96_S1	We seek to protect our technology by, among other things, filing patent applications for technology considered important to the development of our business.
103730_14_ITEM1_P96_S2	We also rely upon trade secrets, unpatented know-how, continuing technological innovation, and the aggressive pursuit of licensing opportunities to help develop and maintain our competitive position.
103730_14_ITEM1_P97_S0	Our ability to compete effectively with other companies depends, in part, on our ability to maintain the proprietary nature of our technology.
103730_14_ITEM1_P97_S1	Although we have been awarded, have filed applications for, or have been licensed under, numerous patents in the United States and other countries, there can be no assurance concerning the degree of protection afforded by these patents or the likelihood that pending patents will be issued.
103730_14_ITEM1_P98_S0	We require all of our technical, research and development, sales and marketing, and management employees and most consultants and other advisors to execute confidentiality agreements upon the commencement of employment or consulting relationships with us.
103730_14_ITEM1_P98_S1	These agreements provide that all confidential information developed or made known to the entity or individual during the course of the entity's or individual's relationship with us is to be kept confidential and not disclosed to third parties except in specific circumstances.
103730_14_ITEM1_P99_S0	Substantially all of our technical, research and development, sales and marketing, and management employees have entered into agreements providing for the assignment to us of rights to inventions made by them while employed by us.
103730_14_ITEM1_P100_S0	When we believe other companies are misappropriating our intellectual property rights, we vigorously enforce those rights through legal action, and we intend to continue to do so.
103730_14_ITEM1_P101_S0	Although we have numerous United States and foreign patents covering certain of our products and manufacturing processes, no particular patent is considered individually material to our business.
103730_14_ITEM1_P102_S0	We have adopted an Environmental Health and Safety Corporate Policy that commits us to achieve and maintain compliance with applicable environmental laws, to promote proper management of hazardous materials for the safety of our employees and the protection of the environment, and to minimize the hazardous materials generated in the course of our operations.
103730_14_ITEM1_P102_S1	This policy is implemented with accountability directly to the Board of Directors.
103730_14_ITEM1_P102_S2	In addition, our manufacturing operations are subject to various federal, state, and local laws restricting discharge of materials into the environment.
103730_14_ITEM1_P103_S0	We are involved in environmental remediation programs at various sites currently or formerly owned by us and our subsidiaries both within and outside of the U.S., in addition to involvement as a potentially responsible party ("PRP") at Superfund sites.
103730_14_ITEM1_P104_S0	Certain obligations as a PRP have arisen in connection with business acquisitions.
103730_14_ITEM1_P105_S0	The remediation programs are on-going and the ultimate cost of site cleanup is difficult to predict given the uncertainties regarding the extent of the required cleanup, the interpretation of applicable laws and regulations and alternative cleanup methods.
103730_14_ITEM1_P106_S0	We are not involved in any pending or threatened proceedings that would require curtailment of our operations.
103730_14_ITEM1_P106_S1	We continually expend funds to ensure that our facilities comply with applicable environmental regulations.
103730_14_ITEM1_P106_S2	While we believe that we are in material compliance with applicable environmental laws, we cannot accurately predict future developments and do not necessarily have knowledge of all past occurrences on sites that we currently occupy.
103730_14_ITEM1_P106_S3	More stringent environmental regulations may be enacted in the future, and we cannot determine the modifications, if any, in our operations that any such future regulations might require, or the cost of compliance with such regulations.
103730_14_ITEM1_P106_S4	Moreover, the risk of environmental liability and remediation costs is inherent in the nature of our business and, therefore, there can be no assurance that material environmental costs, including remediation costs, will not arise in the future.
103730_14_ITEM1_P107_S0	With each acquisition, we attempt to identify potential environmental concerns and to minimize, or obtain indemnification for, the environmental matters we may be required to address.
103730_14_ITEM1_P107_S1	In addition, we establish reserves for specifically identified potential environmental liabilities.
103730_14_ITEM1_P107_S2	We believe that the reserves we have established are adequate.
103730_14_ITEM1_P107_S3	Nevertheless, we have in the past and may in the future inherit certain pre-existing environmental liabilities, generally based on successor liability doctrines.
103730_14_ITEM1_P107_S4	Although we have never been involved in any environmental matter that has had a material adverse impact on our overall operations, there can be no assurance that in connection with any past or future acquisition we will not be obligated to address environmental matters that could have a material adverse impact on our operations.

103730_14_ITEM1_P109_S0	Our relationship with our employees is generally good.

103730_14_ITEM1A_P0_S0	From time to time, information provided by us, including but not limited to statements in this report, or other statements made by or on our behalf, may contain "forward-looking" information within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Such statements involve a number of risks, uncertainties, and contingencies, many of which are beyond our control, which may cause actual results, performance, or achievements to differ materially from those anticipated.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P0_S2	Set forth below are important factors that could cause our results, performance, or achievements to differ materially from those in any forward-looking statements made by us or on our behalf.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P0_S3	You should understand that it is not possible to predict or identify all such factors.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P0_S4	Consequently, you should not consider the following to be a complete discussion of all potential risks or uncertainties.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Our business is cyclical and the periods of decline we recently experienced may resume and may become more pronounced.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P2_S0	The electronic component industry is highly cyclical and experiences periods of decline from time to time.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P2_S1	We and others in the electronic component industry have experienced these conditions in the recent past and cannot predict when we may experience such downturns in the future.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P2_S2	While we believe that a recovery from the recent global downturn is underway, there is no assurance that the recovery will continue at its current pace or at all, or that the conditions that contributed to the recent recessionary environment have in fact abated.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P2_S3	A decline in product demand on a global basis could result in order cancellations and deferrals, lower average selling prices, and a material and adverse impact on our results of operations.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P2_S4	These declines in demand are driven by market conditions in the end markets for our products.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P2_S5	Changes in the demand mix, needed technologies, and these end markets may adversely affect our ability to match our products, inventory, and capacity to meet customer demand and could adversely affect our operating results and financial condition.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P2_S6	A slowdown in demand or recessionary trends in the global economy makes it more difficult for us to predict our future sales and manage our operations, and could adversely impact our results of operations.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P3_S0	We have incurred and will continue to incur restructuring costs and associated asset write-downs.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P4_S0	To remain competitive, particularly when business conditions are difficult, we sometimes attempt to reduce our cost structure by restructuring our existing businesses, where we seek to achieve synergies, eliminate redundant facilities and staff positions, and move operations, where possible, to jurisdictions with lower labor costs.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P4_S1	On October 28, 2013, we announced various cost reduction programs as part of our continuous efforts to improve efficiency and operating performance.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P4_S2	The programs primarily focus on a plan to enhance the competitiveness of our MOSFETs segment and a voluntary separation / early retirement offer to certain employees Company-wide.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P4_S3	We also plan to implement two other smaller cost reduction programs concerning the manufacturing of products within our Diodes segment.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P4_S4	The expenses associated with the programs have been and will continue to be recorded as they become recognizable under generally accepted accounting principles ("GAAP").
103730_14_ITEM1A_P4_S5	Complete implementation of all of the programs is expected to occur before the end of the first fiscal quarter of 2016.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Additionally, our long-term strategy includes growing through the integration of acquired businesses, and GAAP requires plant closure and employee termination costs that we incur in connection with our acquisition activities to be recorded as expenses in our consolidated statement of operations, as such expenses are incurred.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P5_S1	For this reason, we expect to have some level of future restructuring expenses due to acquisitions.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Our business is cyclical, and in periods of a rising economy we may experience intense demand for our products.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P6_S1	If our restructuring activities result in us not being able to satisfy the intense demand from our customers during a rising economy and our competitors sufficiently expand production, we could lose customers and/or market share.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P6_S2	These losses could have an adverse effect on our operations, financial condition, and results of operations.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P7_S0	In the past we have grown through successful integration of acquired businesses, but this may not continue.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P8_S0	Our long-term historical growth in revenues and net earnings has resulted in large part from our strategy of expansion through acquisitions.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P8_S1	Despite our plan to continue to grow, in part, through targeted acquisitions, we may be unable to continue to identify, have the financial capabilities to acquire, or successfully complete transactions with suitable acquisition candidates.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P8_S2	We are subject to various U.S. and foreign competition laws and regulations that may affect our ability to complete certain acquisitions.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P8_S3	Also, if an acquired business fails to operate as anticipated, cannot be successfully integrated with our other businesses, or we cannot effectively mitigate the assumed, contingent, and unknown liabilities acquired, our results of operations, financial condition, enterprise value, market value, and prospects could all be materially adversely affected.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Significant fluctuations in interest rates could adversely affect our results of operations and financial position.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P10_S0	We are exposed to changes in interest rates as a result of our borrowing activities and our cash balances.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P10_S1	Our credit facility and our exchangeable unsecured notes due 2102 bear interest at variable rates based on LIBOR.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P10_S2	A significant increase in LIBOR would significantly increase our interest expense.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P10_S3	A general increase in interest rates would be largely offset by an increase in interest income earned on our cash and short-term investment balances, which are currently greater than our debt balances.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P10_S4	However, there can be no assurance that the interest rate earned on cash and short-term investments will move in tandem with the interest rate paid on our variable rate debt.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P11_S0	Our debt levels have increased and may continue to increase, which could adversely affect the perception in the financial markets of our financial condition.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P12_S0	The recorded value of our outstanding debt increased from approximately $347 million as of December 31, 2008 to approximately $365 million as of December 31, 2013, primarily due to the issuance of convertible senior debentures, the proceeds from the sale of which we used to fund repurchases of our common stock.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P12_S1	The carrying value of our convertible senior debentures will continue to increase as the discount associated with the debentures is amortized.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P12_S2	Additionally, we and our subsidiaries may incur substantial additional debt in the future, subject to the conditions contained in our existing debt instruments, some of which may be secured debt.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P12_S3	The marketplace could react negatively to our current debt levels which in turn could affect our share price and also make it more difficult to obtain financing in the future.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Future acquisitions could require us to issue additional indebtedness or equity.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P14_S0	If we were to undertake a substantial acquisition for cash, the acquisition would likely need to be financed in part through bank borrowings or the issuance of public or private debt.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P14_S1	This acquisition financing would likely decrease our ratio of earnings to fixed charges and adversely affect other leverage criteria.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Under our existing credit facility, we are required to obtain the lenders' consent for certain additional debt financing and to comply with other covenants including the application of specific financial ratios.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P15_S1	We cannot make any assurances that the necessary acquisition financing would be available to us on acceptable terms if and when required.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P15_S2	If we were to undertake an acquisition for equity, the acquisition may have a dilutive effect on the interests of the holders of our common stock.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P16_S0	Our existing credit facility restricts our current and future operations and requires compliance with certain financial covenants.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P17_S0	Our existing credit facility includes restrictions on, among other things, incurring indebtedness, incurring liens on assets, making investments and acquisitions, making asset sales, and paying cash dividends and making other restricted payments.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P17_S1	Our existing credit facility also requires us to comply with other covenants, including the maintenance of specific financial ratios.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P17_S2	If we are not in compliance with all of such covenants, the credit facility could be terminated by the lenders, and all amounts outstanding pursuant to the credit facility could become immediately payable.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P17_S3	Additionally, our exchangeable unsecured notes due 2102 and our convertible senior debentures due 2040, due 2041, and due 2042 have cross-default provisions that could accelerate repayment in the event the indebtedness under the credit facility is accelerated.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P18_S0	To remain successful, we must continue to innovate, and our investments in new technologies may not prove successful.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P19_S0	Our future operating results are dependent on our ability to continually develop, introduce, and market new and innovative products, to modify existing products, to respond to technological change, and to customize certain products to meet customer requirements.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P19_S1	There are numerous risks inherent in this process, including the risks that we will be unable to anticipate the direction of technological change or that we will be unable to develop and market new products and applications in a timely fashion to satisfy customer demands.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P19_S2	If this occurs, we could lose customers and experience adverse effects on our financial condition and results of operations.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P20_S0	In addition to our own research and development initiatives, we periodically invest in technology start-up enterprises, in which we may acquire a controlling or noncontrolling interest but whose technology would be available to be commercialized by us.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P20_S1	There are numerous risks in investments of this nature including the limited operating history of such start-up entities, their need for capital, and their limited or absence of production experience, as well as the risk that their technologies may prove ineffective or fail to gain acceptance in the marketplace.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P20_S2	Certain of our historical investments in start-up companies have not succeeded, and there can be no assurance that our current and future investments in start-up enterprises will prove successful.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Our results are sensitive to raw material availability, quality, and cost.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P22_S0	Many of our products require the use of raw materials that are produced in only a limited number of regions around the world or are available from only a limited number of suppliers.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P22_S1	Our results of operations may be materially adversely affected if we have difficulty obtaining these raw materials, the quality of available raw materials deteriorates, or there are significant price increases for these raw materials.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P22_S2	The determination that any of the raw materials used in our products are conflict minerals originating from the Democratic Republic of the Congo or adjoining countries could increase the probability that we will encounter the challenges noted above, incur additional expenses to comply with government regulations, and face public scrutiny.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P22_S3	For periods in which the prices of these raw materials are rising, we may be unable to pass on the increased cost to our customers, which would result in decreased margins for the products in which they are used.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P22_S4	For periods in which the prices are declining, we may be required to write down our inventory carrying cost of these raw materials, because we record our inventory at the lower of cost or market.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P22_S5	Depending on the extent of the difference between market price and our carrying cost, this write-down could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P23_S0	From time to time there have been short-term market shortages of certain raw materials used in our products.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P23_S1	While these shortages have not historically adversely affected our ability to increase production of products containing these materials, they have historically resulted in higher raw material costs for us.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P23_S2	We cannot make any assurances that any of these market shortages in the future would not adversely affect our ability to increase production, particularly during periods of growing demand for our products.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P23_S3	To assure availability of raw materials in times of shortage, we may enter into long-term supply contracts for these materials, which may prove costly, unnecessary, and burdensome when the shortage abates.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P24_S0	We may not have adequate facilities to satisfy future increases in demand for our products.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P25_S0	Our business is cyclical and in periods of a rising economy, we may experience intense demand for our products.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P25_S1	During such periods, we may have difficulty expanding our manufacturing to satisfy demand.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P25_S2	Factors which could limit such expansion include delays in procurement of manufacturing equipment, shortages of skilled personnel, and physical constraints on expansion of our facilities.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P25_S3	If we are unable to meet our customers' requirements and our competitors sufficiently expand production, we could lose customers and/or market share.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P25_S4	These losses could have an adverse effect on our financial condition and results of operations.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P25_S5	Also, capacity that we add during upturns in the business cycle may result in excess capacity during periods when demand for our products recede, resulting in inefficient use of capital which could also adversely affect us.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P26_S0	Our ability to compete effectively with other companies depends, in part, on our ability to maintain the proprietary nature of our technology.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P27_S0	Protection of intellectual property often involves complex legal and factual issues.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P27_S1	We will be able to protect our proprietary rights from unauthorized use by third parties only to the extent that our proprietary technologies are covered by valid and enforceable patents or are effectively maintained as trade secrets.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P27_S2	We have applied, and will continue to apply, for patents covering our technologies and products, as we deem appropriate.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P27_S3	However, our applications may not result in issued patents.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P27_S4	Also, our existing patents and any future patents may not be sufficiently broad to prevent others from practicing our technologies or from developing competing products.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P27_S5	Others may independently develop similar or alternative technologies, design around our patented technologies, or may challenge or seek to invalidate our patents.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P27_S6	Also, the legal system in certain countries in which we operate may not provide or may not continue to provide sufficient, intellectual property legal protections and remedies.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P28_S0	Litigation regarding patent and other intellectual property rights is prevalent in the electronic components industry, particularly the discrete semiconductor sector.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P28_S1	We have on occasion been notified that we may be infringing on patent and other intellectual property rights of others.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P28_S2	In addition, customers purchasing components from us have rights to indemnification under certain circumstances if such components violate the intellectual property rights of others.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P28_S3	Further, we have observed that in the current business environment, electronic component and semiconductor companies have become more aggressive in asserting and defending patent claims against competitors.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P28_S4	We will continue to vigorously defend our intellectual property rights, and may become party to disputes regarding patent licensing and cross patent licensing.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P28_S5	Although licenses are generally offered in such situations and we have successfully resolved these situations in the past, there can be no assurance that we will not be subject to future litigation alleging intellectual property rights infringement, or that we will be able to obtain licenses on acceptable terms.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P28_S6	An unfavorable outcome regarding one of these matters could have a material adverse effect on our business and results of operations.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P29_S0	We face intense competition in our business, and we market our products to an increasingly concentrated group of customers.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P30_S0	Our business is highly competitive worldwide, with low transportation costs and few import barriers.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P30_S1	We compete principally on the bases of product quality and reliability, availability, customer service, technological innovation, timely delivery, and price.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P30_S2	The electronic component industry has become increasingly concentrated and globalized in recent years and our major competitors, some of which are larger than us, have significant financial resources and technological capabilities.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P31_S0	Our customers have become increasingly concentrated in recent years, and as a result, their buying power has increased and they have had greater ability to negotiate favorable pricing and terms.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P31_S1	This trend has adversely affected our average selling prices, particularly for commodity components.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P32_S0	Our backlog is subject to customer cancellation.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P33_S0	Many of the orders that comprise our backlog may be canceled by our customers without penalty.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P33_S1	Our customers may on occasion double and triple order components from multiple sources to ensure timely delivery when demand exceeds global supply.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P33_S2	They often cancel orders when business is weak and inventories are excessive, a situation that we experienced during the period of economic slowdown.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P33_S3	Therefore, we cannot be certain that the amount of our backlog accurately reflects the level of orders that we will ultimately deliver.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P33_S4	Our results of operations could be adversely impacted if customers cancel a material portion of orders in our backlog.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P34_S0	Future changes in our environmental liability and compliance obligations may harm our ability to operate or increase our costs.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P35_S0	Our operations, products and/or product packaging are subject to environmental laws and regulations governing air emissions, wastewater discharges, the handling, disposal and remediation of hazardous substances, wastes and certain chemicals used or generated in our manufacturing processes, employee health and safety labeling or other notifications with respect to the content or other aspects of our processes, products or packaging, restrictions on the use of certain materials in or on design aspects of our products or product packaging, and responsibility for disposal of products or product packaging.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P35_S1	We establish reserves for specifically identified potential environmental liabilities.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P35_S2	Nevertheless, we have in the past and may in the future inherit certain pre-existing environmental liabilities, generally based on successor liability doctrines, or otherwise incur environmental liabilities.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P36_S0	We are involved in remediation programs and related litigation at various current and former properties and at third-party disposal sites both within and outside of the U.S., including involvement as a potentially responsible party at Superfund sites.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P36_S1	Although we have never been involved in any environmental matter that has had a material adverse impact on our overall operations, there can be no assurance that in connection with any past or future acquisition, future developments, including related to our remediation programs, or otherwise, we will not be obligated to address environmental matters that could have a material adverse impact on our results of operations.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P36_S2	In addition, more stringent environmental regulations may be enacted in the future, and we cannot presently determine the modifications, if any, in our operations that any such future regulations might require, or the cost of compliance with these regulations.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P37_S0	In order to resolve liabilities at various sites, we have entered into various administrative orders and consent decrees, some of which may be, under certain conditions, reopened or subject to renegotiation.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P38_S0	Our products are sold to or used in goods sold to the U.S. government and other governments.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P38_S1	By virtue of such sales, we are subject to various regulatory requirements and risks in the event of non-compliance.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P39_S0	We sell products under prime and subprime contracts with the U.S. government and other governments.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P39_S1	Many of these products are used in military applications.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P40_S0	Government contractors must comply with specific procurement regulations and other requirements.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P40_S1	These requirements, although customary in government contracts, impact our performance and compliance costs.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P40_S2	Failure to comply with these regulations and requirements could result in contract modifications or termination, and the assessment of penalties and fines, which could negatively impact our results of operations and financial condition.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P40_S3	Our failure to comply with these regulations and requirements could also lead to suspension or debarment, for cause, from government contracting or subcontracting for a period of time.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P40_S4	Among the causes for debarment are violations of various statutes, including those related to procurement integrity, export control, government security regulations, employment practices, protection of the environment, accuracy of records and the recording of costs, and foreign corruption.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P40_S5	The termination of a government contract as a result of any of these acts could have a negative impact on our results of operations and financial condition and could have a negative impact on our reputation and ability to procure other government contracts in the future.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P41_S0	We have qualified certain of our products under various military specifications approved and monitored by the United States Defense Electronic Supply Center and under certain European military specifications.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P41_S1	These products are assigned certain classification levels.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P41_S2	In order to maintain the classification level of a product, we must continuously perform tests on the products and the results of these tests must be reported to governmental agencies.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P41_S3	If a product fails to meet the requirements of the applicable classification level, its classification may be reduced to a lower level.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P41_S4	A decrease in the classification level for a product with a military application could have an adverse impact on the net revenues and earnings attributable to that product.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P42_S0	Our future success is substantially dependent on our ability to attract and retain highly qualified technical, managerial, marketing, finance, and administrative personnel.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P43_S0	Rapid changes in technologies, frequent new product introductions, and declining average selling prices over product life cycles require us to attract and retain highly qualified personnel to develop and manufacture products that feature technological innovations and bring them to market on a timely basis.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P43_S1	Our complex operations also require us to attract and retain highly qualified administrative personnel in functions such as legal, tax, accounting, financial reporting, auditing, and treasury.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P43_S2	The market for personnel with such qualifications is highly competitive.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P43_S3	While we have employment agreements with certain of our executives, we have not entered into employment agreements with all of our key personnel.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P44_S0	The loss of the services of or the failure to effectively recruit qualified personnel could have a material adverse effect on our business.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P45_S0	Interruptions in our information technology systems could adversely affect our business.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P46_S0	We rely on the efficient and uninterrupted operation of complex information technology systems and networks to operate our business.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P46_S1	Any significant system or network disruption, including, but not limited to, new system implementations, computer viruses, security breaches, facility issues or energy blackouts could have a material adverse impact on our operations and results of operations.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P46_S2	Such network disruption could result in a loss of the confidentiality of our intellectual property or the release of sensitive competitive information or customer or employee personal data.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P46_S3	Any loss of such information could harm our competitive position, result in a loss of customer confidence, and cause us to incur significant costs to remedy the damages caused by the disruptions or security breaches.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P46_S4	We have implemented protective measures to prevent against and limit the effects of system or network disruptions, but there can be no assurance that such measures will be sufficient to prevent or limit the damage from any future disruptions and any such disruption could have a material adverse impact on our business and results of operations.

103730_14_ITEM1A_P48_S0	We are subject to the risks of political, economic, and military instability in countries outside the United States in which we operate.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P49_S0	We have substantial operations outside the United States, and approximately 75% of our revenues during 2013 were derived from sales to customers outside the United States.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P49_S1	Certain of our assets are located, and certain of our products are produced, in countries which are subject to risks of social, political, economic, and military instability.

103730_14_ITEM1A_P49_S3	These conditions could have an adverse impact on our ability to operate in these regions and, depending on the extent and severity of these conditions, could materially and adversely affect our overall financial condition, results of operations, and our ability to access our liquidity.

103730_14_ITEM1A_P50_S1	Although we have never experienced any material interruption in our operations attributable to these factors, in spite of several Middle East crises, including wars, our financial condition and results of operations might be adversely affected if events were to occur in the Middle East that interfered with our operations in Israel.

103730_14_ITEM1A_P52_S0	The U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and similar foreign anti-corruption laws generally prohibit companies and their intermediaries from making improper payments or providing anything of value to improperly influence foreign government officials for the purpose of obtaining or retaining business, or obtaining an unfair advantage.
103730_14_ITEM1A_P53_S0	Recent years have seen a substantial increase in the global enforcement of anti-corruption laws.
