103730_17_ITEM1_P23_S0	Since our first acquisition in 1985, we have pursued a business strategy that principally consists of the following elements:
103730_17_ITEM1_P24_S0	We plan to continue to use our research and development ("R D"), engineering, and product marketing resources to continually roll out new and innovative products.
103730_17_ITEM1_P24_S1	As part of our plan to foster intensified internal growth, we have increased our worldwide R D and engineering technical staff, and increased our technical field sales force in Asia to increase opportunities to design-in our products in local markets.
103730_17_ITEM1_P24_S2	Our ability to react to changing customer needs and industry trends will continue to be key to our success.
103730_17_ITEM1_P24_S3	We intend to leverage our insights into customer demand to continually develop new innovative products within our existing lines and to modify our existing core products to make them more appealing, addressing changing customer needs and industry trends.
103730_17_ITEM1_P25_S0	We are directing increased funding and are focusing on developing products to capitalize on the connectivity, mobility, and sustainability growth drivers of our business.
103730_17_ITEM1_P26_S0	We place a strong emphasis on controlling our costs.
103730_17_ITEM1_P26_S1	We focus on controlling fixed costs and reducing variable costs.
103730_17_ITEM1_P26_S2	When our ongoing cost management activites are not adequate, we take actions to maintain our cost competitiveness including restructuring our business to improve efficiency and operating performance.
103730_17_ITEM1_P27_S0	We plan to continue to expand within the electronic components industry, through the acquisition of other manufacturers of electronic components that have established positions in major markets, reputations for product innovation, quality, and reliability, strong customer bases, and product lines with which we have substantial marketing and technical expertise.
103730_17_ITEM1_P28_S0	We maintain significant production facilities in those regions where we market the bulk of our products in order to enhance the service and responsiveness that we provide to our customers.
103730_17_ITEM1_P28_S1	We aim to further strengthen our relationships with customers and strategic partners by providing broad product lines that allow us to provide "one-stop shop" service, whereby they can streamline their design and purchasing processes by ordering multiple types of products.
103730_17_ITEM1_P29_S0	Our growth plan was designed based on the tenets of the key business strategies listed above.
103730_17_ITEM1_P30_S0	We design, manufacture, and market electronic components that cover a wide range of functions and technologies.
103730_17_ITEM1_P31_S0	We promote our ability to provide "one-stop shop" service to customers, whereby they can streamline their design and purchasing processes by ordering multiple types of products from Vishay.
103730_17_ITEM1_P31_S1	Our technical sales force consisting of field application engineers offers customers the complete breadth of the Vishay portfolio for their applications.
103730_17_ITEM1_P31_S2	We aim to use this broad portfolio to increase opportunities to have our components selected and "designed in" to new end products.
103730_17_ITEM1_P32_S0	Our products can be divided into two general classes: semiconductors and passive components.
103730_17_ITEM1_P32_S1	Semiconductors are sometimes referred to as "active components" because they require power to function whereas passive components do not require power to function.
103730_17_ITEM1_P32_S2	Our semiconductor and passive components products are further categorized based on their functionality for financial reporting purposes.
103730_17_ITEM1_P32_S3	See Note 15 to our consolidated financial statements for additional information on revenues, income, and total assets by segment.
103730_17_ITEM1_P33_S0	Our semiconductor products include metal oxide semiconductor field-effect transistors ("MOSFETs"), Diodes, and Optoelectronic Components.
103730_17_ITEM1_P34_S0	Semiconductors are typically used to perform functions such as switching, amplifying, rectifying, routing, or transmitting electrical signals, power conversion, and power management.
103730_17_ITEM1_P35_S0	MOSFETs function as solid state switches to control power.
103730_17_ITEM1_P36_S0	Our MOSFETs business includes both the commodity and non-commodity markets in which we believe that we enjoy a good reputation and strong brand recognition (Siliconix).
103730_17_ITEM1_P37_S0	MOSFETs applications include mobile phones, notebook and desktop computers, tablet computers, digital cameras, televisions, DC/DC and AC/DC switch mode power supplies, solar inverters, automotive and industrial systems.
103730_17_ITEM1_P37_S1	We are a leader in low-voltage TrenchFET MOSFETs and also offer high-voltage MOSFETs.
103730_17_ITEM1_P37_S2	Our MOSFETs product line includes low- and medium-voltage TrenchFET MOSFETs, high-voltage planar MOSFETs, high voltage Super Junction MOSFETs, power integrated circuits (power ICs), and integrated function power devices.
103730_17_ITEM1_P37_S3	We are one of the technology leaders in MOSFETs, with a tradition of innovation in wafer design, packaging, and performance.
103730_17_ITEM1_P38_S0	Diodes route, regulate, and block radio frequency, analog, and power signals; protect systems from surges or electrostatic discharge damage; or provide electromagnetic interference filtering.
103730_17_ITEM1_P39_S0	Our Diodes business is a solid business with a strong market presence in both the commodity and non-commodity markets.
103730_17_ITEM1_P39_S1	The products that comprise our Diodes business represent our broadest product line and include rectifiers, small signal diodes, protection diodes, thyristors/SCRs and power modules.
103730_17_ITEM1_P40_S0	The primary application of rectifiers, found inside the power supplies of virtually all electronic equipment, is to derive DC power from the AC supply.
103730_17_ITEM1_P40_S1	Vishay is the worldwide leader in rectifiers, having a broad technology base and a good position in automotive, industrial, computing and consumer markets.
103730_17_ITEM1_P40_S2	Our rectifier innovations include TMBS using Trench MOS barrier Schottky rectifier technology, which reduces power loss and improves the efficiency of end systems and eSMP , the best in class high-current density surface mount packages.
103730_17_ITEM1_P41_S0	Our wide selection of small signal diodes consist of the following functions: switching, tuning, band-switching, RF attenuation and voltage regulation (Zener).
103730_17_ITEM1_P41_S1	They are available in various glass and plastic packaging options and generally are used in electronic circuits, where small currents and high frequencies are involved.
103730_17_ITEM1_P42_S0	Vishay is also one of the market leaders for TVS (transient voltage suppressor) diodes.
103730_17_ITEM1_P42_S1	The portfolio of protection diodes includes ESD protection and EMI filter.
103730_17_ITEM1_P43_S0	Our thyristors or SCR (silicon-controlled rectifiers) are very popular in the industrial high-voltage AC power control applications.
103730_17_ITEM1_P43_S1	The fast growing markets of solar inverter and HEV/EV are the focus of our power modules business (IGBT or MOSFET modules).
103730_17_ITEM1_P43_S2	These modules can be customized to fit in different customer design requirements.
103730_17_ITEM1_P44_S0	Optoelectronic components emit light, detect light, or do both.
103730_17_ITEM1_P45_S0	Our Optoelectronic Components business has a strong market presence in both the commodity and non-commodity markets.
103730_17_ITEM1_P45_S1	Our broad range of standard and customer specific optoelectronic components includes infrared ("IR") emitters and detectors, IR remote control receivers, optocouplers, solid-state relays, optical sensors, light-emitting diodes ("LEDs"), 7-segment displays, and IR data transceiver modules (IrDA ).
103730_17_ITEM1_P45_S2	Our IR remote control receivers are designed for use in infrared remote control, data transmission, and light barrier applications in end products including televisions, set-top boxes, notebook computers, and audio systems.
103730_17_ITEM1_P45_S3	We are the leading manufacturer of IR remote control receivers.
103730_17_ITEM1_P45_S4	Our optocouplers electrically isolate input and output signals.
103730_17_ITEM1_P45_S5	Uses include switch-mode power supplies, consumer electronics, telecommunications equipment, solar inverters, and industrial systems.
103730_17_ITEM1_P46_S0	Our IR data transceiver modules are used for short range, two-way, high-speed, and secure wireless data transfer between electronic devices such as home medical appliances, mobile phones, industrial data loggers, and metering.
103730_17_ITEM1_P46_S1	Our optical sensors product line was considerably strengthened by our acquisition of Capella in 2014.
103730_17_ITEM1_P46_S2	Our optical sensors products include ambient light sensors, optical encoders, integrated photodiode and I/V amplifiers, proximity sensors, color sensors, and UV sensors.
103730_17_ITEM1_P46_S3	Applications include telecommunications, mobile phones, smartphone, handheld devices, digital cameras, laptops, desktop computers, LED backlighting, office automation equipment, household electrical appliance and automotive electronics.
103730_17_ITEM1_P46_S4	Our LEDs are designed for backlighting and illumination in automotive and other applications.
103730_17_ITEM1_P46_S5	Our LEDs include ultra-bright as well as small surface-mount packages, with products available in all standard colors including white.
103730_17_ITEM1_P47_S0	Our passive components include resistors, capacitors, and magnetics such as inductors and transformers.
103730_17_ITEM1_P47_S1	Passive components are used to store electrical charges, to limit or resist electrical current, and to help in filtering, surge suppression, measurement, timing, and tuning applications.
103730_17_ITEM1_P48_S0	Resistors and inductors both impede electric current.
103730_17_ITEM1_P49_S0	Resistors are basic components used in all forms of electronic circuitry to adjust and regulate levels of voltage and current.
103730_17_ITEM1_P50_S0	Inductors use an internal magnetic field to change alternating current phase and resist alternating current.
103730_17_ITEM1_P50_S1	Our Resistors and Inductors business is our original business.
103730_17_ITEM1_P50_S2	We maintain the broadest portfolio of resistor products worldwide.
103730_17_ITEM1_P50_S3	Under current market conditions, the business is solid, predictable, and growing at relatively stable selling prices.
103730_17_ITEM1_P50_S4	We are a market leader with a strong technology base, many specialty products, and strong brand recognition (such as our Dale, Draloric, Beyschlag, Sfernice, and HiRel Systems brands).
103730_17_ITEM1_P50_S5	We focus on higher value markets in specialized industries, while maintaining a complete portfolio of commodity products.
103730_17_ITEM1_P50_S6	We do not aim to be the volume leader in commodity markets.
103730_17_ITEM1_P51_S0	Resistors vary widely in precision and cost, and are manufactured from numerous materials and in many forms.
103730_17_ITEM1_P51_S1	Linear resistive components are classified as variable or fixed, depending on whether or not their resistance is adjustable.
103730_17_ITEM1_P52_S0	Non-linear resistors function by varying in resistance under influence of temperature (thermistors) or voltage (varistors).
103730_17_ITEM1_P52_S1	They can be used in temperature-measuring applications or as current or voltage-limiting devices.
103730_17_ITEM1_P53_S0	We manufacture virtually all types of fixed resistors, both in discrete and network forms, as well as many variable types.
103730_17_ITEM1_P54_S0	Vishay resistor innovations include Power Metal Strip technology.
103730_17_ITEM1_P54_S1	These resistors feature very low resistance and are used to measure changes in current flow (current sensing) or divert current flow (shunting).
103730_17_ITEM1_P55_S0	Inductor applications include controlling AC current and voltage, filtering out unwanted electrical signals, and energy storage.
103730_17_ITEM1_P55_S1	Vishay inductor innovations include IHLP low-profile, high-current inductor technology with industry-leading specifications, which is patented and generates royalty revenue.
103730_17_ITEM1_P55_S2	Our low-profile, high-current inductors save circuit board space and power in voltage regulator module ("VRM") and DC to DC converter applications.
103730_17_ITEM1_P55_S3	In addition, we are a worldwide leader in custom magnetic solutions focusing on high performance and high reliability.
103730_17_ITEM1_P55_S4	This field has been substantially strengthened, with the 2012 acquisition of HiRel Systems, broadening our portfolio, customer, and market segment reach.
103730_17_ITEM1_P56_S0	Capacitors store energy and discharge it when needed.
103730_17_ITEM1_P57_S0	Our Capacitors business consists of a broad range of reliable, high-quality products.
103730_17_ITEM1_P57_S1	We have a strong presence worldwide in specialty markets based on our product performance and reliability and strong brand recognition (including our Sprague, Vitramon, Roederstein, BCcomponents, and ESTA brands).
103730_17_ITEM1_P57_S2	We focus on higher value markets in specialized industries, while maintaining a complete portfolio of commodity products.
103730_17_ITEM1_P57_S3	We do not aim to be the volume leader in commodity markets.
103730_17_ITEM1_P58_S0	Capacitors are used in almost all electronic circuits.
103730_17_ITEM1_P58_S1	They store energy and discharge it when needed.
103730_17_ITEM1_P59_S0	Important applications for capacitors include electronic filtering for linear and switching power supplies; decoupling and bypass of electronic signals for integrated circuits and circuit boards; and frequency control, timing and conditioning of electronic signals for a broad range of applications.
103730_17_ITEM1_P60_S0	We manufacture products based on all major capacitor technologies: tantalum (molded chip tantalum, coated chip tantalum, solid through-hole tantalum, wet tantalum, and polymer), ceramic (multilayer chip and ceramic disc), film, power, heavy-current, and aluminum electrolytic.
103730_17_ITEM1_P60_S1	Our capacitors range from tiny surface-mount devices for hearing aids and mobile devices to large power correction capacitors used in renewable energy, heavy industry, and electrical power grids.
103730_17_ITEM1_P60_S2	We are a recognized technology leader in many product ranges, securing our strong position in military and medical markets, and in a wide range of industrial and automotive applications.
103730_17_ITEM1_P60_S3	Our wet tantalum and MicroTan technologies are market leaders.
103730_17_ITEM1_P61_S0	We have qualified certain of our products under various military specifications approved and monitored by United States government agencies, and under certain European military specifications.
103730_17_ITEM1_P61_S1	Qualification levels are based in part upon the rate of failure of products.
103730_17_ITEM1_P61_S2	In order to maintain the classification level of a product, we must continuously perform tests on the product and the results of these tests must be reported to the government agencies.
103730_17_ITEM1_P61_S3	If the product fails to meet the requirements for the applicable classification level, the product's classification may be reduced to a lower level.
103730_17_ITEM1_P62_S0	During the time that the classification level is reduced for a product with military application, net revenues and earnings attributable to that product may be adversely affected.
103730_17_ITEM1_P63_S0	In order to better serve our customers, we maintain production facilities in locations where we market the bulk of our products, such as the United States, Germany, and Asia.
103730_17_ITEM1_P63_S1	To optimize production efficiencies, we have whenever practicable established manufacturing facilities in countries, such as the Czech Republic, Hungary, India, Israel, Malaysia, Mexico, the People's Republic of China, and the Philippines, where we can benefit from lower labor and tax costs and also benefit from various government incentives, including grants and tax relief.
103730_17_ITEM1_P64_S0	One of our most sophisticated manufacturing operations is the production of power semiconductor components.
103730_17_ITEM1_P64_S1	This manufacturing process involves two phases of production: wafer fabrication and assembly (or packaging).
103730_17_ITEM1_P65_S0	Wafer fabrication subjects silicon wafers to various thermal, metallurgical, and chemical process steps that change their electrical and physical properties.
103730_17_ITEM1_P65_S1	These process steps define cells or circuits within numerous individual devices (termed "dies" or "chips") on each wafer.
103730_17_ITEM1_P65_S2	Assembly is the sequence of production steps that divides the wafer into individual chips and encloses the chips in structures (termed "packages") that make them usable in a circuit.
103730_17_ITEM1_P65_S3	Both wafer fabrication and assembly phases incorporate wafer level and device level electrical testing to ensure that device design integrity has been achieved.
103730_17_ITEM1_P66_S0	In the United States, our manufacturing facilities are located in California, Minnesota, Nebraska, New Hampshire, New York, Rhode Island, South Dakota, Vermont, and Wisconsin.
103730_17_ITEM1_P66_S1	In Asia, our main manufacturing facilities are located in the People's Republic of China, the Republic of China (Taiwan), India, and Malaysia.
103730_17_ITEM1_P66_S2	In Europe, our main manufacturing facilities are located in Germany, France, and the Czech Republic.
103730_17_ITEM1_P66_S3	We have substantial manufacturing facilities in Israel.
103730_17_ITEM1_P66_S4	We also have manufacturing facilities in Austria, Dominican Republic, Japan, Hungary, Italy, Mexico, Portugal, and the Philippines.
103730_17_ITEM1_P66_S5	Over the past several years, we have invested substantial resources to increase the efficiency of our plants, which we believe will further reduce production costs.
103730_17_ITEM1_P67_S0	All of our manufacturing operations have received ISO 9001 certification.
103730_17_ITEM1_P68_S0	ISO 9001 is a comprehensive set of quality program standards developed by the International Standards Organization.

103730_17_ITEM1_P70_S0	Although most materials incorporated in our products are available from a number of sources, certain materials, including plastics and metals, are available only from a relatively limited number of suppliers or are subject to significant price volatility.
103730_17_ITEM1_P71_S0	Silicon wafers are the most important raw material for the manufacturing of our semiconductor products.
103730_17_ITEM1_P72_S0	Silicon wafers are manufactured from high-purity silicon, a metalloid.
103730_17_ITEM1_P72_S1	There have at times been industry-wide shortages of high-purity silicon resulting primarily from growing demand of the electronic component and solar power industries, and limited growth in high-purity silicon manufacturing capacities.
103730_17_ITEM1_P72_S2	Shifts in demand for high-purity silicon and in turn, silicon wafers, have resulted in significant fluctuation in prices of silicon wafers.
103730_17_ITEM1_P73_S0	We are a major consumer of the world's annual production of tantalum, a metal used in the manufacturing of tantalum capacitors.
103730_17_ITEM1_P73_S1	There are few suppliers that process tantalum ore into capacitor grade tantalum powder.
103730_17_ITEM1_P74_S0	Certain materials, in addition to tantalum and including tin, tungsten, and gold are available only from a relatively limited number of suppliers, the source for which may be in the Democratic Republic of the Congo ("DRC") or an adjoining country.
103730_17_ITEM1_P74_S1	We are working toward the elimination of materials that directly or indirectly finance or benefit armed groups in the DRC or adjoining countries from our supply chain.
103730_17_ITEM1_P75_S0	Palladium, a metal used to produce multi-layer ceramic capacitors, is currently found primarily in South Africa and Russia.
103730_17_ITEM1_P75_S1	Palladium is a commodity metal that is subject to price volatility.
103730_17_ITEM1_P75_S2	We periodically enter into short-term commitments to purchase palladium.
103730_17_ITEM1_P76_S0	Certain metals used in the manufacture of our products, such as copper, are traded on active markets, and can be subject to significant price volatility.
103730_17_ITEM1_P76_S1	Our policy is to enter into short-term commitments to purchase defined portions of annual consumption of these metals if market prices decline below budget.
103730_17_ITEM1_P77_S0	We manufacture both standardized products and those designed and produced to meet customer specifications.
103730_17_ITEM1_P77_S1	We maintain an inventory of standardized components and monitor the backlog of outstanding orders for our products.
103730_17_ITEM1_P78_S0	We include in our backlog only open orders that we expect to ship in the next twelve months.
103730_17_ITEM1_P79_S0	Many of our customers encounter uncertain and changing demand for their products.
103730_17_ITEM1_P79_S1	They typically order products from us based on their forecasts.
103730_17_ITEM1_P79_S2	If demand falls below customers' forecasts, or if customers do not control their inventory effectively, they may cancel or reschedule the shipments included in our backlog, in many instances without the payment of any penalty.
103730_17_ITEM1_P79_S3	Therefore, our backlog at any point in time is not necessarily indicative of the results to be expected for future periods.
103730_17_ITEM1_P80_S0	We sell our products to original equipment manufacturers ("OEMs"), electronic manufacturing services ("EMS") companies, which manufacture for OEMs on an outsourcing basis, and independent distributors that maintain large inventories of electronic components for resale to OEMs and EMS companies.

103730_17_ITEM1_P84_S2	Organized by market segment, our Business Development FAEs bring specific knowledge of component applications in their areas of expertise in the automotive, telecommunications, computer, consumer/entertainment, industrial, peripherals, digital consumer, and other market segments.

103730_17_ITEM1_P110_S1	We continually expend funds to ensure that our facilities comply with applicable environmental regulations.
103730_17_ITEM1_P110_S2	While we believe that we are in material compliance with applicable environmental laws, we cannot accurately predict future developments and do not necessarily have knowledge of all past occurrences on sites that we currently occupy.
103730_17_ITEM1_P110_S3	More stringent environmental regulations may be enacted in the future, and we cannot determine the modifications, if any, in our operations that any such future regulations might require, or the cost of compliance with such regulations.
103730_17_ITEM1_P110_S4	Moreover, the risk of environmental liability and remediation costs is inherent in the nature of our business and, therefore, there can be no assurance that material environmental costs, including remediation costs, will not arise in the future.
103730_17_ITEM1_P111_S0	With each acquisition, we attempt to identify potential environmental concerns and to minimize, or obtain indemnification for, the environmental matters we may be required to address.
103730_17_ITEM1_P111_S1	In addition, we establish reserves for specifically identified potential environmental liabilities.
103730_17_ITEM1_P111_S2	We believe that the reserves we have established are adequate.
103730_17_ITEM1_P111_S3	Nevertheless, we have in the past and may in the future inherit certain pre-existing environmental liabilities, generally based on successor liability doctrines.
103730_17_ITEM1_P111_S4	Although we have never been involved in any environmental matter that has had a material adverse impact on our overall operations, there can be no assurance that in connection with any past or future acquisition we will not be obligated to address environmental matters that could have a material adverse impact on our operations.

103730_17_ITEM1A_P0_S0	From time to time, information provided by us, including but not limited to statements in this report, or other statements made by or on our behalf, may contain "forward-looking" information within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Such statements involve a number of risks, uncertainties, and contingencies, many of which are beyond our control, which may cause actual results, performance, or achievements to differ materially from those anticipated.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P0_S2	Set forth below are important factors that could cause our results, performance, or achievements to differ materially from those in any forward-looking statements made by us or on our behalf.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P0_S3	You should understand that it is not possible to predict or identify all such factors.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P0_S4	Consequently, you should not consider the following to be a complete discussion of all potential risks or uncertainties.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Our business is cyclical and future periods of decline and recovery are not predictable.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P2_S0	The electronic component industry is highly cyclical and experiences periods of decline from time to time.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P2_S1	We and others in the electronic component industry have experienced these conditions in the recent past and cannot predict when we may experience such downturns in the future.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Market conditions, such as a decline in product demand on a global basis, could result in order cancellations and deferrals, lower average selling prices, and a material and adverse impact on our results of operations.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P2_S3	These declines in demand are driven by market conditions in the end markets for our products.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P2_S4	Changes in the demand mix, needed technologies, and these end markets may adversely affect our ability to match our products, inventory, and capacity to meet customer demand and could adversely affect our operating results and financial condition.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P2_S5	A slowdown in demand or recessionary trends in the global economy makes it more difficult for us to predict our future sales and manage our operations, and could adversely impact our results of operations.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P3_S0	We have incurred and will continue to incur restructuring costs and associated asset write-downs.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P4_S0	To remain competitive, particularly when business conditions are difficult, we sometimes attempt to reduce our cost structure by restructuring our existing businesses, where we seek to achieve synergies, eliminate redundant facilities and staff positions, and move operations, where possible, to jurisdictions with lower labor costs.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P4_S1	In 2013 and 2015, we announced various cost reduction programs as part of our continuous efforts to improve efficiency and operating performance.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P4_S2	The programs primarily focus on enhancing the competitiveness of our MOSFETs segment, reducing selling, general, and administrative expenses company-wide, and improving the performance of certain product lines within our Capacitors and Resistors Inductors segments.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P4_S3	In 2016, we announced an extension of the 2013 MOSFETs Enhanced Competitiveness Program.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P4_S4	We incur accelerated depreciation expenses related to assets that will no longer be used after the associated restructuring programs are implemented.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P4_S5	The expenses associated with the programs have been and will continue to be recorded as they become recognizable under GAAP.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P4_S6	Complete implementation of all of the programs is expected to occur before the end of 2017.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Additionally, our long-term strategy includes growing through the integration of acquired businesses, and GAAP requires plant closure and employee termination costs that we incur in connection with our acquisition activities to be recorded as expenses in our consolidated statement of operations, as such expenses are incurred.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P5_S1	For this reason, we expect to have some level of future restructuring expenses due to acquisitions.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Our business is cyclical, and in periods of a rising economy we may experience intense demand for our products.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P6_S1	If our restructuring activities result in us not being able to satisfy the intense demand from our customers during a rising economy and our competitors sufficiently expand production, we could lose customers and/or market share.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P6_S2	These losses could have an adverse effect on our operations, financial condition, and results of operations.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P7_S0	In the past we have grown through successful integration of acquired businesses, but this may not continue.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P8_S0	Our long-term historical growth in revenues and net earnings has resulted in large part from our strategy of expansion through acquisitions.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P8_S1	Despite our plan to continue to grow, in part, through targeted acquisitions, we may be unable to continue to identify, have the financial capabilities to acquire, or successfully complete transactions with suitable acquisition candidates.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P8_S2	We are subject to various U.S. and foreign competition laws and regulations that may affect our ability to complete certain acquisitions.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P8_S3	Also, if an acquired business fails to operate as anticipated, cannot be successfully integrated with our other businesses, or we cannot effectively mitigate the assumed, contingent, and unknown liabilities acquired, our results of operations, financial condition, enterprise value, market value, and prospects could all be materially adversely affected.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P9_S0	To remain successful, we must continue to innovate, and our investments in new technologies may not prove successful.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Our future operating results are dependent on our ability to continually develop, introduce, and market new and innovative products, to modify existing products, to respond to technological change, and to customize certain products to meet customer requirements.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P10_S1	There are numerous risks inherent in this process, including the risks that we will be unable to anticipate the direction of technological change or that we will be unable to develop and market new products and applications in a timely fashion to satisfy customer demands.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P10_S2	If this occurs, we could lose customers and experience adverse effects on our financial condition and results of operations.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P11_S0	In addition to our own research and development initiatives, we periodically invest in technology start-up enterprises, in which we may acquire a controlling or noncontrolling interest but whose technology would be available to be commercialized by us.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P11_S1	There are numerous risks in investments of this nature including the limited operating history of such start-up entities, their need for capital, and their limited or absence of production experience, as well as the risk that their technologies may prove ineffective or fail to gain acceptance in the marketplace.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P11_S2	Certain of our historical investments in start-up companies have not succeeded, and there can be no assurance that our current and future investments in start-up enterprises will prove successful.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Certain acquisitions will increase the risks inherent in our business.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Our 2014 acquisition of Capella Microsystems (Taiwan) Inc. is unique compared to our past acquisitions.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P13_S1	Most of our previous acquisitions were established businesses with substantial tangible assets.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P13_S2	As a fabless design business, most of the assets acquired in the Capella transaction were intangible.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P14_S0	The Capella business has not performed as expected.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P14_S1	As a result, it was determined in 2015 that the depreciable and amortizable long-lived assets of Capella were not recoverable, and we recorded impairment charges of $57.6 million in 2015 to write-down the related assets to their fair value.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P14_S2	If the acquired business continues to not perform as expected, we may be required to record further impairment charges related to those intangible assets, with limited ability to monetize any of those assets.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P15_S0	There are significant risks specific to the acquired business that could result in it continuing to not perform as expected.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P16_S0	As a fabless design business, Capella is substantially dependent on independent third-party foundries and subcontractors to manufacture its products.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P16_S1	If Capella cannot obtain sufficient capacity commitments, if Capella's foundries and subcontractors suffer financial instability, liquidity issues, or insolvency proceedings affecting their ability to manufacture our products, or if Capella's foundries and subcontractors experience production delays for other reasons, the supply of its products could be disrupted, which could adversely affect our business.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P16_S2	If demand for its products increases significantly, we have no assurances that Capella's third-party foundries and subcontractors will be able to increase their manufacturing capacity to a level that meets our requirements, potentially preventing us from meeting our customer demand and harming our business and customer relationships.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P16_S3	Also, even if Capella's foundries and subcontractors are able to meet our increased demand, those third-party manufacturers may decide to charge significantly higher wafer prices to us, which could reduce our gross margin or require us to offset the increased costs by increasing prices to our customers, either of which could harm our business and operating results.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P17_S0	Capella's future success is substantially dependent on our ability to attract and retain highly qualified technical personnel.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P17_S1	We could be materially adversely affected if the turnover rates for engineers and other key personnel increases significantly or we are unsuccessful in attracting, motivating and retaining qualified personnel.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P17_S2	Should we lose one or more engineers who are key to a project's completion during the course of a particular project, the completion of such project may be delayed which could negatively affect customer relationships and goodwill and have a material adverse effect on our results of operations.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P18_S0	Capella's historical customer base is concentrated among a few key customers, and is focused on end-users in the consumer products industry.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P18_S1	The delay, significant reduction in, or loss of, orders from these large customers or the consumer products industry, or demands of price concessions from these customers could have a material adverse effect on our net revenues and results of operations, or could result in significant volatility in our results of operations.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P19_S0	Significant fluctuations in interest rates could adversely affect our results of operations and financial position.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P20_S0	We are exposed to changes in interest rates as a result of our borrowing activities and our cash balances.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P20_S1	Our credit facility bears interest at variable rates based on LIBOR.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P20_S2	A significant increase in LIBOR would significantly increase our interest expense.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P20_S3	A general increase in interest rates would be largely offset by an increase in interest income earned on our cash and short-term investment balances, which are currently greater than our debt balances.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P20_S4	However, there can be no assurance that the interest rate earned on cash and short-term investments will move in tandem with the interest rate paid on our variable rate debt.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Our debt levels have increased and may continue to increase, which could adversely affect the perception in the financial markets of our financial condition.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P22_S0	The recorded value of our outstanding debt increased from approximately $347 million as of December 31, 2008 to approximately $357 million as of December 31, 2016, primarily due to the issuance of convertible senior debentures, the proceeds from the sale of which we used to fund repurchases of our common stock.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P22_S1	The carrying value of our convertible senior debentures will continue to increase as the discount associated with the debentures is amortized.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P22_S2	Additionally, we and our subsidiaries may incur substantial additional debt in the future, subject to the conditions contained in our existing debt instruments, some of which may be secured debt.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P22_S3	The marketplace could react negatively to our current debt levels which in turn could affect our share price and also make it more difficult to obtain financing in the future.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P23_S0	Future acquisitions could require us to issue additional indebtedness or equity.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P24_S0	If we were to undertake a substantial acquisition for cash, the acquisition would likely need to be financed in part through bank borrowings or the issuance of public or private debt.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P24_S1	This acquisition financing would likely decrease our ratio of earnings to fixed charges and adversely affect other leverage criteria.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P25_S0	Under our existing credit facility, we are required to obtain the lenders' consent for certain additional debt financing and to comply with other covenants including the application of specific financial ratios.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P25_S1	We cannot make any assurances that the necessary acquisition financing would be available to us on acceptable terms if and when required.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P25_S2	If we were to undertake an acquisition for equity, the acquisition may have a dilutive effect on the interests of the holders of our common stock.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P26_S0	Our existing credit facility restricts our current and future operations and requires compliance with certain financial covenants.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P27_S0	Our existing credit facility includes restrictions on, among other things, incurring indebtedness, incurring liens on assets, making investments and acquisitions, making asset sales, and paying cash dividends and making other restricted payments.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P27_S1	Our existing credit facility also requires us to comply with other covenants, including the maintenance of specific financial ratios.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P27_S2	If we are not in compliance with all of such covenants, the credit facility could be terminated by the lenders, and all amounts outstanding pursuant to the credit facility could become immediately payable.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P27_S3	Additionally, our convertible senior debentures due 2040, due 2041, and due 2042 have cross-default provisions that could accelerate repayment in the event the indebtedness under the credit facility is accelerated.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P28_S0	Our results are sensitive to raw material availability, quality, and cost.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P29_S0	Many of our products require the use of raw materials that are produced in only a limited number of regions around the world or are available from only a limited number of suppliers.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P29_S1	Our results of operations may be materially adversely affected if we have difficulty obtaining these raw materials, the quality of available raw materials deteriorates, or there are significant price increases for these raw materials.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P29_S2	The determination that any of the raw materials used in our products are conflict minerals originating from the Democratic Republic of the Congo or adjoining countries could increase the probability that we will encounter the challenges noted above, incur additional expenses to comply with government regulations, and face public scrutiny.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P29_S3	For periods in which the prices of these raw materials are rising, we may be unable to pass on the increased cost to our customers, which would result in decreased margins for the products in which they are used.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P29_S4	For periods in which the prices are declining, we may be required to write down our inventory carrying cost of these raw materials, because we record our inventory at the lower of cost or market.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P29_S5	Depending on the extent of the difference between market price and our carrying cost, this write-down could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P30_S0	From time to time there have been short-term market shortages of certain raw materials used in our products.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P30_S1	While these shortages have not historically adversely affected our ability to increase production of products containing these materials, they have historically resulted in higher raw material costs for us.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P30_S2	We cannot make any assurances that any of these market shortages in the future would not adversely affect our ability to increase production, particularly during periods of growing demand for our products.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P30_S3	To assure availability of raw materials in times of shortage, we may enter into long-term supply contracts for these materials, which may prove costly, unnecessary, and burdensome when the shortage abates.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P31_S0	We may not have adequate facilities to satisfy future increases in demand for our products.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P32_S0	Our business is cyclical and in periods of a rising economy, we may experience intense demand for our products.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P32_S1	During such periods, we may have difficulty expanding our manufacturing to satisfy demand.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P32_S2	Factors which could limit such expansion include delays in procurement of manufacturing equipment, shortages of skilled personnel, and physical constraints on expansion of our facilities.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P32_S3	If we are unable to meet our customers' requirements and our competitors sufficiently expand production, we could lose customers and/or market share.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P32_S4	These losses could have an adverse effect on our financial condition and results of operations.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P32_S5	Also, capacity that we add during upturns in the business cycle may result in excess capacity during periods when demand for our products recede, resulting in inefficient use of capital which could also adversely affect us.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P33_S0	Our ability to compete effectively with other companies depends, in part, on our ability to maintain the proprietary nature of our technology.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P34_S0	Protection of intellectual property often involves complex legal and factual issues.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P34_S1	We will be able to protect our proprietary rights from unauthorized use by third parties only to the extent that our proprietary technologies are covered by valid and enforceable patents or are effectively maintained as trade secrets.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P34_S2	We have applied, and will continue to apply, for patents covering our technologies and products, as we deem appropriate.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P34_S3	However, our applications may not result in issued patents.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P34_S4	Also, our existing patents and any future patents may not be sufficiently broad to prevent others from practicing our technologies or from developing competing products.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P34_S5	Others may independently develop similar or alternative technologies, design around our patented technologies, or may challenge or seek to invalidate our patents.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P34_S6	Also, the legal system in certain countries in which we operate may not provide or may not continue to provide sufficient, intellectual property legal protections and remedies.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P35_S0	Litigation regarding patent and other intellectual property rights is prevalent in the electronic components industry, particularly the discrete semiconductor sector.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P35_S1	We have on occasion been notified that we may be infringing on patent and other intellectual property rights of others.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P35_S2	In addition, customers purchasing components from us have rights to indemnification under certain circumstances if such components violate the intellectual property rights of others.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P35_S3	Further, we have observed that in the current business environment, electronic component and semiconductor companies have become more aggressive in asserting and defending patent claims against competitors.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P35_S4	We will continue to vigorously defend our intellectual property rights, and may become party to disputes regarding patent licensing and cross patent licensing.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P35_S5	Although licenses are generally offered in such situations and we have successfully resolved these situations in the past, there can be no assurance that we will not be subject to future litigation alleging intellectual property rights infringement, or that we will be able to obtain licenses on acceptable terms.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P35_S6	An unfavorable outcome regarding one of these matters could have a material adverse effect on our business and results of operations.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P36_S0	We face intense competition in our business, and we market our products to an increasingly concentrated group of customers.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P37_S0	Our business is highly competitive worldwide, with low transportation costs and few import barriers.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P37_S1	We compete principally on the bases of product quality and reliability, availability, customer service, technological innovation, timely delivery, and price.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P37_S2	The electronic component industry has become increasingly concentrated and globalized in recent years and our major competitors, some of which are larger than us, have significant financial resources and technological capabilities.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P38_S0	Our customers have become increasingly concentrated in recent years, and as a result, their buying power has increased and they have had greater ability to negotiate favorable pricing and terms.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P38_S1	This trend has adversely affected our average selling prices, particularly for commodity components.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P39_S0	Our backlog is subject to customer cancellation.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P40_S0	Many of the orders that comprise our backlog may be canceled by our customers without penalty.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P40_S1	Our customers may on occasion double and triple order components from multiple sources to ensure timely delivery when demand exceeds global supply.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P40_S2	They often cancel orders when business is weak and inventories are excessive, a situation that we experienced during the recent period of economic slowdown.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P40_S3	Therefore, we cannot be certain that the amount of our backlog accurately reflects the level of orders that we will ultimately deliver.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P40_S4	Our results of operations could be adversely impacted if customers cancel a material portion of orders in our backlog.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P41_S0	Future changes in our environmental liability and compliance obligations may harm our ability to operate or increase our costs.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P42_S0	Our operations, products and/or product packaging are subject to environmental laws and regulations governing air emissions, wastewater discharges, the handling, disposal and remediation of hazardous substances, wastes and certain chemicals used or generated in our manufacturing processes, employee health and safety labeling or other notifications with respect to the content or other aspects of our processes, products or packaging, restrictions on the use of certain materials in or on design aspects of our products or product packaging, and responsibility for disposal of products or product packaging.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P42_S1	We establish reserves for specifically identified potential environmental liabilities.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P42_S2	Nevertheless, we have in the past and may in the future inherit certain pre-existing environmental liabilities, generally based on successor liability doctrines, or otherwise incur environmental liabilities.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P43_S0	We are involved in remediation programs and related litigation at various current and former properties and at third-party disposal sites both within and outside of the U.S., including involvement as a potentially responsible party at Superfund sites.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P43_S1	Although we have never been involved in any environmental matter that has had a material adverse impact on our overall operations, there can be no assurance that in connection with any past or future acquisition, future developments, including related to our remediation programs, or otherwise, we will not be obligated to address environmental matters that could have a material adverse impact on our results of operations.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P43_S2	In addition, more stringent environmental regulations may be enacted in the future, and we cannot presently determine the modifications, if any, in our operations that any such future regulations might require, or the cost of compliance with these regulations.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P44_S0	In order to resolve liabilities at various sites, we have entered into various administrative orders and consent decrees, some of which may be, under certain conditions, reopened or subject to renegotiation.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P45_S0	Our products are sold to or used in goods sold to the U.S. government and other governments.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P45_S1	By virtue of such sales, we are subject to various regulatory requirements and risks in the event of non-compliance.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P46_S0	We sell products under prime and subprime contracts with the U.S. government and other governments.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P46_S1	Many of these products are used in military applications.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P47_S0	Government contractors must comply with specific procurement regulations and other requirements.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P47_S1	These requirements, although customary in government contracts, impact our performance and compliance costs.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P47_S2	Failure to comply with these regulations and requirements could result in contract modifications or termination, and the assessment of penalties and fines, which could negatively impact our results of operations and financial condition.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P47_S3	Our failure to comply with these regulations and requirements could also lead to suspension or debarment, for cause, from government contracting or subcontracting for a period of time.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P47_S4	Among the causes for debarment are violations of various statutes, including those related to procurement integrity, export control, government security regulations, employment practices, protection of the environment, accuracy of records and the recording of costs, and foreign corruption.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P47_S5	The termination of a government contract as a result of any of these acts could have a negative impact on our results of operations and financial condition and could have a negative impact on our reputation and ability to procure other government contracts in the future.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P48_S0	We have qualified certain of our products under various military specifications approved and monitored by the United States Defense Electronic Supply Center and under certain European military specifications.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P48_S1	These products are assigned certain classification levels.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P48_S2	In order to maintain the classification level of a product, we must continuously perform tests on the products and the results of these tests must be reported to governmental agencies.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P48_S3	If a product fails to meet the requirements of the applicable classification level, its classification may be reduced to a lower level.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P48_S4	A decrease in the classification level for a product with a military application could have an adverse impact on the net revenues and earnings attributable to that product.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P49_S0	Our future success is substantially dependent on our ability to attract and retain highly qualified technical, managerial, marketing, finance, and administrative personnel.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P50_S0	Rapid changes in technologies, frequent new product introductions, and declining average selling prices over product life cycles require us to attract and retain highly qualified personnel to develop and manufacture products that feature technological innovations and bring them to market on a timely basis.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P50_S1	Our complex operations also require us to attract and retain highly qualified administrative personnel in functions such as legal, tax, accounting, financial reporting, auditing, and treasury.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P50_S2	The market for personnel with such qualifications is highly competitive.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P50_S3	While we have employment agreements with certain of our executives, we have not entered into employment agreements with all of our key personnel.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P51_S0	The loss of the services of or the failure to effectively recruit qualified personnel could have a material adverse effect on our business.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P52_S0	Interruptions in our information technology systems could adversely affect our business.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P53_S0	We rely on the efficient and uninterrupted operation of complex information technology systems and networks to operate our business.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P53_S1	Any significant system or network disruption, including, but not limited to, new system implementations, computer viruses, security breaches, facility issues or energy blackouts could have a material adverse impact on our operations and results of operations.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P53_S2	Such network disruption could result in a loss of the confidentiality of our intellectual property or the release of sensitive competitive information or customer or employee personal data.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P53_S3	Any loss of such information could harm our competitive position, result in a loss of customer confidence, and cause us to incur significant costs to remedy the damages caused by the disruptions or security breaches.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P53_S4	We have implemented protective measures to prevent against and limit the effects of system or network disruptions, but there can be no assurance that such measures will be sufficient to prevent or limit the damage from any future disruptions and any such disruption could have a material adverse impact on our business and results of operations.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P54_S0	Third-party service providers, such as foundries, subcontractors, distributors, and vendors have access to certain portions of our sensitive data.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P54_S1	In the event that these service providers do not properly safeguard our data that they hold, security breaches and loss of our data could result.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P54_S2	Any such loss of data by our third-party service providers could have a material adverse impact on our business and results of operations.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P55_S0	We are subject to the risks of political, economic, and military instability in countries outside the United States in which we operate.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P56_S0	We have substantial operations outside the United States, and approximately 76% of our revenues during 2016 were derived from sales to customers outside the United States.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P56_S1	Certain of our assets are located, and certain of our products are produced, in countries which are subject to risks of social, political, economic, and military instability.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P56_S2	This instability could result in wars, riots, nationalization of industry, currency fluctuation, and labor unrest.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P56_S3	These conditions could have an adverse impact on our ability to operate in these regions and, depending on the extent and severity of these conditions, could materially and adversely affect our overall financial condition, results of operations, and our ability to access our liquidity.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P57_S0	Our business has been in operation in Israel for 46 years, where we have substantial manufacturing operations.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P57_S1	Although we have never experienced any material interruption in our operations attributable to these factors, in spite of several Middle East crises, including wars, our financial condition and results of operations might be adversely affected if events were to occur in the Middle East that interfered with our operations in Israel.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P58_S0	Our global operations are subject to extensive anti-corruption laws and other regulations.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P59_S0	The U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and similar foreign anti-corruption laws generally prohibit companies and their intermediaries from making improper payments or providing anything of value to improperly influence foreign government officials for the purpose of obtaining or retaining business, or obtaining an unfair advantage.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P60_S0	Recent years have seen a substantial increase in the global enforcement of anti-corruption laws.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P60_S1	Our continued operation and expansion outside the United States, including in developing countries, could increase the risk of such violations or violations under other regulations relating to limitations on or licenses required for sales made to customers located in certain countries.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P60_S2	Violations of these laws may result in severe criminal or civil sanctions, could disrupt our business, and result in a material adverse effect on our reputation, business and results of operations or financial condition.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P61_S0	We attempt to improve profitability by controlling labor costs, but these activities could result in labor unrest or considerable expense.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P62_S0	Historically, our primary labor cost controlling strategy was to transfer manufacturing operations to countries with lower production costs, such as the Czech Republic, Hungary, India, Israel, Malaysia, Mexico, the People's Republic of China, and the Philippines.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P62_S1	We believe that our manufacturing footprint is suitable to serve our customers and end markets, while maintaining lower manufacturing costs.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P62_S2	We do not anticipate further transferring any significant existing operations to lower-labor-cost countries; however, acquired operations may be transferred to lower-labor-cost countries when integrated into Vishay.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P63_S0	Currently, our primary labor cost controlling strategy involves reducing hours and limiting the use of subcontractors and foundries when demand for our products decreases.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P63_S1	Shifting operations to lower-labor-cost countries, reducing hours, or limiting the use of subcontractors and foundries could result in production inefficiencies, higher costs, and/or strikes or other types of labor unrest.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P64_S0	We are subject to foreign currency exchange rate risks which may impact our results of operations.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P65_S0	We are exposed to foreign currency exchange rate risks, particularly due to market values of transactions in currencies other than the functional currencies of certain subsidiaries.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P65_S1	From time to time, we utilize forward contracts to hedge a portion of projected cash flows from these exposures.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P66_S0	Our significant foreign subsidiaries are located in Germany, Israel, and Asia.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P66_S1	We finance our operations in Europe and certain locations in Asia in local currencies.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P66_S2	Our operations in Israel and most significant locations in Asia are largely financed in U.S. dollars, but these subsidiaries also have significant transactions in local currencies.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P66_S3	Our exposure to foreign currency risk is mitigated to the extent that the costs incurred and the revenues earned in a particular currency offset one another.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P66_S4	Our exposure to foreign currency risk is more pronounced in situations where, for example, production labor costs are predominantly paid in local currencies while the sales revenue for those products is denominated in U.S. dollars.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P66_S5	This is particularly the case for products produced in Israel, the Czech Republic, and China.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P67_S0	A change in the mix of the currencies in which we transact our business could have a material effect on results of operations.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P67_S1	Furthermore, the timing of cash receipts and disbursements could have a material effect on our results of operations, particularly if there are significant changes in exchange rates in a short period of time.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P68_S0	Approximately 99% of our cash and cash equivalents and short-term investments balances were held by our non-U.S. subsidiaries.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P69_S0	We generate a significant amount of cash and profits from our non-U.S. subsidiaries.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P69_S1	As of December 31, 2016, $1,084.5 million of our cash and cash equivalents and short-term investments were held by subsidiaries outside of the United States.

103730_17_ITEM1A_P69_S3	Our U.S. subsidiaries have other operating cash needs.

103730_17_ITEM1A_P69_S5	If additional cash is needed to be repatriated to the United States, in addition to various foreign country laws regulating the exportation of the cash and profits, we would be subject to U.S. income taxes (subject to an adjustment for foreign tax credits), state income taxes, incremental foreign income taxes, and withholding taxes payable to various foreign jurisdictions.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P70_S0	The holders of our Class B common stock have effective voting control of our company.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P71_S0	We have two classes of common stock: common stock and Class B common stock.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P71_S1	The holders of common stock are entitled to one vote for each share held, while the holders of Class B common stock are entitled to 10 votes for each share held.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P71_S2	At December 31, 2016, the holders of Class B common stock held approximately 47.5% of the voting power of Vishay.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P71_S3	The ownership of Class B common stock is highly concentrated, and holders of Class B common stock effectively can cause the election of directors and approve other actions as stockholders.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P71_S4	As a result of the passing of our founder and former Executive Chairman, Dr. Felix Zandman, Mrs. Ruta Zandman (a member of our Board of Directors) controls the voting of, solely or on a shared basis with Marc Zandman (our Executive Chairman) and Ziv Shoshani (a member of our Board of Directors), approximately 89.5% of our Class B common stock and 42.6% of the total voting power of our capital stock as of December 31, 2016.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P72_S0	We have a staggered board of directors which could make a takeover of Vishay difficult.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P73_S0	Along with the voting power of the Class B common stock, our staggered board of directors might discourage, delay, or prevent a change in control of our company by a third party and could discourage proxy contests and make it more difficult for stockholders to elect directors and take other corporate actions.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P73_S1	Also, as a consequence of our staggered board, directors may not be removed without cause, even though a majority of stockholders may wish to do so.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P74_S0	Our reluctance to issue substantial additional shares in order not to dilute the interests of our existing stockholders could impede growth.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P75_S0	Our overall long-term business strategy has historically included a strong focus on acquisitions financed alternatively through cash on hand, the incurrence of indebtedness, and the issuance of equity, directly or indirectly by refinancing acquisition debt.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P75_S1	We may in the future be presented with attractive investment or strategic opportunities that, because of their size and our financial condition at the time, would require the issuance of substantial additional amounts of our common stock.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P75_S2	Some or all of our holders of Class B common stock may exert considerable influence over our policies, business and affairs, and in any corporate transaction or other matter, including those described above.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P75_S3	If such opportunities were to arise, our Board of Directors may consider the potentially dilutive effect on the interests and voting power of our existing stockholders, including our Class B stockholders.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P75_S4	Any resulting reluctance to issue additional shares could impede our future growth.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P76_S0	Our outstanding convertible debentures may impact the trading price of our common stock.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P77_S0	We believe that many investors in, and potential purchasers of, convertible debt instruments employ, or seek to employ, a convertible arbitrage strategy with respect to these instruments.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P77_S1	Investors that employ a convertible arbitrage strategy with respect to convertible debt instruments typically implement that strategy by selling short the common stock underlying the convertible instrument and dynamically adjusting their short position while they hold the instrument.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P77_S2	The implementation of this strategy by investors in our convertible debentures, as well as related market regulatory actions, could have a significant impact on the trading prices of our common stock, and the trading prices and liquidity of our convertible debentures.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P77_S3	The price of our common stock and our convertible debentures could also be affected by possible sales of our common stock by investors who view our convertible debentures as more attractive means of equity participation in us.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P78_S0	Vishay Precision Group is using the Vishay name under license from us, which could result in product and market confusion or the loss of certain of our rights to the Vishay name .
103730_17_ITEM1A_P79_S0	VPG has a worldwide, perpetual and royalty-free license from us to use the "Vishay" mark as part of its corporate name and in connection with the manufacture, sale, and marketing of the products and services that comprise its measurements and foil resistors businesses.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P79_S1	The license of the Vishay name to VPG is important because we anticipate that the success of VPG will depend in no small measure on the reputation of the Vishay brand for these products and services built over many years.
103730_17_ITEM1A_P79_S2	Nonetheless, there exists the risk that the use by VPG could cause confusion in the marketplace over the products of the two companies, that any negative publicity associated with a product or service of VPG following the spin-off could be mistakenly attributed to our company or that we could lose our own rights to the "Vishay" mark if we fail to impose sufficient controls on VPG's use of the mark.

103730_17_ITEM3_P1_S0	Vishay Polytech Co., Ltd. ("VPC"), a subsidiary of Vishay which was purchased from Holy Stone Enterprises Co., Ltd. ("Holy Stone") in June 2014, is a named defendant, among other manufacturers, in purported antitrust class action complaints in the United States and Canada.
103730_17_ITEM3_P1_S1	The complaints allege restraints of trade in aluminum and tantalum electrolytic capacitors, and in some cases, film capacitors, and seek injunctive relief and unspecified joint and several treble damages.
103730_17_ITEM3_P1_S2	Vishay Intertechnology, Inc. is a party to similar cases filed in Canada.
103730_17_ITEM3_P2_S0	Holy Stone has agreed to indemnify Vishay and VPC for losses, including penalties and expenses associated with the litigation and investigation described above.
103730_17_ITEM3_P2_S1	Notwithstanding this indemnity obligation, the Company and VPC intend to defend vigorously against the civil complaints.
103730_17_ITEM3_P3_S0	Since August 2015, the Company has been named as a defendant in a purported antitrust class action complaint in Canada alleging restraints of trade in resistors by the Company and other unaffiliated manufacturers, and seeking injunctive relief and unspecified joint and several treble damages.
103730_17_ITEM3_P3_S1	The Company intends to defend vigorously against the complaint.
103730_17_ITEM3_P4_S0	We are engaged in discussions with various parties regarding patent licensing and cross patent licensing issues.
103730_17_ITEM3_P4_S1	In addition, we have observed that in the current business environment, electronic component and semiconductor companies have become more aggressive in asserting and defending patent claims against competitors.
103730_17_ITEM3_P4_S2	We are a party to disputes alleging infringement of third-party patents.
103730_17_ITEM3_P4_S3	We will continue to vigorously defend our intellectual property rights.
103730_17_ITEM3_P5_S0	When we believe other companies are misappropriating our intellectual property rights, we vigorously enforce those rights through legal action, and we intend to continue to do so.
103730_17_ITEM3_P5_S1	During the past few years, we settled several suits which we had initiated to enforce our intellectual property rights.
103730_17_ITEM3_P5_S2	We are receiving royalties on sales of these companies' products which use our technology.
103730_17_ITEM3_P5_S3	We are continuing to assert our legal rights against other parties which we believe are misappropriating our intellectual property rights.

103730_17_ITEM7_P0_S0	Vishay Intertechnology, Inc. is a global manufacturer and supplier of semiconductors and passive components, including power MOSFETs, power integrated circuits, transistors, diodes, optoelectronic components, resistors, capacitors, and inductors.
103730_17_ITEM7_P0_S1	Discrete semiconductors and passive components manufactured by Vishay are used in virtually all types of electronic products, including those in the industrial, computing, automotive, consumer electronic products, telecommunications, power supplies, military/aerospace, and medical industries.
103730_17_ITEM7_P1_S0	We operate in five product segments, MOSFETs, Diodes, Optoelectronic Components, Resistors Inductors, and Capacitors.
103730_17_ITEM7_P2_S0	Since 1985, we have pursued a business strategy of growth through focused research and development and acquisitions.
103730_17_ITEM7_P2_S1	Through this strategy, we have grown to become one of the world's largest manufacturers of discrete semiconductors and passive components.
103730_17_ITEM7_P2_S2	We expect to continue our strategy of acquisitions while also maintaining a prudent capital structure.
103730_17_ITEM7_P3_S0	We are focused on enhancing stockholder value and improving earnings per share.
103730_17_ITEM7_P3_S1	In addition to our growth plan, we also have opportunistically repurchased our stock.
103730_17_ITEM7_P3_S2	In 2014, our Board of Directors instituted a quarterly dividend payment program and declared the first cash dividend in the history of Vishay.
103730_17_ITEM7_P3_S3	In December 2015, we amended our credit facility to increase our ability to repurchase shares of stock or pay cash dividends.
103730_17_ITEM7_P3_S4	Although we have no current plans, we will continue to evaluate attractive stock repurchase opportunities.
103730_17_ITEM7_P3_S5	On May 2, 2016, our Board of Directors approved a stock repurchase plan, authorizing us to repurchase, in the aggregate, up to $100 million of our outstanding common stock.
103730_17_ITEM7_P3_S6	The stock repurchase plan will expire on May 2, 2017.
103730_17_ITEM7_P3_S7	The stock repurchase plan does not obligate us to acquire any particular amount of common stock, and it may be terminated or suspended at the Company's direction in accordance with the plan.
103730_17_ITEM7_P3_S8	The Company repurchased 1,752,454 shares of stock for $23.2 million since the inception of the plan.
103730_17_ITEM7_P3_S9	We will continue to evaluate attractive stock repurchase opportunities.
103730_17_ITEM7_P4_S0	As part of the amendment and restatement of the revolving credit facility in December 2015, we completed an evaluation of our anticipated domestic cash needs over the next several years and our most efficient use of liquidity, with consideration of the amount of cash that can be repatriated to the U.S. efficiently with lesser withholding taxes in foreign jurisdictions.
103730_17_ITEM7_P4_S1	As a result of that evaluation, during the fourth quarter of 2015, we recognized income tax expense of $164.0 million, including U.S. federal and state income taxes, incremental foreign income taxes, and withholding taxes payable to foreign jurisdictions, on $300 million of foreign earnings which we expect to repatriate to the U.S. over the next several years.
103730_17_ITEM7_P4_S2	We repatriated $46 million to the U.S. in 2016 pursuant to this plan.

103730_17_ITEM7_P5_S1	Our revenues are dependent on end markets that are impacted by consumer and industrial demand, and our operating results can be adversely affected by reduced demand in those global markets.
103730_17_ITEM7_P6_S0	For several years, we implemented aggressive cost reduction programs.

103730_17_ITEM7_P22_S0	We utilize several financial metrics to evaluate the performance and assess the future direction of our business.
103730_17_ITEM7_P22_S1	These key financial measures and metrics include net revenues, gross profit margin, operating margin, segment operating income, end-of-period backlog, and the book-to-bill ratio.
103730_17_ITEM7_P22_S2	We also monitor changes in our inventory turnover and our or publicly available average selling prices ("ASP").
103730_17_ITEM7_P23_S0	Gross profit margin is computed as gross profit as a percentage of net revenues.
103730_17_ITEM7_P23_S1	Gross profit is generally net revenues less costs of products sold, but also deducts certain other period costs, particularly losses on purchase commitments and inventory write-downs.
103730_17_ITEM7_P23_S2	Losses on purchase commitments and inventory write-downs have the impact of reducing gross profit margin in the period of the charge, but result in improved gross profit margins in subsequent periods by reducing costs of products sold as inventory is used.
103730_17_ITEM7_P24_S0	Gross profit margin is clearly a function of net revenues, but also reflects our cost management programs and our ability to contain fixed costs.
103730_17_ITEM7_P25_S0	Operating margin is computed as gross profit less operating expenses as a percentage of net revenues.
103730_17_ITEM7_P25_S1	We evaluate business segment performance on segment operating margin.
103730_17_ITEM7_P25_S2	Only dedicated, direct selling, general, and administrative expenses of the segments are included in the calculation of segment operating income.
103730_17_ITEM7_P25_S3	Segment operating margin is computed as operating income less items such as restructuring and severance costs, asset write-downs, goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible asset impairments, inventory write-downs, gain or losses on purchase commitments, global operations, sales and marketing, information systems, finance and administrative groups, and other items, expressed as a percentage of net revenues.
103730_17_ITEM7_P25_S4	We believe that evaluating segment performance excluding such items is meaningful because it provides insight with respect to intrinsic operating results of the segment.
103730_17_ITEM7_P26_S0	Operating margin is clearly a function of net revenues, but also reflects our cost management programs and our ability to contain fixed costs.
103730_17_ITEM7_P27_S0	End-of-period backlog is one indicator of future revenues.
103730_17_ITEM7_P27_S1	We include in our backlog only open orders that we expect to ship in the next twelve months.
103730_17_ITEM7_P27_S2	If demand falls below customers' forecasts, or if customers do not control their inventory effectively, they may cancel or reschedule the shipments that are included in our backlog, in many instances without the payment of any penalty.
103730_17_ITEM7_P27_S3	Therefore, the backlog is not necessarily indicative of the results to be expected for future periods.
103730_17_ITEM7_P28_S0	An important indicator of demand in our industry is the book-to-bill ratio, which is the ratio of the amount of product ordered during a period as compared with the product that we ship during that period.
103730_17_ITEM7_P28_S1	A book-to-bill ratio that is greater than one indicates that our backlog is building and that we are likely to see increasing revenues in future periods.
103730_17_ITEM7_P28_S2	Conversely, a book-to-bill ratio that is less than one is an indicator of declining demand and may foretell declining revenues.
103730_17_ITEM7_P29_S0	We focus on our inventory turnover as a measure of how well we are managing our inventory.
103730_17_ITEM7_P30_S0	We define inventory turnover for a financial reporting period as our costs of products sold for the four fiscal quarters ending on the last day of the reporting period divided by our average inventory (computed using each fiscal quarter-end balance) for this same period.
103730_17_ITEM7_P30_S1	A higher level of inventory turnover reflects more efficient use of our capital.
103730_17_ITEM7_P31_S0	Pricing in our industry can be volatile.
103730_17_ITEM7_P31_S1	Using our and publicly available data, we analyze trends and changes in average selling prices to evaluate likely future pricing.
103730_17_ITEM7_P32_S0	The erosion of average selling prices of established products is typical for semiconductor products.
103730_17_ITEM7_P32_S1	We attempt to offset this deterioration with ongoing cost reduction activities and new product introductions.
103730_17_ITEM7_P32_S2	Our specialty passive components are more resistant to average selling price erosion.
103730_17_ITEM7_P33_S0	All pricing is subject to governing market conditions.
103730_17_ITEM7_P34_S0	The quarter-to-quarter trends in these financial metrics can also be an important indicator of the likely direction of our business.
