103730_17_ITEM15_P359_S0	Vishay is a global manufacturer and supplier of electronic components.
103730_17_ITEM15_P359_S1	Vishay operates, and its chief operating decision maker makes strategic and operating decisions with regards to assessing performance and allocating resources based on, five reporting segments: MOSFETs, Diodes, Optoelectronic Components, Resistors Inductors, and Capacitors.
103730_17_ITEM15_P359_S2	These segments represent groupings of product lines based on their functionality:
103730_17_ITEM15_P360_S0	Metal oxide semiconductor field effect transistors ("MOSFETs") function as solid state switches to control power.
103730_17_ITEM15_P361_S0	Diodes route, regulate, and block radio frequency, analog, and power signals; protect systems from surges or electrostatic discharge damage; or provide electromagnetic interference filtering.
103730_17_ITEM15_P362_S0	Optoelectronic components emit light, detect light, or do both.
103730_17_ITEM15_P363_S0	Resistors and inductors both impede electric current.
103730_17_ITEM15_P364_S0	Resistors are basic components used in all forms of electronic circuitry to adjust and regulate levels of voltage and current.
103730_17_ITEM15_P365_S0	Inductors use an internal magnetic field to change alternating current phase and resist alternating current.
103730_17_ITEM15_P366_S0	Capacitors store energy and discharge it when needed.
103730_17_ITEM15_P367_S0	Vishay's reporting segments generate substantially all of their revenue from product sales to the industrial, automotive, telecommunications, computing, consumer products, power supplies, military and aerospace, and medical end markets.
103730_17_ITEM15_P367_S1	A small portion of revenues are from royalties.
103730_17_ITEM15_P368_S0	The Company evaluates business segment performance on operating income, exclusive of certain items ("segment operating income").
103730_17_ITEM15_P368_S1	Only dedicated, direct selling, general, and administrative expenses of the segments are included in the calculation of segment operating income.
103730_17_ITEM15_P368_S2	The Company's calculation of segment operating income excludes such selling, general, and administrative costs as global operations, sales and marketing, information systems, finance and administration groups, as well as restructuring and severance costs, goodwill and long-lived asset impairment charges, and other items.
103730_17_ITEM15_P368_S3	Management believes that evaluating segment performance excluding such items is meaningful because it provides insight with respect to intrinsic operating results of the Company.
103730_17_ITEM15_P368_S4	These items represent reconciling items between segment operating income and consolidated operating income.
103730_17_ITEM15_P369_S0	Business segment assets are the owned or allocated assets used by each business.
103730_17_ITEM15_P370_S0	The Company also regularly evaluates gross profit by segment to assist in the analysis of consolidated gross profit.
103730_17_ITEM15_P370_S1	The Company considers segment operating income to be the more important metric because it more fully captures the business operations of the segments.

103730_17_ITEM15_P380_S1	Accordingly, the debentures are included in the diluted earnings per share computation using the "treasury stock method" (similar to options and warrants) rather than the "if converted method" otherwise required for convertible debt.
103730_17_ITEM15_P380_S2	Under the "treasury stock method," Vishay calculates the number of shares issuable under the terms of the debentures based on the average market price of Vishay common stock during the period, and that number is included in the total diluted shares figure for the period.
103730_17_ITEM15_P380_S3	If the average market price is less than $13.14, no shares are included in the diluted earnings per share computation for the convertible senior debentures due 2040, if the average market price is less than $18.00, no shares are included in the diluted earnings per share computation for the convertible senior debentures due 2041, and if the average market price is less than $11.17, no shares are included in the diluted earnings per share computation for the convertible senior debentures due 2042.

103730_17_ITEM15_P382_S0	The fair value measurement accounting guidance establishes a valuation hierarchy of the inputs used to measure fair value.
103730_17_ITEM15_P382_S1	This hierarchy prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value into three broad levels.
103730_17_ITEM15_P382_S2	The following is a brief description of those three levels:
103730_17_ITEM15_P383_S0	Level 1: Observable inputs such as quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
103730_17_ITEM15_P384_S0	Level 2: Inputs other than quoted prices that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly or indirectly.
103730_17_ITEM15_P384_S1	These include quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities in active markets and quoted prices for identical or similar assets or liabilities in markets that are not active.
103730_17_ITEM15_P385_S0	Level 3: Unobservable inputs that reflect the Company's own assumptions.
103730_17_ITEM15_P386_S0	An asset or liability's classification within the hierarchy is determined based on the lowest level input that is significant to the fair value measurement.

103730_17_ITEM15_P402_S0	The Company uses a derivative valuation model to derive the value of the embedded derivative features.
103730_17_ITEM15_P402_S1	Key inputs into this valuation model are the Company's current stock price, risk-free interest rates, the stock dividend yield, the stock volatility, and the debentures' credit spread over London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR).
103730_17_ITEM15_P402_S2	The first three aforementioned inputs are based on observable market data and are considered Level 2 inputs while the last two aforementioned inputs are unobservable and thus require management's judgment and are considered Level 3 inputs.
103730_17_ITEM15_P403_S0	The fair value measurement is considered a Level 3 measurement within the fair value hierarchy.

(the "Company") on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2016 as filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on the date hereof (the "Report"), I, Lori Lipcaman, Chief Financial Officer of the Company, certify, pursuant to 18 U.S.C. section 1350, as adopted pursuant to section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, that:

103730_18_ITEM1_P0_S0	Vishay Intertechnology, Inc. ("Vishay," the "Company," "we," "us," or "our") is a leading global manufacturer and supplier of discrete semiconductors and passive components.
103730_18_ITEM1_P0_S1	Semiconductors include MOSFETs, diodes, and optoelectronic components.
103730_18_ITEM1_P0_S2	Passive components include resistive products, capacitors, and inductors.
103730_18_ITEM1_P0_S3	Discrete semiconductors and passive components are essential elements of virtually every type of electronic circuit.
103730_18_ITEM1_P0_S4	They support the microprocessor chips and other integrated circuits ("ICs") that coordinate and control the functions of electronic devices and equipment.
103730_18_ITEM1_P0_S5	We offer our customers "one-stop shop" access to one of the most comprehensive electronic component product lines of any manufacturer in the United States, Europe, and Asia.
103730_18_ITEM1_P1_S0	Our semiconductor components are used for a wide variety of functions, including power control, power conversion, power management, signal switching, signal routing, signal blocking, signal amplification, two-way data transfer, one-way remote control, and circuit isolation.
103730_18_ITEM1_P1_S1	Our passive components are used to restrict current flow, suppress voltage increases, store and discharge energy, control alternating current ("AC") and voltage, filter out unwanted electrical signals, and perform other functions.
103730_18_ITEM1_P1_S2	Our components are used in virtually every type of product that contains electronic circuitry, in the industrial, computing, automotive, consumer, telecommunications, power supplies, military, aerospace, and medical markets.
103730_18_ITEM1_P2_S0	In the 1950's, the late Dr. Felix Zandman, Vishay's founder, was issued patents for his PhotoStress coatings and instruments, used to reveal and measure the distribution of stresses in structures such as airplanes and cars under live load conditions.
103730_18_ITEM1_P2_S1	His research in this area led him to develop Bulk Metal foil resistors ultra-precise, ultra-stable resistors with performance far beyond any other resistor available to date.
103730_18_ITEM1_P3_S0	In 1962, Dr. Zandman, with a loan from the late Alfred P. Slaner, founded Vishay to develop and manufacture Bulk Metal foil resistors.
103730_18_ITEM1_P3_S1	Concurrently, J.E. Starr developed foil resistance strain gages, which also became part of Vishay.
103730_18_ITEM1_P3_S2	Throughout the 1960's and 1970's, Vishay established itself as a technical and market leader in foil resistors, PhotoStress products, and strain gages.
103730_18_ITEM1_P3_S3	These products were included with the measurements and foil resistor businesses that we spun off into an independent, publicly-traded company named Vishay Precision Group, Inc. ("Vishay Precision Group" or "VPG") through a tax-free stock dividend to our stockholders on July 6, 2010.
103730_18_ITEM1_P4_S0	In 1985, Vishay began to expand its product line through various strategic acquisitions, including the resistor companies Dale Electronics, Draloric Electronic, and Sfernice.
103730_18_ITEM1_P4_S1	In the early 1990's, Vishay applied its acquisition strategy to the capacitor market, with the major acquisitions of Sprague Electric, Roederstein, and Vitramon.
103730_18_ITEM1_P4_S2	In 2002, Vishay acquired BCcomponents, the former passive components business of Philips Electronics and Beyschlag, which greatly enhanced Vishay's global market position in passive components.
103730_18_ITEM1_P4_S3	Over the years, we have made several smaller passive components acquisitions to gain market share, penetrate different geographic markets, enhance new product development, round out our product lines, or grow our high margin niche businesses.
103730_18_ITEM1_P4_S4	These include Electro-Films, Cera-Mite, and Spectrol in 2000; Tansitor and North American Capacitor Company (Mallory) in 2001; the thin film interconnect business of Aeroflex in 2004; Phoenix do Brasil in 2006; the wet tantalum capacitor business of KEMET Corporation in 2008; the resistor businesses of Huntington Electric in 2011; HiRel Systems in 2012; MCB Industrie in 2013; Holy Stone Polytech in 2014; and UltraSource in 2018.
103730_18_ITEM1_P5_S0	In the late 1990's, Vishay began expanding its product lines to include discrete semiconductors.
103730_18_ITEM1_P6_S0	In 1998, Vishay acquired the Semiconductor Business Group of TEMIC, which included Telefunken and an 80.4% interest in Siliconix, producers of MOSFETs, RF transistors, diodes, optoelectronics, and power and analog switching integrated circuits.
103730_18_ITEM1_P7_S0	Vishay's next semiconductor acquisition came in 2001, with the purchase of the infrared components business of Infineon Technologies, which was followed the same year by Vishay's acquisition of General Semiconductor, a leading global manufacturer of rectifiers and diodes.
103730_18_ITEM1_P7_S1	In 2005, Vishay made a successful tender offer for the minority interest in Siliconix.
103730_18_ITEM1_P7_S2	In 2007, Vishay acquired the Power Control Systems business of International Rectifier, further enhancing our product offerings.
103730_18_ITEM1_P7_S3	These acquisitions propelled Vishay into the top ranks of discrete semiconductor manufacturers.
103730_18_ITEM1_P7_S4	In 2014, Vishay increased its position in optoelectronic sensors through its acquisition of Capella, a fabless IC design company specializing in optoelectronic components.

103730_18_ITEM1_P32_S0	Our products can be divided into two general classes: semiconductors and passive components.
103730_18_ITEM1_P32_S1	Semiconductors are sometimes referred to as "active components" because they require power to function whereas passive components do not require power to function.
103730_18_ITEM1_P32_S2	Our semiconductor and passive components products are further categorized based on their functionality for financial reporting purposes.
103730_18_ITEM1_P32_S3	See Note 15 to our consolidated financial statements for additional information on revenues, income, and total assets by segment.
103730_18_ITEM1_P33_S0	Our semiconductor products include metal oxide semiconductor field-effect transistors ("MOSFETs"), Diodes, and Optoelectronic Components.
103730_18_ITEM1_P34_S0	Semiconductors are typically used to perform functions such as switching, amplifying, rectifying, routing, or transmitting electrical signals, power conversion, and power management.
103730_18_ITEM1_P35_S0	MOSFETs function as solid state switches to control power.
103730_18_ITEM1_P36_S0	Our MOSFETs business includes both the commodity and non-commodity markets in which we believe that we enjoy a good reputation and strong brand recognition (Siliconix).
103730_18_ITEM1_P37_S0	MOSFETs applications include mobile phones, notebook and desktop computers, tablet computers, digital cameras, televisions, DC/DC and AC/DC switch mode power supplies, solar inverters, automotive and industrial systems.
103730_18_ITEM1_P37_S1	We are a leader in low-voltage TrenchFET MOSFETs and also offer high-voltage MOSFETs.
103730_18_ITEM1_P37_S2	Our MOSFETs product line includes low- and medium-voltage TrenchFET MOSFETs, high-voltage planar MOSFETs, high voltage Super Junction MOSFETs, power integrated circuits (power ICs), and integrated function power devices.
103730_18_ITEM1_P37_S3	We are one of the technology leaders in MOSFETs, with a tradition of innovation in wafer design, packaging, and performance.
103730_18_ITEM1_P38_S0	Diodes route, regulate, and block radio frequency, analog, and power signals; protect systems from surges or electrostatic discharge damage; or provide electromagnetic interference filtering.
103730_18_ITEM1_P39_S0	Our Diodes business is a solid business with a strong market presence in both the commodity and non-commodity markets.
103730_18_ITEM1_P39_S1	The products that comprise our Diodes business represent our broadest product line and include rectifiers, small signal diodes, protection diodes, thyristors/SCRs and power modules.
103730_18_ITEM1_P40_S0	The primary application of rectifiers, found inside the power supplies of virtually all electronic equipment, is to derive DC power from the AC supply.
103730_18_ITEM1_P40_S1	Vishay is the worldwide leader in rectifiers, having a broad technology base and a good position in automotive, industrial, computing and consumer markets.
103730_18_ITEM1_P40_S2	Our rectifier innovations include TMBS using Trench MOS barrier Schottky rectifier technology, which reduces power loss and improves the efficiency of end systems and eSMP , the best in class high-current density surface mount packages.
103730_18_ITEM1_P41_S0	Our wide selection of small signal diodes consist of the following functions: switching, tuning, band-switching, RF attenuation and voltage regulation (Zener).
103730_18_ITEM1_P41_S1	They are available in various glass and plastic packaging options and generally are used in electronic circuits, where small currents and high frequencies are involved.
103730_18_ITEM1_P42_S0	Vishay is also one of the market leaders for TVS (transient voltage suppressor) diodes.
103730_18_ITEM1_P42_S1	The portfolio of protection diodes includes ESD protection and EMI filter.
103730_18_ITEM1_P43_S0	Our thyristors or SCR (silicon-controlled rectifiers) are very popular in the industrial high-voltage AC power control applications.
103730_18_ITEM1_P43_S1	The fast growing markets of solar inverter and HEV/EV are the focus of our power modules business (IGBT or MOSFET modules).
103730_18_ITEM1_P43_S2	These modules can be customized to fit in different customer design requirements.
103730_18_ITEM1_P44_S0	Optoelectronic components emit light, detect light, or do both.
103730_18_ITEM1_P45_S0	Our Optoelectronic Components business has a strong market presence in both the commodity and non-commodity markets.
103730_18_ITEM1_P45_S1	Our broad range of standard and customer specific optoelectronic components includes infrared ("IR") emitters and detectors, IR remote control receivers, optocouplers, solid-state relays, optical sensors, light-emitting diodes ("LEDs"), 7-segment displays, and IR data transceiver modules (IrDA ).
103730_18_ITEM1_P45_S2	Our IR remote control receivers are designed for use in infrared remote control, data transmission, and light barrier applications in end products including televisions, set-top boxes, notebook computers, and audio systems.
103730_18_ITEM1_P45_S3	We are the leading manufacturer of IR remote control receivers.
103730_18_ITEM1_P45_S4	Our optocouplers electrically isolate input and output signals.
103730_18_ITEM1_P45_S5	Uses include switch-mode power supplies, consumer electronics, telecommunications equipment, solar inverters, and industrial systems.
103730_18_ITEM1_P46_S0	Our IR data transceiver modules are used for short range, two-way, high-speed, and secure wireless data transfer between electronic devices such as home medical appliances, mobile phones, industrial data loggers, and metering.
103730_18_ITEM1_P46_S1	Our optical sensors product line was considerably strengthened by our acquisition of Capella in 2014.
103730_18_ITEM1_P46_S2	Our optical sensors products include ambient light sensors, optical encoders, integrated photodiode and I/V amplifiers, proximity sensors, color sensors, and UV sensors.
103730_18_ITEM1_P46_S3	Applications include telecommunications, mobile phones, smartphone, handheld devices, digital cameras, laptops, desktop computers, LED backlighting, office automation equipment, household electrical appliance and automotive electronics.
103730_18_ITEM1_P46_S4	Our LEDs are designed for backlighting and illumination in automotive and other applications.
103730_18_ITEM1_P46_S5	Our LEDs include ultra-bright as well as small surface-mount packages, with products available in all standard colors including white.
103730_18_ITEM1_P47_S0	Our passive components include resistors, capacitors, and magnetics such as inductors and transformers.
103730_18_ITEM1_P47_S1	Passive components are used to store electrical charges, to limit or resist electrical current, and to help in filtering, surge suppression, measurement, timing, and tuning applications.
103730_18_ITEM1_P48_S0	Resistors and inductors both impede electric current.
103730_18_ITEM1_P49_S0	Resistors are basic components used in all forms of electronic circuitry to adjust and regulate levels of voltage and current.
103730_18_ITEM1_P50_S0	Inductors use an internal magnetic field to change alternating current phase and resist alternating current.
103730_18_ITEM1_P50_S1	Our Resistors and Inductors business is our original business.
103730_18_ITEM1_P50_S2	We maintain the broadest portfolio of resistor products worldwide.
103730_18_ITEM1_P50_S3	Under current market conditions, the business is solid, predictable, and growing at relatively stable selling prices.
103730_18_ITEM1_P50_S4	We are a market leader with a strong technology base, many specialty products, and strong brand recognition (such as our Dale, Draloric, Beyschlag, Sfernice, and HiRel Systems brands).
103730_18_ITEM1_P50_S5	We focus on higher value markets in specialized industries, while maintaining a complete portfolio of commodity products.
103730_18_ITEM1_P50_S6	We do not aim to be the volume leader in commodity markets.
103730_18_ITEM1_P51_S0	Resistors vary widely in precision and cost, and are manufactured from numerous materials and in many forms.
103730_18_ITEM1_P51_S1	Linear resistive components are classified as variable or fixed, depending on whether or not their resistance is adjustable.
103730_18_ITEM1_P52_S0	Non-linear resistors function by varying in resistance under influence of temperature (thermistors) or voltage (varistors).
103730_18_ITEM1_P52_S1	They can be used in temperature-measuring applications or as current or voltage-limiting devices.
103730_18_ITEM1_P53_S0	We manufacture virtually all types of fixed resistors, both in discrete and network forms, as well as many variable types.
103730_18_ITEM1_P54_S0	Vishay resistor innovations include Power Metal Strip technology.
103730_18_ITEM1_P54_S1	These resistors feature very low resistance and are used to measure changes in current flow (current sensing) or divert current flow (shunting).
103730_18_ITEM1_P55_S0	Inductor applications include controlling AC current and voltage, filtering out unwanted electrical signals, and energy storage.
103730_18_ITEM1_P55_S1	Vishay inductor innovations include IHLP low-profile, high-current inductor technology with industry-leading specifications, which is patented and generates royalty revenue.
103730_18_ITEM1_P55_S2	Our low-profile, high-current inductors save circuit board space and power in voltage regulator module ("VRM") and DC to DC converter applications.
103730_18_ITEM1_P55_S3	In addition, we are a worldwide leader in custom magnetic solutions focusing on high performance and high reliability.
103730_18_ITEM1_P55_S4	This field has been substantially strengthened, with the 2012 acquisition of HiRel Systems, broadening our portfolio, customer, and market segment reach.
103730_18_ITEM1_P56_S0	Capacitors store energy and discharge it when needed.
103730_18_ITEM1_P57_S0	Our Capacitors business consists of a broad range of reliable, high-quality products.
103730_18_ITEM1_P57_S1	We have a strong presence worldwide in specialty markets based on our product performance and reliability and strong brand recognition (including our Sprague, Vitramon, Roederstein, BCcomponents, and ESTA brands).
103730_18_ITEM1_P57_S2	We focus on higher value markets in specialized industries, while maintaining a complete portfolio of commodity products.
103730_18_ITEM1_P57_S3	We do not aim to be the volume leader in commodity markets.
103730_18_ITEM1_P58_S0	Capacitors are used in almost all electronic circuits.
103730_18_ITEM1_P58_S1	They store energy and discharge it when needed.
103730_18_ITEM1_P59_S0	Important applications for capacitors include electronic filtering for linear and switching power supplies; decoupling and bypass of electronic signals for integrated circuits and circuit boards; and frequency control, timing and conditioning of electronic signals for a broad range of applications.
103730_18_ITEM1_P60_S0	We manufacture products based on all major capacitor technologies: tantalum (molded chip tantalum, coated chip tantalum, solid through-hole tantalum, wet tantalum, and polymer), ceramic (multilayer chip and ceramic disc), film, power, heavy-current, and aluminum electrolytic.
103730_18_ITEM1_P60_S1	Our capacitors range from tiny surface-mount devices for hearing aids and mobile devices to large power correction capacitors used in renewable energy, heavy industry, and electrical power grids.
103730_18_ITEM1_P60_S2	We are a recognized technology leader in many product ranges, securing our strong position in military and medical markets, and in a wide range of industrial and automotive applications.
103730_18_ITEM1_P60_S3	Our wet tantalum and MicroTan technologies are market leaders.
103730_18_ITEM1_P61_S0	We have qualified certain of our products under various military specifications approved and monitored by United States government agencies, and under certain European military specifications.
103730_18_ITEM1_P61_S1	Qualification levels are based in part upon the rate of failure of products.
103730_18_ITEM1_P61_S2	In order to maintain the classification level of a product, we must continuously perform tests on the product and the results of these tests must be reported to the government agencies.
103730_18_ITEM1_P61_S3	If the product fails to meet the requirements for the applicable classification level, the product's classification may be reduced to a lower level.
103730_18_ITEM1_P62_S0	During the time that the classification level is reduced for a product with military application, net revenues and earnings attributable to that product may be adversely affected.
103730_18_ITEM1_P63_S0	In order to better serve our customers, we maintain production facilities in locations where we market the bulk of our products, such as the United States, Germany, and Asia.
103730_18_ITEM1_P63_S1	To optimize production efficiencies, we have whenever practicable established manufacturing facilities in countries, such as the Czech Republic, Hungary, India, Israel, Malaysia, Mexico, the People's Republic of China, and the Philippines, where we can benefit from lower labor and tax costs and also benefit from various government incentives, including grants and tax relief.
103730_18_ITEM1_P64_S0	One of our most sophisticated manufacturing operations is the production of power semiconductor components.
103730_18_ITEM1_P64_S1	This manufacturing process involves two phases of production: wafer fabrication and assembly (or packaging).
103730_18_ITEM1_P65_S0	Wafer fabrication subjects silicon wafers to various thermal, metallurgical, and chemical process steps that change their electrical and physical properties.
103730_18_ITEM1_P65_S1	These process steps define cells or circuits within numerous individual devices (termed "dies" or "chips") on each wafer.
103730_18_ITEM1_P65_S2	Assembly is the sequence of production steps that divides the wafer into individual chips and encloses the chips in structures (termed "packages") that make them usable in a circuit.
103730_18_ITEM1_P65_S3	Both wafer fabrication and assembly phases incorporate wafer level and device level electrical testing to ensure that device design integrity has been achieved.
103730_18_ITEM1_P66_S0	In the United States, our manufacturing facilities are located in California, Minnesota, Nebraska, New Hampshire, New York, Rhode Island, South Dakota, Vermont, and Wisconsin.
103730_18_ITEM1_P66_S1	In Asia, our main manufacturing facilities are located in the People's Republic of China, the Republic of China (Taiwan), India, and Malaysia.
103730_18_ITEM1_P66_S2	In Europe, our main manufacturing facilities are located in Germany, France, and the Czech Republic.
103730_18_ITEM1_P66_S3	We have substantial manufacturing facilities in Israel.
103730_18_ITEM1_P66_S4	We also have manufacturing facilities in Austria, Dominican Republic, Japan, Hungary, Italy, Mexico, Portugal, and the Philippines.
103730_18_ITEM1_P66_S5	Over the past several years, we have invested substantial resources to increase the efficiency of our plants, which we believe will further reduce production costs.
103730_18_ITEM1_P67_S0	All of our manufacturing operations have received ISO 9001 certification.
103730_18_ITEM1_P68_S0	ISO 9001 is a comprehensive set of quality program standards developed by the International Standards Organization.
103730_18_ITEM1_P69_S0	See Note 15 to our consolidated financial statements for financial information by geographic area.
103730_18_ITEM1_P70_S0	Although most materials incorporated in our products are available from a number of sources, certain materials, including plastics and metals, are available only from a relatively limited number of suppliers or are subject to significant price volatility.
103730_18_ITEM1_P71_S0	Silicon wafers are the most important raw material for the manufacturing of our semiconductor products.
103730_18_ITEM1_P72_S0	Silicon wafers are manufactured from high-purity silicon, a metalloid.
103730_18_ITEM1_P72_S1	There have at times been industry-wide shortages of high-purity silicon resulting primarily from growing demand of the electronic component and solar power industries, and limited growth in high-purity silicon manufacturing capacities.
103730_18_ITEM1_P72_S2	Shifts in demand for high-purity silicon and in turn, silicon wafers, have resulted in significant fluctuation in prices of silicon wafers.
103730_18_ITEM1_P73_S0	We are a major consumer of the world's annual production of tantalum, a metal used in the manufacturing of tantalum capacitors.
103730_18_ITEM1_P73_S1	There are few suppliers that process tantalum ore into capacitor grade tantalum powder.
103730_18_ITEM1_P74_S0	Certain materials, in addition to tantalum and including tin, tungsten, and gold are available only from a relatively limited number of suppliers, the source for which may be in the Democratic Republic of the Congo ("DRC") or an adjoining country.
103730_18_ITEM1_P74_S1	We are working toward the elimination of materials that directly or indirectly finance or benefit armed groups in the DRC or adjoining countries from our supply chain.
103730_18_ITEM1_P75_S0	Palladium, a metal used to produce multi-layer ceramic capacitors, is currently found primarily in South Africa and Russia.
103730_18_ITEM1_P75_S1	Palladium is a commodity metal that is subject to price volatility.
103730_18_ITEM1_P75_S2	We periodically enter into short-term commitments to purchase palladium.
103730_18_ITEM1_P76_S0	Certain metals used in the manufacture of our products, such as copper, are traded on active markets, and can be subject to significant price volatility.
103730_18_ITEM1_P76_S1	Our policy is to enter into short-term commitments to purchase defined portions of annual consumption of these metals if market prices decline below budget.
103730_18_ITEM1_P77_S0	We manufacture both standardized products and those designed and produced to meet customer specifications.
103730_18_ITEM1_P77_S1	We maintain an inventory of standardized components and monitor the backlog of outstanding orders for our products.
103730_18_ITEM1_P78_S0	We include in our backlog only open orders that we expect to ship in the next twelve months.
103730_18_ITEM1_P79_S0	Many of our customers encounter uncertain and changing demand for their products.
103730_18_ITEM1_P79_S1	They typically order products from us based on their forecasts.
103730_18_ITEM1_P79_S2	If demand falls below customers' forecasts, or if customers do not control their inventory effectively, they may cancel or reschedule the shipments included in our backlog, in many instances without the payment of any penalty.
103730_18_ITEM1_P79_S3	Therefore, our backlog at any point in time is not necessarily indicative of the results to be expected for future periods.
103730_18_ITEM1_P80_S0	We sell our products to original equipment manufacturers ("OEMs"), electronic manufacturing services ("EMS") companies, which manufacture for OEMs on an outsourcing basis, and independent distributors that maintain large inventories of electronic components for resale to OEMs and EMS companies.

103730_18_ITEM1_P81_S0	Our sales organizations are regionally based.
103730_18_ITEM1_P81_S1	While our sales and support procedures are typically similar across all regions, we remain flexible in our ability to offer programs tailored to our customers' specific support requirements in each local area.
103730_18_ITEM1_P81_S2	The aim of our sales organizations is supporting our customers across all product lines, developing new design wins, negotiating contracts, and providing general commercial support as would normally be expected of a large multi-national sales force.
103730_18_ITEM1_P82_S0	We have an established Strategic Global Account program, which provides each of our top customers with a dedicated Strategic Global Account Manager.
103730_18_ITEM1_P82_S1	Our Strategic Global Account Managers are typically highly experienced salesmen or saleswomen who are capable of providing key customers with the coordination and management visibility required in a complex multi-product business relationship.
103730_18_ITEM1_P82_S2	They typically coordinate the sales, pricing, contract, logistic, quality, and other aspects of the customer's business requirements.
103730_18_ITEM1_P83_S0	The Strategic Global Account Manager normally is the focal point of communication between Vishay and our main customers.
103730_18_ITEM1_P83_S1	We maintain a similar program for our strategic distributors as well.
103730_18_ITEM1_P84_S0	We work with our customers so that our products are incorporated into the design of electronic equipment at the earliest stages of development and to provide technical and applications support.
103730_18_ITEM1_P84_S1	In addition to our staff of direct field sales personnel, independent manufacturers' representatives, and distributors, our Business Development group maintains teams of dedicated Field Application Engineers ("FAEs") to assist our customers in solving technical problems and in developing products to meet specific customer application needs using our entire product portfolio to provide support for our customers' engineering needs.
103730_18_ITEM1_P84_S2	Organized by market segment, our Business Development FAEs bring specific knowledge of component applications in their areas of expertise in the automotive, telecommunications, computer, consumer/entertainment, industrial, peripherals, digital consumer, and other market segments.
103730_18_ITEM1_P84_S3	With the ultimate goal of a Vishay "design-in" the process by which our customers specify a Vishay component in their products this program offers our customers enhanced access to all Vishay technologies while at the same time increasing design wins, and ultimately sales, for us.
103730_18_ITEM1_P84_S4	Most importantly, the process is closely monitored via a proprietary database developed by our Business Development group.
103730_18_ITEM1_P84_S5	Our database captures specific design activities and allows for real-time measurement of new business potential for our management team.
103730_18_ITEM1_P85_S0	Our top 30 customers have been relatively stable despite not having long-term commitments to purchase our products.
103730_18_ITEM1_P85_S1	With selected customers, we have signed longer term (greater than one year) contracts for specific products.
103730_18_ITEM1_P85_S2	Net revenues from our top 30 customers represent approximately 70% of our total net revenues.
103730_18_ITEM1_P85_S3	No single customer comprises more than 10% of our total net revenues.

103730_18_ITEM1A_P0_S0	From time to time, information provided by us, including but not limited to statements in this report, or other statements made by or on our behalf, may contain "forward-looking" information within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Such statements involve a number of risks, uncertainties, and contingencies, many of which are beyond our control, which may cause actual results, performance, or achievements to differ materially from those anticipated.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P0_S2	Set forth below are important factors that could cause our results, performance, or achievements to differ materially from those in any forward-looking statements made by us or on our behalf.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P0_S3	You should understand that it is not possible to predict or identify all such factors.

103730_18_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Our business is cyclical and future periods of decline and recovery are not predictable.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P2_S0	The electronic component industry is highly cyclical and experiences periods of decline from time to time.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P2_S1	We and others in the electronic component industry have experienced these conditions in the recent past and cannot predict when we may experience such downturns in the future.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Market conditions, such as a decline in product demand on a global basis, could result in order cancellations and deferrals, lower average selling prices, and a material and adverse impact on our results of operations.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P2_S3	These declines in demand are driven by market conditions in the end markets for our products.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P2_S4	Changes in the demand mix, needed technologies, and these end markets may adversely affect our ability to match our products, inventory, and capacity to meet customer demand and could adversely affect our operating results and financial condition.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P2_S5	A slowdown in demand or recessionary trends in the global economy makes it more difficult for us to predict our future sales and manage our operations, and could adversely impact our results of operations.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P3_S0	We have incurred, and may in the future incur, restructuring costs and associated asset write-downs.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P4_S0	To remain competitive, particularly when business conditions are difficult, we sometimes attempt to reduce our cost structure by restructuring our existing businesses, where we seek to achieve synergies, eliminate redundant facilities and staff positions, and move operations, where possible, to jurisdictions with lower labor costs.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P4_S1	In 2013 and 2015, we announced various cost reduction programs as part of our continuous efforts to improve efficiency and operating performance.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P4_S2	The programs primarily focused on enhancing the competitiveness of our MOSFETs segment, reducing selling, general, and administrative expenses company-wide, and improving the performance of certain product lines within our Capacitors and Resistors Inductors segments.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P4_S3	In 2016, we announced an extension of the 2013 MOSFETs Enhanced Competitiveness Program.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P4_S4	We incurred accelerated depreciation expenses related to assets that are no longer used after the implementation of the associated restructuring programs.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P4_S5	The expenses associated with the programs were recorded as they become recognizable under GAAP.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P4_S6	As of December 31, 2017, the programs were substantially implemented.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Additionally, our long-term strategy includes growing through the integration of acquired businesses, and GAAP requires plant closure and employee termination costs that we incur in connection with our acquisition activities to be recorded as expenses in our consolidated statement of operations, as such expenses are incurred.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P5_S1	For this reason, we expect to have some level of future restructuring expenses due to acquisitions.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Our business is cyclical, and in periods of a rising economy we may experience intense demand for our products.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P6_S1	If our restructuring activities result in us not being able to satisfy the intense demand from our customers during a rising economy and our competitors sufficiently expand production, we could lose customers and/or market share.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P6_S2	These losses could have an adverse effect on our operations, financial condition, and results of operations.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P7_S0	In the past we have grown through successful integration of acquired businesses, but this may not continue.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P8_S0	Our long-term historical growth in revenues and net earnings has resulted in large part from our strategy of expansion through acquisitions.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P8_S1	Despite our plan to continue to grow, in part, through targeted acquisitions, we may be unable to continue to identify, have the financial capabilities to acquire, or successfully complete transactions with suitable acquisition candidates.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P8_S2	We are subject to various U.S. and foreign competition laws and regulations that may affect our ability to complete certain acquisitions.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P8_S3	Also, if an acquired business fails to operate as anticipated, cannot be successfully integrated with our other businesses, or we cannot effectively mitigate the assumed, contingent, and unknown liabilities acquired, our results of operations, financial condition, enterprise value, market value, and prospects could all be materially adversely affected.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P9_S0	To remain successful, we must continue to innovate, and our investments in new technologies may not prove successful.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Our future operating results are dependent on our ability to continually develop, introduce, and market new and innovative products, to modify existing products, to respond to technological change, and to customize certain products to meet customer requirements.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P10_S1	There are numerous risks inherent in this process, including the risks that we will be unable to anticipate the direction of technological change or that we will be unable to develop and market new products and applications in a timely fashion to satisfy customer demands.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P10_S2	If this occurs, we could lose customers and experience adverse effects on our financial condition and results of operations.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P11_S0	In addition to our own research and development initiatives, we periodically invest in technology start-up enterprises, in which we may acquire a controlling or noncontrolling interest but whose technology would be available to be commercialized by us.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P11_S1	There are numerous risks in investments of this nature including the limited operating history of such start-up entities, their need for capital, and their limited or absence of production experience, as well as the risk that their technologies may prove ineffective or fail to gain acceptance in the marketplace.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P11_S2	Certain of our historical investments in start-up companies have not succeeded, and there can be no assurance that our current and future investments in start-up enterprises will prove successful.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Our results are sensitive to raw material availability, quality, and cost.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Many of our products require the use of raw materials that are produced in only a limited number of regions around the world or are available from only a limited number of suppliers.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P13_S1	Our results of operations may be materially adversely affected if we have difficulty obtaining these raw materials, the quality of available raw materials deteriorates, or there are significant price increases for these raw materials.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P13_S2	The determination that any of the raw materials used in our products are conflict minerals originating from the Democratic Republic of the Congo or adjoining countries could increase the probability that we will encounter the challenges noted above, incur additional expenses to comply with government regulations, and face public scrutiny.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P13_S3	For periods in which the prices of these raw materials are rising, we may be unable to pass on the increased cost to our customers, which would result in decreased margins for the products in which they are used.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P13_S4	For periods in which the prices are declining, we may be required to write down our inventory carrying cost of these raw materials, because we record our inventory at the lower of cost or market.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P13_S5	Depending on the extent of the difference between market price and our carrying cost, this write-down could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P14_S0	From time to time there have been short-term market shortages of certain raw materials used in our products.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P14_S1	While these shortages have not historically adversely affected our ability to increase production of products containing these materials, they have historically resulted in higher raw material costs for us.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P14_S2	We cannot make any assurances that any of these market shortages in the future would not adversely affect our ability to increase production, particularly during periods of growing demand for our products.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P14_S3	To assure availability of raw materials in times of shortage, we may enter into long-term supply contracts for these materials, which may prove costly, unnecessary, and burdensome when the shortage abates.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P15_S0	We may not have adequate facilities to satisfy future increases in demand for our products.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P16_S0	Our business is cyclical and in periods of a rising economy, we may experience intense demand for our products.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P16_S1	During such periods, we may have difficulty expanding our manufacturing to satisfy demand.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P16_S2	Factors which could limit such expansion include delays in procurement of manufacturing equipment, shortages of skilled personnel, and physical constraints on expansion of our facilities.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P16_S3	If we are unable to meet our customers' requirements and our competitors sufficiently expand production, we could lose customers and/or market share.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P16_S4	These losses could have an adverse effect on our financial condition and results of operations.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P16_S5	Also, capacity that we add during upturns in the business cycle may result in excess capacity during periods when demand for our products recede, resulting in inefficient use of capital which could also adversely affect us.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P17_S0	Our ability to compete effectively with other companies depends, in part, on our ability to maintain the proprietary nature of our technology.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P18_S0	Protection of intellectual property often involves complex legal and factual issues.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P18_S1	We will be able to protect our proprietary rights from unauthorized use by third parties only to the extent that our proprietary technologies are covered by valid and enforceable patents or are effectively maintained as trade secrets.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P18_S2	We have applied, and will continue to apply, for patents covering our technologies and products, as we deem appropriate.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P18_S3	However, our applications may not result in issued patents.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P18_S4	Also, our existing patents and any future patents may not be sufficiently broad to prevent others from practicing our technologies or from developing competing products.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P18_S5	Others may independently develop similar or alternative technologies, design around our patented technologies, or may challenge or seek to invalidate our patents.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P18_S6	Also, the legal system in certain countries in which we operate may not provide or may not continue to provide sufficient, intellectual property legal protections and remedies.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P19_S0	Litigation regarding patent and other intellectual property rights is prevalent in the electronic components industry, particularly the discrete semiconductor sector.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P19_S1	We have on occasion been notified that we may be infringing on patent and other intellectual property rights of others.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P19_S2	In addition, customers purchasing components from us have rights to indemnification under certain circumstances if such components violate the intellectual property rights of others.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P19_S3	Further, we have observed that in the current business environment, electronic component and semiconductor companies have become more aggressive in asserting and defending patent claims against competitors.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P19_S4	We will continue to vigorously defend our intellectual property rights, and may become party to disputes regarding patent licensing and cross patent licensing.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P19_S5	Although licenses are generally offered in such situations and we have successfully resolved these situations in the past, there can be no assurance that we will not be subject to future litigation alleging intellectual property rights infringement, or that we will be able to obtain licenses on acceptable terms.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P19_S6	An unfavorable outcome regarding one of these matters could have a material adverse effect on our business and results of operations.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P20_S0	We face intense competition in our business, and we market our products to an increasingly concentrated group of customers.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Our business is highly competitive worldwide, with low transportation costs and few import barriers.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P21_S1	We compete principally on the bases of product quality and reliability, availability, customer service, technological innovation, timely delivery, and price.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P21_S2	The electronic component industry has become increasingly concentrated and globalized in recent years and our major competitors, some of which are larger than us, have significant financial resources and technological capabilities.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P22_S0	Our customers have become increasingly concentrated in recent years, and as a result, their buying power has increased and they have had greater ability to negotiate favorable pricing and terms.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P22_S1	This trend has adversely affected our average selling prices, particularly for commodity components.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P23_S0	Our backlog is subject to customer cancellation.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P24_S0	Many of the orders that comprise our backlog may be canceled by our customers without penalty.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P24_S1	Our customers may on occasion double and triple order components from multiple sources to ensure timely delivery when demand exceeds global supply.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P24_S2	They often cancel orders when business is weak and inventories are excessive.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P24_S3	Therefore, we cannot be certain that the amount of our backlog accurately reflects the level of orders that we will ultimately deliver.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P24_S4	Our results of operations could be adversely impacted if customers cancel a material portion of orders in our backlog.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P25_S0	Future changes in our environmental liability and compliance obligations may harm our ability to operate or increase our costs.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P26_S0	Our operations, products and/or product packaging are subject to environmental laws and regulations governing air emissions, wastewater discharges, the handling, disposal and remediation of hazardous substances, wastes and certain chemicals used or generated in our manufacturing processes, employee health and safety labeling or other notifications with respect to the content or other aspects of our processes, products or packaging, restrictions on the use of certain materials in or on design aspects of our products or product packaging, and responsibility for disposal of products or product packaging.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P26_S1	We establish reserves for specifically identified potential environmental liabilities.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P26_S2	Nevertheless, we have in the past and may in the future inherit certain pre-existing environmental liabilities, generally based on successor liability doctrines, or otherwise incur environmental liabilities.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P27_S0	We are involved in remediation programs and related litigation at various current and former properties and at third-party disposal sites both within and outside of the U.S., including involvement as a potentially responsible party at Superfund sites.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P27_S1	Although we have never been involved in any environmental matter that has had a material adverse impact on our overall operations, there can be no assurance that in connection with any past or future acquisition, future developments, including related to our remediation programs, or otherwise, we will not be obligated to address environmental matters that could have a material adverse impact on our results of operations.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P27_S2	In addition, more stringent environmental regulations may be enacted in the future, and we cannot presently determine the modifications, if any, in our operations that any such future regulations might require, or the cost of compliance with these regulations.

103730_18_ITEM1A_P29_S1	By virtue of such sales, we are subject to various regulatory requirements and risks in the event of non-compliance.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P30_S0	We sell products under prime and subprime contracts with the U.S. government and other governments.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P30_S1	Many of these products are used in military applications.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P31_S0	Government contractors must comply with specific procurement regulations and other requirements.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P31_S1	These requirements, although customary in government contracts, impact our performance and compliance costs.

103730_18_ITEM1A_P31_S3	Our failure to comply with these regulations and requirements could also lead to suspension or debarment, for cause, from government contracting or subcontracting for a period of time.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P31_S4	Among the causes for debarment are violations of various statutes, including those related to procurement integrity, export control, government security regulations, employment practices, protection of the environment, accuracy of records and the recording of costs, and foreign corruption.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P31_S5	The termination of a government contract as a result of any of these acts could have a negative impact on our results of operations and financial condition and could have a negative impact on our reputation and ability to procure other government contracts in the future.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P32_S0	We have qualified certain of our products under various military specifications approved and monitored by the United States Defense Electronic Supply Center and under certain European military specifications.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P32_S1	These products are assigned certain classification levels.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P32_S2	In order to maintain the classification level of a product, we must continuously perform tests on the products and the results of these tests must be reported to governmental agencies.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P32_S3	If a product fails to meet the requirements of the applicable classification level, its classification may be reduced to a lower level.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P32_S4	A decrease in the classification level for a product with a military application could have an adverse impact on the net revenues and earnings attributable to that product.

103730_18_ITEM1A_P39_S0	Significant fluctuations in interest rates could adversely affect our results of operations and financial position.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P40_S0	We are exposed to changes in interest rates as a result of our borrowing activities and our cash balances.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P40_S1	Our credit facility bears interest at variable rates based on LIBOR.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P40_S2	A significant increase in LIBOR would significantly increase our interest expense.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P40_S3	A general increase in interest rates would be largely offset by an increase in interest income earned on our cash and short-term investment balances, which are currently greater than our debt balances.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P40_S4	However, there can be no assurance that the interest rate earned on cash and short-term investments will move in tandem with the interest rate paid on our variable rate debt.

103730_18_ITEM1A_P42_S0	The recorded value of our outstanding debt increased from approximately $347 million as of December 31, 2008 to approximately $370 million as of December 31, 2017, primarily due to the issuance of convertible senior debentures, the proceeds from the sale of which we used to fund repurchases of our common stock.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P42_S1	The carrying value of our convertible senior debentures will continue to increase as the discount associated with the debentures is amortized.

103730_18_ITEM1A_P43_S0	Prior to three months before the respective maturity dates of our convertible senior debentures due 2040, 2041, and 2042, the holders of the debentures may only convert the debentures under specific circumstances as defined in the indentures governing the debentures.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P43_S1	As of December 31, 2017, our convertible senior debentures due 2040 and 2042 are convertible (See Note 6 to the Consolidated Financial Statements).
103730_18_ITEM1A_P43_S2	Regardless of current convertibility of the debentures, GAAP requires convertible debentures to be included in the calculation of diluted EPS using either the "If Converted" or the "Treasury Stock Method" depending on our intent and ability to settle the debentures upon repurchase or conversion.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P44_S0	Pursuant to the indentures governing the respective debentures, we have the right to pay the conversion value or purchase price for the debentures in cash, Vishay common stock, or a combination of both.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P44_S1	At the direction of our Board of Directors, we intend, upon conversion, to repay the principal amounts of the debentures and settle any additional amounts in shares of Vishay common stock.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P44_S2	Accordingly, the debentures are included in the diluted EPS computation using the "Treasury Stock" method" rather than the "If Converted" method.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P45_S0	If we were unable to employ the "Treasury Stock" method due to increased debt levels or changes in intentions, the number of potentially dilutive securities could increase significantly.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P46_S0	Our existing credit facility restricts our current and future operations and requires compliance with certain financial covenants.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P47_S0	Our existing credit facility includes restrictions on, among other things, incurring indebtedness, incurring liens on assets, making investments and acquisitions, making asset sales, and paying cash dividends and making other restricted payments.

103730_18_ITEM1A_P51_S0	We are subject to the risks of political, economic, and military instability in countries outside the United States in which we operate.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P52_S0	We have substantial operations outside the United States, and approximately 77% of our revenues during 2017 were derived from sales to customers outside the United States.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P52_S1	Certain of our assets are located, and certain of our products are produced, in countries which are subject to risks of social, political, economic, and military instability.

103730_18_ITEM1A_P52_S3	These conditions could have an adverse impact on our ability to operate in these regions and, depending on the extent and severity of these conditions, could materially and adversely affect our overall financial condition, results of operations, and our ability to access our liquidity.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P53_S0	Our business has been in operation in Israel for 47 years, where we have substantial manufacturing operations.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P53_S1	Although we have never experienced any material interruption in our operations attributable to these factors, in spite of several Middle East crises, including wars, our financial condition and results of operations might be adversely affected if events were to occur in the Middle East that interfered with our operations in Israel.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P54_S0	Our global operations are subject to extensive anti-corruption laws and other regulations.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P55_S0	The U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and similar foreign anti-corruption laws generally prohibit companies and their intermediaries from making improper payments or providing anything of value to improperly influence foreign government officials for the purpose of obtaining or retaining business, or obtaining an unfair advantage.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P56_S0	Recent years have seen a substantial increase in the global enforcement of anti-corruption laws.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P56_S1	Our continued operation and expansion outside the United States, including in developing countries, could increase the risk of such violations or violations under other regulations relating to limitations on or licenses required for sales made to customers located in certain countries.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P56_S2	Violations of these laws may result in severe criminal or civil sanctions, could disrupt our business, and result in a material adverse effect on our reputation, business and results of operations or financial condition.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P57_S0	We attempt to improve profitability by controlling labor costs, but these activities could result in labor unrest or considerable expense.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P58_S0	Historically, our primary labor cost controlling strategy was to transfer manufacturing operations to countries with lower production costs, such as the Czech Republic, Hungary, India, Israel, Malaysia, Mexico, the People's Republic of China, and the Philippines.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P58_S1	We believe that our manufacturing footprint is suitable to serve our customers and end markets, while maintaining lower manufacturing costs.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P58_S2	We do not anticipate further transferring any significant existing operations to lower-labor-cost countries; however, acquired operations may be transferred to lower-labor-cost countries when integrated into Vishay.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P59_S0	Currently, our primary labor cost controlling strategy involves reducing hours and limiting the use of subcontractors and foundries when demand for our products decreases.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P59_S1	Shifting operations to lower-labor-cost countries, reducing hours, or limiting the use of subcontractors and foundries could result in production inefficiencies, higher costs, and/or strikes or other types of labor unrest.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P60_S0	We are subject to foreign currency exchange rate risks which may impact our results of operations.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P61_S0	We are exposed to foreign currency exchange rate risks, particularly due to market values of transactions in currencies other than the functional currencies of certain subsidiaries.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P61_S1	From time to time, we utilize forward contracts to hedge a portion of projected cash flows from these exposures.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P62_S0	Our significant foreign subsidiaries are located in Germany, Israel, and Asia.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P62_S1	We finance our operations in Europe and certain locations in Asia in local currencies.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P62_S2	Our operations in Israel and most significant locations in Asia are largely financed in U.S. dollars, but these subsidiaries also have significant transactions in local currencies.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P62_S3	Our exposure to foreign currency risk is mitigated to the extent that the costs incurred and the revenues earned in a particular currency offset one another.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P62_S4	Our exposure to foreign currency risk is more pronounced in situations where, for example, production labor costs are predominantly paid in local currencies while the sales revenue for those products is denominated in U.S. dollars.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P62_S5	This is particularly the case for products produced in Israel, the Czech Republic, and China.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P63_S0	A change in the mix of the currencies in which we transact our business could have a material effect on results of operations.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P63_S1	Furthermore, the timing of cash receipts and disbursements could have a material effect on our results of operations, particularly if there are significant changes in exchange rates in a short period of time.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P64_S0	Approximately 99% of our cash and cash equivalents and short-term investments balances were held by our non-U.S. subsidiaries, and our U.S. parent company and U.S. subsidiaries have significant payment obligations.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P65_S0	We generate a significant amount of cash and profits from our non-U.S. subsidiaries.

103730_18_ITEM1A_P66_S0	The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act ("TCJA"), enacted on December 22, 2017, transitions the U.S. from a worldwide tax system to a territorial tax system.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P67_S0	Under previous law, companies could indefinitely defer U.S. income taxation on unremitted foreign earnings.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P67_S1	The TCJA imposes a one-time transition tax on deferred foreign earnings of 15.5% for liquid assets and 8% for illiquid assets, payable in defined increments over eight years.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P67_S2	As a result of this requirement, we provisionally expect to pay $180.0 million, net of estimated applicable foreign tax credits, and after utilization of net operating loss and R D and FTC Credit carryforwards.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P67_S3	Based on our U.S. cash position, we expect that we will be required to repatriate amounts from our non-U.S. subsidiaries to the United States to satisfy this tax obligation.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P68_S0	These previously deferred foreign earnings may now be repatriated to the United States without additional U.S. federal taxation.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P68_S1	However, any such repatriation could incur withholding and other foreign taxes in the source and intervening foreign jurisdictions, and certain U.S. state taxes.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P69_S0	Cash dividends to stockholders, share repurchases, and principal and interest payments on our debt instruments need to be paid by the U.S. parent company, Vishay Intertechnology, Inc.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P69_S1	Our U.S. subsidiaries have other operating cash needs.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P70_S0	If we are unable to repatriate adequate cash to the United States to satisfy these obligations, it could materially and adversely affect our overall financial condition, results of operations and our liquidity.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P71_S0	The holders of our Class B common stock have effective voting control of our company.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P72_S0	We have two classes of common stock: common stock and Class B common stock.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P72_S1	The holders of common stock are entitled to one vote for each share held, while the holders of Class B common stock are entitled to 10 votes for each share held.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P72_S2	At December 31, 2017, the holders of Class B common stock held approximately 47.9% of the voting power of Vishay.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P72_S3	The ownership of Class B common stock is highly concentrated, and holders of Class B common stock effectively can cause the election of directors and approve other actions as stockholders.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P72_S4	As a result of the passing of our founder and former Executive Chairman, Dr. Felix Zandman, Mrs. Ruta Zandman (a member of our Board of Directors) controls the voting of, solely or on a shared basis with Marc Zandman (our Executive Chairman) and Ziv Shoshani (a member of our Board of Directors), approximately 89.5% of our Class B common stock and 42.9% of the total voting power of our capital stock as of December 31, 2017.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P73_S0	We have a staggered board of directors which could make a takeover of Vishay difficult.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P74_S0	Along with the Class B common stock voting power, our staggered board of directors might discourage, delay, or prevent a change in control of our company by a third party and could discourage proxy contests and make it more difficult for stockholders to elect directors and take other corporate actions.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P74_S1	Also, as a consequence of our staggered board, directors may not be removed without cause, even though a majority of stockholders may wish to do so.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P75_S0	Our reluctance to issue substantial additional shares in order not to dilute the interests of our existing stockholders could impede growth.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P76_S0	Our overall long-term business strategy has historically included a strong focus on acquisitions financed alternatively through cash on hand, the incurrence of indebtedness, and the issuance of equity, directly or indirectly by refinancing acquisition debt.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P76_S1	We may in the future be presented with attractive investment or strategic opportunities that, because of their size and our financial condition at the time, would require the issuance of substantial additional amounts of our common stock.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P76_S2	Some or all of our holders of Class B common stock may exert considerable influence over our policies, business and affairs, and in any corporate transaction or other matter, including those described above.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P76_S3	If such opportunities were to arise, our Board of Directors may consider the potentially dilutive effect on the interests and voting power of our existing stockholders, including our Class B stockholders.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P76_S4	Any resulting reluctance to issue additional shares could impede our future growth.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P77_S0	Our outstanding convertible debentures may impact the trading price of our common stock.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P78_S0	We believe that many investors in, and potential purchasers of, convertible debt instruments employ, or seek to employ, a convertible arbitrage strategy with respect to these instruments.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P78_S1	Investors that employ a convertible arbitrage strategy with respect to convertible debt instruments typically implement that strategy by selling short the common stock underlying the convertible instrument and dynamically adjusting their short position while they hold the instrument.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P78_S2	The implementation of this strategy by investors in our convertible debentures, as well as related market regulatory actions, could have a significant impact on the trading prices of our common stock, and the trading prices and liquidity of our convertible debentures.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P78_S3	The price of our common stock and our convertible debentures could also be affected by possible sales of our common stock by investors who view our convertible debentures as more attractive means of equity participation in us.

103730_18_ITEM1A_P80_S0	VPG has a worldwide, perpetual and royalty-free license from us to use the "Vishay" mark as part of its corporate name and in connection with the manufacture, sale, and marketing of the products and services that comprise its measurements and foil resistors businesses.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P80_S1	The license of the Vishay name to VPG is important because we anticipate that the success of VPG will depend in no small measure on the reputation of the Vishay brand for these products and services built over many years.
103730_18_ITEM1A_P80_S2	Nonetheless, there exists the risk that the use by VPG could cause confusion in the marketplace over the products of the two companies, that any negative publicity associated with a product or service of VPG following the spin-off could be mistakenly attributed to our company or that we could lose our own rights to the "Vishay" mark if we fail to impose sufficient controls on VPG's use of the mark.

103730_18_ITEM3_P0_S0	From time to time we are involved in routine litigation incidental to our business.

103730_18_ITEM3_P1_S0	Vishay Polytech Co., Ltd. ("VPC"), a subsidiary of Vishay which was purchased from Holy Stone Enterprises Co., Ltd. ("Holy Stone") in June 2014, is a named defendant, among other manufacturers, in purported antitrust class action complaints in the United States and Canada.
103730_18_ITEM3_P1_S1	The complaints allege restraints of trade in aluminum and tantalum electrolytic capacitors, and in some cases, film capacitors, and seek injunctive relief and unspecified joint and several treble damages.
103730_18_ITEM3_P1_S2	Vishay Intertechnology, Inc. is a party to similar cases filed in Canada.
103730_18_ITEM3_P2_S0	Holy Stone has agreed to indemnify Vishay and VPC for losses, including penalties and expenses associated with the litigation and investigation described above.
103730_18_ITEM3_P2_S1	Notwithstanding this indemnity obligation, the Company and VPC intend to defend vigorously against the civil complaints.
103730_18_ITEM3_P3_S0	We are engaged in discussions with various parties regarding patent licensing and cross patent licensing issues.
103730_18_ITEM3_P3_S1	In addition, we have observed that in the current business environment, electronic component and semiconductor companies have become more aggressive in asserting and defending patent claims against competitors.
103730_18_ITEM3_P3_S2	We are a party to disputes alleging infringement of third-party patents.
103730_18_ITEM3_P3_S3	When we believe other companies are misappropriating our intellectual property rights, we vigorously enforce those rights through legal action, and we intend to continue to do so.

103730_18_ITEM3_P5_S0	Certain obligations as a PRP have arisen in connection with business acquisitions.

103730_18_ITEM7_P0_S0	Vishay Intertechnology, Inc. is a global manufacturer and supplier of semiconductors and passive components, including power MOSFETs, power integrated circuits, transistors, diodes, optoelectronic components, resistors, capacitors, and inductors.
103730_18_ITEM7_P0_S1	Discrete semiconductors and passive components manufactured by Vishay are used in virtually all types of electronic products, including those in the industrial, computing, automotive, consumer electronic products, telecommunications, power supplies, military/aerospace, and medical industries.
103730_18_ITEM7_P1_S0	We operate in five product segments, MOSFETs, Diodes, Optoelectronic Components, Resistors Inductors, and Capacitors.
103730_18_ITEM7_P2_S0	Since 1985, we have pursued a business strategy of growth through focused research and development and acquisitions.
103730_18_ITEM7_P2_S1	Through this strategy, we have grown to become one of the world's largest manufacturers of discrete semiconductors and passive components.
103730_18_ITEM7_P2_S2	We expect to continue our strategy of acquisitions while also maintaining a prudent capital structure.

103730_18_ITEM7_P22_S0	Our results for 2016 and 2017 represent the effects of an excellent business environment, a high level of orders, our cost reduction programs, and our organic growth initiatives.
103730_18_ITEM7_P22_S1	Order activity was already strong in 2016, but we experienced a relatively sharp upturn in demand in the first half of 2017 that continued through the second half of the year.

103730_18_ITEM7_P23_S0	We utilize several financial metrics to evaluate the performance and assess the future direction of our business.
103730_18_ITEM7_P23_S1	These key financial measures and metrics include net revenues, gross profit margin, operating margin, segment operating income, end-of-period backlog, and the book-to-bill ratio.
103730_18_ITEM7_P23_S2	We also monitor changes in our inventory turnover and our or publicly available average selling prices ("ASP").
103730_18_ITEM7_P24_S0	Gross profit margin is computed as gross profit as a percentage of net revenues.
103730_18_ITEM7_P24_S1	Gross profit is generally net revenues less costs of products sold, but also deducts certain other period costs, particularly losses on purchase commitments and inventory write-downs.
103730_18_ITEM7_P24_S2	Losses on purchase commitments and inventory write-downs have the impact of reducing gross profit margin in the period of the charge, but result in improved gross profit margins in subsequent periods by reducing costs of products sold as inventory is used.
103730_18_ITEM7_P25_S0	Gross profit margin is clearly a function of net revenues, but also reflects our cost management programs and our ability to contain fixed costs.
103730_18_ITEM7_P26_S0	Operating margin is computed as gross profit less operating expenses as a percentage of net revenues.
103730_18_ITEM7_P26_S1	We evaluate business segment performance on segment operating margin.
103730_18_ITEM7_P26_S2	Only dedicated, direct selling, general, and administrative expenses of the segments are included in the calculation of segment operating income.
103730_18_ITEM7_P26_S3	Segment operating margin is computed as operating income less items such as restructuring and severance costs, asset write-downs, goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible asset impairments, inventory write-downs, gain or losses on purchase commitments, global operations, sales and marketing, information systems, finance and administrative groups, and other items, expressed as a percentage of net revenues.
103730_18_ITEM7_P26_S4	We believe that evaluating segment performance excluding such items is meaningful because it provides insight with respect to intrinsic operating results of the segment.
103730_18_ITEM7_P27_S0	Operating margin is clearly a function of net revenues, but also reflects our cost management programs and our ability to contain fixed costs.
103730_18_ITEM7_P28_S0	End-of-period backlog is one indicator of future revenues.
103730_18_ITEM7_P28_S1	We include in our backlog only open orders that we expect to ship in the next twelve months.
103730_18_ITEM7_P28_S2	If demand falls below customers' forecasts, or if customers do not control their inventory effectively, they may cancel or reschedule the shipments that are included in our backlog, in many instances without the payment of any penalty.
103730_18_ITEM7_P28_S3	Therefore, the backlog is not necessarily indicative of the results to be expected for future periods.
103730_18_ITEM7_P29_S0	An important indicator of demand in our industry is the book-to-bill ratio, which is the ratio of the amount of product ordered during a period as compared with the product that we ship during that period.
103730_18_ITEM7_P29_S1	A book-to-bill ratio that is greater than one indicates that our backlog is building and that we are likely to see increasing revenues in future periods.
103730_18_ITEM7_P29_S2	Conversely, a book-to-bill ratio that is less than one is an indicator of declining demand and may foretell declining revenues.
103730_18_ITEM7_P30_S0	We focus on our inventory turnover as a measure of how well we are managing our inventory.
103730_18_ITEM7_P31_S0	We define inventory turnover for a financial reporting period as our costs of products sold for the four fiscal quarters ending on the last day of the reporting period divided by our average inventory (computed using each fiscal quarter-end balance) for this same period.
103730_18_ITEM7_P31_S1	A higher level of inventory turnover reflects more efficient use of our capital.
103730_18_ITEM7_P32_S0	Pricing in our industry can be volatile.
103730_18_ITEM7_P32_S1	Using our and publicly available data, we analyze trends and changes in average selling prices to evaluate likely future pricing.
103730_18_ITEM7_P33_S0	The erosion of average selling prices of established products is typical for semiconductor products.
103730_18_ITEM7_P33_S1	We attempt to offset this deterioration with ongoing cost reduction activities and new product introductions.
103730_18_ITEM7_P33_S2	Our specialty passive components are more resistant to average selling price erosion.
103730_18_ITEM7_P34_S0	All pricing is subject to governing market conditions.
103730_18_ITEM7_P35_S0	The quarter-to-quarter trends in these financial metrics can also be an important indicator of the likely direction of our business.
