103730_18_ITEM7_P42_S0	On December 22, 2017, the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (the "TCJA") was enacted in the United States.
103730_18_ITEM7_P42_S1	The TCJA represents sweeping changes in U.S. tax law.
103730_18_ITEM7_P43_S0	Under U.S. GAAP (specifically, ASC Topic 740), the effects of changes in tax rates and laws on deferred tax balances are recognized in the period in which the new legislation is enacted.
103730_18_ITEM7_P43_S1	The total effect of tax law changes on deferred tax balances is recorded as a component of income tax expense.
103730_18_ITEM7_P44_S0	In response to the TCJA, the Staff of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission issued Staff Accounting Bulletin No. 118 ("SAB No. 118") to provide guidance to registrants in applying ASC Topic 740 in connection with the TCJA.
103730_18_ITEM7_P44_S1	SAB No. 118 provides that in the period of enactment, the income tax effects of the TCJA may be reported as a provisional amount based on a reasonable estimate (to the extent a reasonable estimate can be determined), which would be subject to adjustment during a "measurement period".
103730_18_ITEM7_P44_S2	The measurement period begins in the reporting period of the TCJA's enactment and ends when a registrant has obtained, prepared, and analyzed the information that was needed in order to complete the accounting requirements under ASC Topic 740.
103730_18_ITEM7_P44_S3	SAB No. 118 also describes supplemental disclosures that should accompany the provisional amounts.
103730_18_ITEM7_P45_S0	The TCJA represents the first significant change in U.S. tax law in over 30 years.
103730_18_ITEM7_P46_S0	As permitted by SAB No. 118, the net tax expense recorded in our financial statements for the fourth fiscal quarter of 2017 due to the enactment of the TCJA is considered "provisional," based on reasonable estimates.
103730_18_ITEM7_P46_S1	We are continuing to collect and analyze detailed information about the earnings and profits of our non-U.S. subsidiaries, the related taxes paid, the amounts which could be repatriated, the foreign taxes which may be incurred on repatriation, and the associated impact of these items under the TCJA.
103730_18_ITEM7_P46_S2	We may record adjustments to refine those estimates during the measurement period, as additional analysis is completed.
103730_18_ITEM7_P46_S3	Furthermore, we are continuing to evaluate the TCJA's provisions and may prospectively adjust our financial structure and business practices accordingly.
103730_18_ITEM7_P47_S0	The provisional amount of net tax expense recorded in the fourth fiscal quarter of 2017 that is directly and indirectly related to the TCJA is summarized as follows (amounts in thousands) :
103730_18_ITEM7_P48_S0	As a result of the TCJA, we recognized a provisional tax benefit of $74.8 million to remeasure our net deferred tax liabilities at the lower, 21% rate.
103730_18_ITEM7_P49_S0	The TCJA transitions the U.S. from a worldwide tax system to a territorial tax system.
103730_18_ITEM7_P50_S0	Under previous law, companies could indefinitely defer U.S. income taxation on unremitted foreign earnings.
103730_18_ITEM7_P50_S1	The TCJA imposes a one-time transition tax on deferred foreign earnings of 15.5% for liquid assets and 8% for illiquid assets, payable in defined increments over eight years.
103730_18_ITEM7_P50_S2	As a result of this requirement, we recognized provisional tax expense of $215.6 million, and provisionally expect to pay $180.0 million, net of estimated applicable foreign tax credits, and after utilization of net operating loss and R D and FTC Credit carryforwards.
103730_18_ITEM7_P50_S3	These previously deferred foreign earnings may now be repatriated to the United States without additional U.S. federal taxation.
103730_18_ITEM7_P50_S4	However, any such repatriation could incur withholding and other foreign taxes in the source and intervening foreign jurisdictions, and certain U.S. state taxes.
103730_18_ITEM7_P51_S0	Due to the changes in taxation of dividends received from foreign subsidiaries, and also because of the need to finance the payment of the transition tax, we made the determination during the fourth fiscal quarter of 2017 that certain unremitted foreign earnings in Israel, Germany, Austria, and France are no longer permanently reinvested, and have recorded provisional tax expense of $213.0 million to accrue the incremental foreign income taxes and withholding taxes payable to foreign jurisdictions assuming the hypothetical repatriation to the United States of these approximately $1.1 billion of available foreign earnings.
103730_18_ITEM7_P51_S1	Due to the existence of the foreign cash taxes payable at the source, we expect to actually repatriate these amounts at a measured pace over several years, and may decide to ultimately not repatriate some of these amounts.
103730_18_ITEM7_P52_S0	There are additional amounts of unremitted foreign earnings in other countries, which continue to be reinvested indefinitely, and we have made no provision for incremental foreign income taxes and withholding taxes payable to foreign jurisdictions related to these amounts.
103730_18_ITEM7_P52_S1	Determination of the amount of the unrecognized deferred foreign tax liability for these amounts is not practicable because of the complexities associated with its hypothetical calculation.
103730_18_ITEM7_P53_S0	During the fourth fiscal quarter of 2015, we recognized income tax, including U.S. federal and state income taxes, incremental foreign income taxes, and withholding taxes payable to foreign jurisdictions, on $300 million of foreign earnings.
103730_18_ITEM7_P53_S1	This tax expense was recognized in 2015 following an evaluation of our anticipated domestic cash needs over the next several years and our most efficient use of liquidity, and with consideration of the amount of cash that could be repatriated to the U.S. efficiently with lesser withholding taxes in foreign jurisdictions.
103730_18_ITEM7_P53_S2	We repatriated $38.0 million and $46.0 million pursuant to this program in 2017 and 2016, respectively.
103730_18_ITEM7_P53_S3	Prior to the enactment of the TCJA, the related deferred tax liability for the 2015 repatriation plan was $118.9 million.
103730_18_ITEM7_P53_S4	We have terminated the 2015 cash repatriation plan and recorded a provisional income tax benefit to reverse this deferred tax liability, which was replaced by the liability for the transition tax and foreign income and withholding taxes described above.
103730_18_ITEM7_P54_S0	The deferred tax liability related to these unremitted foreign earnings is based on the available sources of cash, applicable tax rates, foreign currency exchange rates, and other factors and circumstances, as of each balance sheet date.
103730_18_ITEM7_P54_S1	Changes in these underlying facts and circumstances result in changes in the deferred tax liability balance, which are recorded as tax benefit or expense.
103730_18_ITEM7_P55_S0	We expect to continue to generate a significant amount of cash and profits from our non-U.S. subsidiaries, and our provision for income taxes will continue to be based on various assertions regarding the future use of that cash and profits.
103730_18_ITEM7_P55_S1	Such assertions require us to consider a wide variety of U.S. federal and foreign tax laws, and the application of such laws to our operational and strategic needs.
103730_18_ITEM7_P56_S0	Our GAAP interest expense generally exceeds our U.S.-based operating income, resulting in pre-tax losses in the U.S.
103730_18_ITEM7_P56_S1	Accordingly, we have historically recorded U.S. federal tax benefits, at 35%, which had the effect of reducing our consolidated GAAP tax rate.
103730_18_ITEM7_P56_S2	Accordingly, the reduction in the statutory U.S. tax rate will generally increase our consolidated GAAP tax rate due to the loss of these tax benefits recognized on a GAAP basis.
103730_18_ITEM7_P57_S0	The TCJA expands the U.S. current taxation of foreign earned income beginning in 2018.
103730_18_ITEM7_P58_S0	Global intangible low-taxed income ("GILTI") is income of our non-U.S. subsidiaries that exceeds an allowable return and which will then be included in U.S. current taxable income, subject to certain adjustments, and possibly reduced by indirect foreign tax credits.
103730_18_ITEM7_P58_S1	We have elected to account for GILTI tax in the period in which it is incurred, and therefore have not provided any deferred tax impacts of GILTI in our consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2017.
103730_18_ITEM7_P58_S2	We expect that we will be subject to incremental U.S. tax on GILTI income beginning in 2018.
103730_18_ITEM7_P58_S3	Because of the complexity of the new GILTI provisions, we are still evaluating the impact on our future effective tax rate.
103730_18_ITEM7_P59_S0	The TCJA also imposes a base erosion and anti-abuse minimum tax ("BEAT").
103730_18_ITEM7_P59_S1	BEAT could potentially increase our U.S. federal income tax by disallowing certain otherwise deductible payments from the U.S. to non-U.S. subsidiaries and imposing a minimum tax if greater than the regular tax.
103730_18_ITEM7_P59_S2	We are still evaluating the potential impacts of the new BEAT tax rules.
103730_18_ITEM7_P60_S0	We historically derived significant cash tax savings from our convertible debentures.
103730_18_ITEM7_P60_S1	For U.S. federal income tax purposes, the interest deduction for the convertible debentures is computed based on the comparable yield of a hypothetical fixed rate debt instrument with similar terms and conditions but no conversion feature.
103730_18_ITEM7_P60_S2	Accordingly, annual interest deductions are calculated at 8.0%, 8.375%, and 7.5% of the adjusted issue price.
103730_18_ITEM7_P60_S3	The adjusted issue price, and consequently the interest deduction for income tax purposes, grows over the term of the debt due to the difference between the interest deduction using a comparable yield applied to the adjusted issue price, and the coupon rate of 2.5% on the principal amount.
103730_18_ITEM7_P60_S4	Interest expense recognized in accordance with GAAP is calculated at the comparable yield multiplied by the carrying amount of the liability component of convertible debentures, which is substantially lower than the adjusted issue price for tax purposes.
103730_18_ITEM7_P60_S5	The difference between the tax and GAAP interest computations resulted in substantially greater interest deductions for tax purposes than GAAP interest expense.
103730_18_ITEM7_P60_S6	The TCJA limits deduction for net interest expense, which makes the convertible debentures less attractive financial instruments.
103730_18_ITEM7_P60_S7	While the convertible debentures due 2040 and 2042 and currently convertible at the option of the holders, none of the convertible debentures are currently callable by us.
103730_18_ITEM7_P60_S8	We are evaluating financing alternatives, which might include the modification or replacement of such instruments, as a result of the TCJA.
103730_18_ITEM7_P61_S0	As part of our growth strategy, we seek to expand through targeted acquisitions of other manufacturers of electronic components that have established positions in major markets, reputations for product quality and reliability, and product lines with which we have substantial marketing and technical expertise.
103730_18_ITEM7_P61_S1	This includes exploring opportunities to acquire targets to gain market share, penetrate different geographic markets, enhance new product development, round out our existing product lines, or grow our high margin niche market businesses.
103730_18_ITEM7_P61_S2	Acquisitions of passive components businesses would likely be made to strengthen and broaden our position as a specialty product supplier; acquisitions of discrete semiconductor businesses would be made to increase market share and to generate synergies.
103730_18_ITEM7_P61_S3	To limit our financial exposure, we have implemented a policy not to pursue acquisitions if our post-acquisition debt would exceed 2.5x our pro forma earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization ("EBITDA").
103730_18_ITEM7_P61_S4	For these purposes, we calculate pro forma EBITDA as the adjusted EBITDA of Vishay and the target for Vishay's four preceding fiscal quarters, with a pro forma adjustment for savings which management estimates would have been achieved had the target been acquired by Vishay at the beginning of the four fiscal quarter period.
103730_18_ITEM7_P62_S0	Our growth plan targets adding, through acquisitions, an average of approximately $100 million of revenues per year.
103730_18_ITEM7_P62_S1	Depending on the opportunities available, we might make several smaller acquisitions or a few larger acquisitions.
103730_18_ITEM7_P62_S2	We intend to make such acquisitions using mainly cash, rather than debt or equity, although we do have capacity under our revolving credit facility if necessary.
103730_18_ITEM7_P62_S3	We are not currently targeting acquisitions with a purchase price larger than $500 million.

103730_18_ITEM7_P66_S1	This business will be incorporated into our Resistors Inductors segment.
103730_18_ITEM7_P67_S0	We place a strong emphasis on controlling our costs, and use various measures and metrics to evaluate our cost structure.
103730_18_ITEM7_P68_S0	We define variable costs as expenses that vary with respect to quantity produced.
103730_18_ITEM7_P68_S1	Fixed costs do not vary with respect to quantity produced over the relevant time period.
103730_18_ITEM7_P69_S0	Contributive margin is calculated as net revenue less variable costs.
103730_18_ITEM7_P69_S1	It may be expressed in dollars or as a percentage of net revenue.
103730_18_ITEM7_P69_S2	Management uses this measure to determine the amount of profit to be expected for any change in revenues.
103730_18_ITEM7_P69_S3	While these measures are typical cost accounting measures, none of these measures are recognized in accordance with GAAP.
103730_18_ITEM7_P70_S0	The classification of expenses as either variable or fixed is judgmental and other companies might classify such expenses differently.
103730_18_ITEM7_P70_S1	These measures, as calculated by Vishay, may not be comparable to similarly titled measures used by other companies.
103730_18_ITEM7_P71_S0	We closely monitor variable costs and seek to achieve the contributive margin in our business model.
103730_18_ITEM7_P71_S1	Over a period of many years, we have generally maintained a contributive margin of between 45% - 47% of revenues.
103730_18_ITEM7_P71_S2	The erosion of average selling prices, particularly of our semiconductor products, that is typical of our industry, and inflation negatively impact contributive margin and drive us to continually seek ways to reduce our variable costs.
103730_18_ITEM7_P71_S3	Our variable cost reduction efforts include increasing the efficiency in our production facilities by expending capital for automation, reducing materials costs, materials substitution, increasing wafer size and shrinking dies to maximize efficiency in our semiconductor production processes, and other yield improvement activities.
103730_18_ITEM7_P72_S0	Our cost management strategy also includes a focus on controlling fixed costs recorded as costs of products sold or selling, general, and administrative expenses and maintaining our break-even point (adjusted for acquisitions).
103730_18_ITEM7_P72_S1	We seek to limit increases in selling, general, and administrative expenses to the rate of inflation, excluding foreign currency exchange effects and substantially independent of sales volume changes.
103730_18_ITEM7_P72_S2	At constant fixed costs, we would expect each $1 million increase in revenues to increase our operating income by approximately $450,000 to $470,000.
103730_18_ITEM7_P72_S3	Sudden changes in the business conditions, however, may not allow us to quickly adapt our manufacturing capacity and cost structure.
103730_18_ITEM7_P73_S0	Occasionally, our ongoing cost containment activities are not adequate and we must take actions to maintain our cost competitiveness.
103730_18_ITEM7_P73_S1	We incurred significant restructuring expenses in our past to reduce our cost structure.
103730_18_ITEM7_P74_S0	Historically, our primary cost reduction technique was through the transfer of production to the extent possible from high-labor-cost countries to lower-labor-cost countries.
103730_18_ITEM7_P74_S1	We believe that our manufacturing footprint is suitable to serve our customers and end markets, while maintaining lower manufacturing costs.
103730_18_ITEM7_P74_S2	Since 2013, our cost reduction programs have primarily focused on reducing fixed costs, including selling, general, and administrative expenses.
103730_18_ITEM7_P75_S0	In the fourth fiscal quarter of 2013, we announced various cost reduction programs as part of our continuous efforts to improve efficiency and operating performance.
103730_18_ITEM7_P76_S0	The programs initiated in 2013 primarily focused on a plan to enhance the competitiveness of our MOSFETs segment and a voluntary separation / early retirement offer to certain employees Company-wide.
103730_18_ITEM7_P76_S1	We also implemented two other smaller cost reduction programs concerning the manufacturing of products within our Diodes segment.
103730_18_ITEM7_P76_S2	The voluntary separation / early retirement and Diodes segment programs were substantially completed in 2014.
103730_18_ITEM7_P77_S0	We completed the initially planned production transfer as part of the MOSFETs Enhanced Competitiveness Program in the first fiscal quarter of 2016.
103730_18_ITEM7_P77_S1	The production transfer occurred over a period of approximately two years.
103730_18_ITEM7_P77_S2	The manufacture of wafers for certain critical products was transferred into a more cost-efficient fab.
103730_18_ITEM7_P77_S3	As a consequence, certain other wafer manufacturing previously occurring in-house was transferred to third-party foundries.
103730_18_ITEM7_P77_S4	We incurred other exit costs associated with the production transfer, including certain contract termination costs.
103730_18_ITEM7_P78_S0	The initially-planned production transfer achieved the expected improvement in contributive margin percentage and fixed cost reduction; however, as a result of a decrease in net revenues since the plan was first initiated, gross margin for the MOSFETs segment remained below 20%.
103730_18_ITEM7_P79_S0	As a result of a review of the financial results and outlook for the MOSFETs segment following the completion of production transfers, in November 2016, we determined to implement further cost reductions for the MOSFETs segment.
103730_18_ITEM7_P80_S0	In November 2016, we announced an extension of the MOSFETs Enhanced Competitiveness Program.
103730_18_ITEM7_P80_S1	The extended program included various cost reduction initiatives, primarily the transfer of all remaining manufacturing operations at our Santa Clara, California facility to other Vishay facilities or third-party subcontractors.
103730_18_ITEM7_P81_S0	We incurred cash charges of $7.2 million, primarily related to severance, to implement these additional steps.
103730_18_ITEM7_P81_S1	We expect to realize annualized savings of approximately $8 million to $9 million as a result of these additional initiatives.
103730_18_ITEM7_P81_S2	These savings were largely achieved by the end of the third fiscal quarter of 2017.

103730_18_ITEM7_P83_S0	As a result of our cost reduction activities in our MOSFETs segment, we have established a solid and competitive cost basis for future growth.
103730_18_ITEM7_P83_S1	Segment gross profit margin has improved to acceptable levels beginning in the second fiscal quarter of 2017 (which also reflects higher revenues).

103730_18_ITEM7_P90_S0	Even as we seek to manage our costs, we continue to pursue our growth plans through investing in capacities for strategic product lines, and through increasing our resources for R D, technical marketing, and field application engineering; supplemented by opportunistic acquisitions of specialty businesses.

103730_18_ITEM7_P103_S0	We are exposed to foreign currency exchange rate risks, particularly due to transactions in currencies other than the functional currencies of certain subsidiaries.
103730_18_ITEM7_P103_S1	We occasionally use forward exchange contracts to economically hedge a portion of our projected cash flows from these exposures.
103730_18_ITEM7_P104_S0	GAAP requires that entities identify the "functional currency" of each of their subsidiaries and measure all elements of the financial statements in that functional currency.
103730_18_ITEM7_P104_S1	A subsidiary's functional currency is the currency of the primary economic environment in which it operates.
103730_18_ITEM7_P104_S2	In cases where a subsidiary is relatively self-contained within a particular country, the local currency is generally deemed to be the functional currency.
103730_18_ITEM7_P104_S3	However, a foreign subsidiary that is a direct and integral component or extension of the parent company's operations generally would have the parent company's currency as its functional currency.
103730_18_ITEM7_P104_S4	We have both situations among our subsidiaries.
103730_18_ITEM7_P105_S0	We finance our operations in Europe and certain locations in Asia in local currencies, and accordingly, these subsidiaries utilize the local currency as their functional currency.
103730_18_ITEM7_P105_S1	For those subsidiaries where the local currency is the functional currency, assets and liabilities in the consolidated balance sheets have been translated at the rate of exchange as of the balance sheet date.
103730_18_ITEM7_P105_S2	Translation adjustments do not impact the results of operations and are reported as a separate component of stockholders' equity.
103730_18_ITEM7_P106_S0	The significant weakening of the U.S. dollar versus the euro in 2017 had significant impacts on our balance sheet.
103730_18_ITEM7_P107_S0	For those subsidiaries where the local currency is the functional currency, revenues and expenses are translated at the average exchange rate for the year.
103730_18_ITEM7_P107_S1	While the translation of revenues and expenses into U.S. dollars does not directly impact the consolidated statement of operations, the translation effectively increases or decreases the U.S. dollar equivalent of revenues generated and expenses incurred in those foreign currencies.
103730_18_ITEM7_P107_S2	The dollar was weaker during 2017 versus 2016, with the translation of foreign currency revenues and expenses into U.S. dollars increasing reported revenues and expenses versus 2016.
103730_18_ITEM7_P107_S3	On a weighted average basis for the full year 2016 versus 2015, the U.S. dollar was relatively unchanged versus relevant foreign currencies, with the translation of foreign currency revenues and expenses into U.S. dollars having an immaterial impact on reported revenues and expenses versus 2015.
103730_18_ITEM7_P108_S0	Our operations in Israel and most significant locations in Asia are largely financed in U.S. dollars, and accordingly, these subsidiaries utilize the U.S. dollar as their functional currency.
103730_18_ITEM7_P108_S1	For those foreign subsidiaries where the U.S. dollar is the functional currency, all foreign currency financial statement amounts are remeasured into U.S. dollars.
103730_18_ITEM7_P108_S2	Exchange gains and losses arising from remeasurement of foreign currency-denominated monetary assets and liabilities are included in the results of operations.
103730_18_ITEM7_P108_S3	While these subsidiaries transact most business in U.S. dollars, they may have significant costs, particularly payroll-related, which are incurred in the local currency.
103730_18_ITEM7_P108_S4	The cost of products sold and selling, general, and administrative expense for the year ended December 31, 2017 have been unfavorably impacted (compared to the prior year) by local currency transactions of subsidiaries which use the U.S. dollar as their functional currency.
103730_18_ITEM7_P109_S0	See Item 7A for additional discussion of foreign currency exchange risk and forward contracts used to mitigate certain foreign currency risks.
103730_18_ITEM7_P110_S0	Our significant accounting policies are summarized in Note 1 to our consolidated financial statements.
103730_18_ITEM7_P110_S1	We identify here a number of policies that entail significant judgments or estimates.
103730_18_ITEM7_P111_S0	We recognize revenue on product sales during the period when the sales process is complete.
103730_18_ITEM7_P111_S1	This generally occurs when products are shipped to the customer in accordance with terms of an agreement of sale, title and risk of loss have been transferred, collectibility is reasonably assured, and pricing is fixed or determinable.
103730_18_ITEM7_P111_S2	For the portion of sales where title and risk of loss passes at point of delivery, we recognize revenue upon delivery to the customer, assuming all other criteria for revenue recognition are met.
103730_18_ITEM7_P112_S0	We historically have had agreements with distributors that provided limited rights of product return.
103730_18_ITEM7_P112_S1	Consistent with industry practice, we also have a "stock, ship and debit" program whereby we consider, and grant at our discretion, requests by distributors for credits on previously purchased products that remain in distributors' inventory, to enable the distributors to offer more competitive pricing.
103730_18_ITEM7_P112_S2	In addition, we have contractual arrangements whereby we provide distributors with protection against price reductions that we initiate after the sale of product to the distributor and prior to resale by the distributor.
103730_18_ITEM7_P113_S0	We record end of period accruals for each of the programs based upon our estimate of future credits under the programs that will be attributable to sales recorded through the end of the period.
103730_18_ITEM7_P113_S1	We calculate reductions of revenue attributable to each of the programs during any period by computing the change in the accruals from the prior period and adding the credits actually given to distributors during the period under the programs.
103730_18_ITEM7_P113_S2	These procedures require the exercise of significant judgments, but we believe they enable us to reasonably estimate future credits under the programs.
103730_18_ITEM7_P114_S0	Recording and monitoring of our sales accruals takes place at our subsidiaries and divisions, with input from sales and marketing personnel and review, assessment, and, if necessary, adjustment by corporate management.
103730_18_ITEM7_P114_S1	While our subsidiaries and divisions utilize different methodologies based on their individual experiences, all of the methodologies take into account certain elements that management considers relevant, such as sales to distributors during the relevant period, inventory levels at the distributors, current and projected market trends and conditions, recent and historical activity under the relevant programs, changes in program policies, and open requests for credits.
103730_18_ITEM7_P114_S2	In our judgment, the different methodologies provide us with equally reliable estimates upon which to base our accruals.
103730_18_ITEM7_P114_S3	We do not track the credits that we record against specific products sold from distributor inventories, so as to directly compare revenue reduction for credits recorded during any period with credits ultimately awarded in respect of products sold during that period.
103730_18_ITEM7_P114_S4	Nevertheless, we believe that we have an adequate basis to assess the reasonableness and reliability of our estimates.
103730_18_ITEM7_P115_S0	See Note 1 to our consolidated financial statements for information regarding recent revenue recognition guidance that has not yet been adopted.
103730_18_ITEM7_P116_S0	We value our inventories at the lower of cost or market, with cost determined under the first-in, first-out method and market based upon net realizable value.
103730_18_ITEM7_P116_S1	The valuation of our inventories requires our management to make market estimates.
103730_18_ITEM7_P116_S2	For work in process goods, we are required to estimate the cost to completion of the products and the prices at which we will be able to sell the products.
103730_18_ITEM7_P116_S3	For finished goods, we must assess the prices at which we believe the inventory can be sold.
103730_18_ITEM7_P116_S4	Inventories are also adjusted for estimated obsolescence and written down to net realizable value based upon estimates of future demand, technology developments and market conditions.
103730_18_ITEM7_P117_S0	Certain metals used in the manufacture of our products are traded on active markets, and can be subject to significant price volatility.
103730_18_ITEM7_P117_S1	Our policy is to enter into short-term commitments to purchase defined portions of annual consumption of these metals if market prices decline below budget.
103730_18_ITEM7_P117_S2	We record losses and related liabilities when the contractually obligated purchase price under our purchase commitments exceed quoted market prices for the metals.
103730_18_ITEM7_P118_S0	See Notes 1 and 3 to our consolidated financial statements for a description of our goodwill impairment tests.
103730_18_ITEM7_P119_S0	The determination of the fair value of the reporting units required for a quantitative goodwill impairment test requires us to make significant estimates and assumptions measured at a point in time.
103730_18_ITEM7_P119_S1	These estimates and assumptions primarily include, but are not limited to: the selection of appropriate peer group companies; control premiums appropriate for acquisitions in the industries in which we compete; the discount rate; terminal growth rates; and forecasts of revenue, operating income, depreciation and amortization, and capital expenditures.
103730_18_ITEM7_P120_S0	Due to the inherent uncertainty involved in making these estimates, actual financial results could differ from those estimates.
103730_18_ITEM7_P120_S1	In addition, changes in assumptions concerning future financial results or other underlying assumptions could have a significant impact on the fair value of the reporting unit and the amount of the goodwill impairment charge.
103730_18_ITEM7_P121_S0	See Notes 1 and 3 to our consolidated financial statements for a description of our long-lived assets and indefinite-lived intangible assets impairment analyses.
103730_18_ITEM7_P122_S0	The evaluation of the recoverability of long-lived assets, and the determination of their fair value, requires us to make significant estimates and assumptions measured at a point in time.
103730_18_ITEM7_P122_S1	These estimates and assumptions primarily include, but are not limited to: the identification of the asset group at the lowest level of independent cash flows and the principal asset of the group; the discount rate; terminal growth rates; and forecasts of revenue, operating income, depreciation and amortization, and capital expenditures.
103730_18_ITEM7_P123_S0	The evaluation of the fair value of indefinite-lived trademarks also requires us to make significant estimates and assumptions.
103730_18_ITEM7_P123_S1	These estimates and assumptions primarily include, but are not limited to: the assumed market-royalty rate; the discount rate; terminal growth rates; and forecasts of revenue.
103730_18_ITEM7_P124_S0	Due to the inherent uncertainty involved in making these estimates, actual results could differ from those estimates.
103730_18_ITEM7_P124_S1	In addition, changes in underlying assumptions would have a significant impact on the conclusion that an asset group's carrying value is recoverable, that an indefinite-lived asset is not impaired, or the determination of any impairment charge if it was determined that the asset values were indeed impaired.
103730_18_ITEM7_P125_S0	Our accounts receivable represent a significant portion of our current assets.
103730_18_ITEM7_P125_S1	We are required to estimate the collectibility of our receivables and to establish allowances for the amount of receivables that will prove uncollectible.
103730_18_ITEM7_P125_S2	We base these allowances on our historical collection experience, the length of time our receivables are outstanding, the financial circumstances of individual customers, and general business and economic conditions.

103730_18_ITEM7_P129_S0	The table below summarizes information about our pension and other postretirement benefit plans.
103730_18_ITEM7_P129_S1	This information should be read in conjunction with Note 11 to our consolidated financial statements (amounts in thousands):
103730_18_ITEM7_P130_S0	Accounting for defined benefit pension and other postretirement plans involves numerous assumptions and estimates.
103730_18_ITEM7_P130_S1	The discount rate at which obligations could effectively be settled and the expected long-term rate of return on plan assets are two critical assumptions in measuring the cost and benefit obligations of our pension and other postretirement benefit plans.
103730_18_ITEM7_P130_S2	Other important assumptions include the anticipated rate of future increases in compensation levels, estimated mortality, and for certain postretirement medical plans, increases or trends in health care costs.
103730_18_ITEM7_P130_S3	Management reviews these assumptions at least annually.
103730_18_ITEM7_P130_S4	We use independent actuaries and investment advisers to assist us in formulating assumptions and making estimates.
103730_18_ITEM7_P130_S5	These assumptions are updated periodically to reflect the actual experience and expectations on a plan specific basis as appropriate.
103730_18_ITEM7_P131_S0	In the U.S., we utilize published long-term high quality bonds to determine the discount rate at the measurement date.
103730_18_ITEM7_P131_S1	In Germany and the Republic of China (Taiwan), we utilize published long-term government bond rates to determine the discount rate at the measurement date.
103730_18_ITEM7_P131_S2	We utilize bond yields at various maturity dates that reflect the timing of expected future benefit payments.
103730_18_ITEM7_P131_S3	We believe the discount rates selected are the rates at which these obligations could effectively be settled.
103730_18_ITEM7_P132_S0	Non-qualified plans in the U.S. are considered by law to be unfunded.
103730_18_ITEM7_P132_S1	However, the Company maintains assets in a rabbi trust to fund benefit payments under certain of these plans.
103730_18_ITEM7_P132_S2	Such assets would be subject to creditor claims under certain conditions.
103730_18_ITEM7_P133_S0	Many of our non-U.S. plans are unfunded based on local laws and customs.
103730_18_ITEM7_P133_S1	For those non-U.S. plans that do maintain investments, their asset holdings are primarily cash and fixed income securities, based on local laws and customs.
103730_18_ITEM7_P133_S2	Some non-U.S. plans also informally fund their plans by holding certain available-for-sale investments.
103730_18_ITEM7_P133_S3	Such assets would be subject to creditor claims under certain conditions.
103730_18_ITEM7_P134_S0	We set the expected long-term rate of return based on the expected long-term average rates of return to be achieved by the underlying investment portfolios.
103730_18_ITEM7_P134_S1	In establishing this rate, we consider historical and expected returns for the asset classes in which the plans are invested, advice from pension consultants and investment advisors, and current economic and capital market conditions.
103730_18_ITEM7_P134_S2	The expected return on plan assets is incorporated into the computation of pension expense.
103730_18_ITEM7_P134_S3	The difference between this expected return and the actual return on plan assets is deferred.
103730_18_ITEM7_P135_S0	The net deferral of past asset losses (gains) affects the calculated value of plan assets and, ultimately, future pension expense (income).
103730_18_ITEM7_P136_S0	During the fourth fiscal quarter of 2008, we adopted amendments to our principal U.S. defined benefit pension plans, such that effective January 1, 2009, the plans were frozen.
103730_18_ITEM7_P136_S1	Pursuant to these amendments, no new employees may participate in the plans, no further participant contributions were required or permitted, and no further benefits accrued after December 31, 2008.

103730_18_ITEM7_P213_S0	As a result of the TCJA, we have terminated the 2015 cash repatriation plan and replaced it as described in "U.S. Tax Reform: Tax Cut and Jobs Act" above.
103730_18_ITEM7_P214_S0	We operate in a global environment with significant operations in various locations outside the United States.
103730_18_ITEM7_P214_S1	Accordingly, the consolidated income tax rate is a composite rate reflecting our earnings and the applicable tax rates in the various locations where we operate.
103730_18_ITEM7_P215_S0	Part of our historical strategy has been to achieve cost savings through the transfer and expansion of manufacturing operations to countries where we can take advantage of lower labor costs and available tax and other government-sponsored incentives.
103730_18_ITEM7_P215_S1	Accordingly, our effective tax rate has historically been less than the U.S. statutory rate, except in years where there are material discrete items.
103730_18_ITEM7_P216_S0	The TCJA significantly reduces the U.S. statutory tax rate, to a rate that is less than the applicable tax rates of many of the jurisdictions in which we operate.
103730_18_ITEM7_P216_S1	Furthermore, our GAAP interest expense generally exceeds our U.S.-based operating income, resulting in pre-tax losses in the U.S.
103730_18_ITEM7_P216_S2	Accordingly, we have historically recorded U.S. federal tax benefits, at 35%, which had the effect of reducing our consolidated GAAP tax rate.
103730_18_ITEM7_P216_S3	Accordingly, the reduction in the statutory U.S. tax rate will generally increase our consolidated GAAP tax rate due to the loss of these tax benefits recognized on a GAAP basis.
103730_18_ITEM7_P216_S4	We are still evaluating the effects of the TCJA on our future effective tax rate.
103730_18_ITEM7_P216_S5	Other actions independent of the TCJA will also impact the future effective tax rate.
103730_18_ITEM7_P217_S0	Additional information about income taxes is included in Note 5 to our consolidated financial statements.

103730_18_ITEM7_P227_S0	The amended and restated credit facility allows an unlimited amount of defined "Restricted Payments," which include cash dividends to stockholders and share repurchases, provided our pro forma leverage ratio is less than 2.25 to 1.
103730_18_ITEM7_P227_S1	If our leverage ratio is greater than 2.25 to 1, the credit facility allows such payments up to $75 million per annum (subject to a cap of $225 million for the term of the facility).
103730_18_ITEM7_P227_S2	The amended and restated credit facility provides us with significantly more flexibility to execute these transactions, and our ability to utilize some of our foreign-source income for these types of transactions provides even further financial flexibility.
103730_18_ITEM7_P228_S0	Borrowings under the credit facility bear interest at LIBOR plus an interest margin.
103730_18_ITEM7_P228_S1	The applicable interest margin is based on our leverage ratio.
103730_18_ITEM7_P228_S2	Based on our current leverage ratio, borrowings bear interest at LIBOR plus 1.75%.
103730_18_ITEM7_P228_S3	The interest rate on our borrowings will increase to LIBOR plus 2.00% if our leverage ratio equals or exceeds 2.50 to 1 and will decrease to LIBOR plus 1.50% if our leverage ratio decreases below 1.50 to 1.
103730_18_ITEM7_P229_S0	We also pay a fee, also based on our leverage ratio, on undrawn amounts.
103730_18_ITEM7_P229_S1	The undrawn commitment fee, based on our current leverage ratio, is 0.35% per annum.
103730_18_ITEM7_P229_S2	Such undrawn commitment fee will increase to 0.50% per annum if our leverage ratio equals or exceeds 2.50 to 1 and will decrease to 0.30% per annum if our leverage ratio decreases below 1.50 to 1.

103730_18_ITEM7_P245_S1	As these investments were funded using a portion of excess cash and represent a significant aspect of our cash management strategy, we include the investments in the calculation of net cash and short-term investments (debt).

103730_18_ITEM7A_P0_S0	We are exposed to certain financial risks, including fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, interest rates, and commodity prices.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P0_S1	We manage our exposure to these market risks through internally established policies and procedures and, when deemed appropriate, through the use of derivative financial instruments.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P0_S2	Our policies do not allow speculation in derivative instruments for profit or execution of derivative instrument contracts for which there are no underlying exposures.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P0_S3	We do not use financial instruments for trading purposes and we are not a party to any leveraged derivatives.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P0_S4	We monitor our underlying market risk exposures on an ongoing basis and believe that we can modify or adapt our hedging strategies as needed.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P1_S0	We are exposed to changes in interest rates as a result of our borrowing activities and our cash balances.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P1_S1	On a selective basis, we have in the past entered into interest rate swap or cap agreements to reduce the potential negative impact that increases in interest rates could have on our outstanding variable rate debt.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P1_S2	As of December 31, 2017, 2016, and 2015 we did not have any outstanding interest rate swap or cap agreements.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P2_S0	The interest paid on our credit facility is based on a LIBOR spread.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P2_S1	At December 31, 2017, we had $150.0 million outstanding under the revolving credit facility.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P2_S2	The present amounts outstanding under the revolving credit commitment bears interest at LIBOR plus 1.75%.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P3_S0	Our convertible senior debentures due 2040, due 2041, and due 2042 bear interest at a fixed rate, and accordingly are not subject to interest rate fluctuation risks.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P4_S0	At December 31, 2017, we have $748.0 million of cash and cash equivalents and $547.1 million of short-term investments, which earn interest at various variable rates.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P5_S0	Based on the debt and cash positions at December 31, 2017, we would expect a 50 basis point increase or decrease in interest rates to increase or decrease our annualized net earnings by approximately $4.0 million.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P6_S0	See Note 6 to our consolidated financial statements for additional information about our long-term debt.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P6_S1	Also see "Economic Outlook and Impact on Operations and Future Financial Results" included in Item 7, "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations" for additional discussion of market risks.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P7_S0	We are exposed to foreign currency exchange rate risks, particularly due to market values of transactions in currencies other than the functional currencies of certain subsidiaries.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P7_S1	We use forward exchange contracts to economically hedge a portion of these exposures.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P8_S0	We entered into forward contracts with highly-rated financial institutions to mitigate the foreign currency risk associated with intercompany loans denominated in a currency other than the legal entity's functional currency.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P8_S1	The notional amount of the forward contracts was $100 million as of December 31, 2017.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P8_S2	The forward contracts are short-term in nature and are expected to be renewed at our discretion until the intercompany loans are repaid.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P8_S3	We have not designated the forward contracts as hedges for accounting purposes, and as such the change in the fair value of contracts is recognized in our consolidated statements of operations as a component of other income (expense).
103730_18_ITEM7A_P9_S0	We do not utilize derivatives or other financial instruments for trading or other speculative purposes.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P10_S0	Our significant foreign subsidiaries are located in Germany, Israel, and Asia.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P10_S1	We finance our operations in Europe and certain locations in Asia in local currencies.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P10_S2	Our operations in Israel and most significant locations in Asia are largely financed in U.S. dollars, but these subsidiaries also have significant transactions in local currencies.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P10_S3	Our exposure to foreign currency risk is mitigated to the extent that the costs incurred and the revenues earned in a particular currency offset one another.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P10_S4	Our exposure to foreign currency risk is more pronounced in Israel, the Czech Republic, and China because the percentage of expenses denominated in Israeli shekels, Czech koruna, and Chinese renminbi to total expenses is much greater than the percentage of sales denominated in Israeli shekels, Czech koruna, and Chinese renminbi to total sales.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P10_S5	Therefore, if the Israeli shekel, Czech koruna, and Chinese renminbi strengthen against all or most of our other major currencies, our operating profit is reduced.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P10_S6	Where possible, we maintain local currency denominated cash balances in these countries approximately equal to the local currency liabilities to naturally hedge our exposures.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P10_S7	We also have a slightly higher percentage of euro-denominated sales than expenses.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P10_S8	Therefore, when the euro strengthens against all or most of our other major currencies, our operating profit is slightly increased.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P10_S9	Accordingly, we monitor several important cross-rates.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P11_S0	We have performed sensitivity analyses of our consolidated foreign exchange risk as of December 31, 2017 and 2016, using a model that measures the change in the values arising from a hypothetical 10% adverse movement in foreign currency exchange rates relative to the U.S. dollar, with all other variables held constant.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P11_S1	The foreign currency exchange rates we used were based on market rates in effect at December 31, 2017 and 2016.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P11_S2	The sensitivity analyses indicated that a hypothetical 10% adverse movement in foreign currency exchange rates would impact our net earnings by approximately $9.0 million and $9.1 million at December 31, 2017 and December 31, 2016, respectively, although individual line items in our consolidated statement of operations would be materially affected.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P11_S3	For example, a 10% weakening in all foreign currencies would decrease the U.S. dollar equivalent of operating income generated in foreign currencies, which would be offset by foreign exchange gains of our foreign subsidiaries that have significant transactions in U.S. dollars or have the U.S. dollar as their functional currency.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P12_S0	A change in the mix of the currencies in which we transact our business could have a material effect on the estimated impact of the hypothetical 10% movement in the value of the U.S. dollar.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P12_S1	Furthermore, the timing of cash receipts and disbursements could result in materially different actual results versus the hypothetical 10% movement in the value of the U.S. dollar, particularly if there are significant changes in exchange rates in a short period of time.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P13_S0	Although most materials incorporated in our products are available from a number of sources, certain materials are available only from a relatively limited number of suppliers or are subject to significant price volatility.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P13_S1	Our results of operations may be materially and adversely affected if we have difficulty obtaining these raw materials, the quality of available raw materials deteriorates, or there are significant price changes for these raw materials.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P13_S2	The determination that any of the raw materials used in our products are conflict minerals originating from the Democratic Republic of the Congo and adjoining countries could increase the probability that we will encounter the challenges noted above, incur additional expenses to comply with government regulations, and face public scrutiny.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P13_S3	For periods in which the prices of these raw materials are rising, we may be unable to pass on the increased cost to our customers which would result in decreased margins for the products in which they are used.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P13_S4	For periods in which the prices are declining, we may be required to write down our inventory carrying cost of these raw materials, since we record our inventory at the lower of cost or market.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P13_S5	Depending on the extent of the difference between market price and our carrying cost, this write-down could have a material adverse effect on our net earnings.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P13_S6	We also may need to record losses for adverse purchase commitments for these materials in periods of declining prices.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P14_S0	Silicon wafers are the most important raw material for the manufacturing of our semiconductor products.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P15_S0	Silicon wafers are manufactured from high-purity silicon, a metalloid.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P15_S1	There have at times been industry-wide shortages of high-purity silicon resulting primarily from growing demand of the electronic component and solar power industries, and limited growth in high-purity silicon manufacturing capacities.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P15_S2	Shifts in demand for high-purity silicon and in turn, silicon wafers, have resulted in significant fluctuation in prices of silicon wafers.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P16_S0	We are a major consumer of the world's annual production of tantalum, a metal used in the manufacturing of tantalum capacitors.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P16_S1	There are few suppliers that process tantalum ore into capacitor grade tantalum powder.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P17_S0	Palladium, a metal used to produce multi-layer ceramic capacitors, is currently found primarily in South Africa and Russia.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P17_S1	Palladium is a commodity metal that is subject to price volatility.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P17_S2	We periodically enter into short-term commitments to purchase palladium.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P18_S0	Certain metals used in the manufacture of our products, such as copper, are traded on active markets, and can be subject to significant price volatility.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P18_S1	Our policy is to enter into short-term commitments to purchase defined portions of annual consumption of these metals if market prices decline below budget.
103730_18_ITEM7A_P19_S0	We estimate that a 10% increase or decrease in the costs of raw materials subject to commodity price risk would decrease or increase our net earnings by $6.1 million, assuming that such changes in our costs have no impact on the selling prices of our products and that we have no pending commitments to purchase metals at fixed prices.

103730_18_ITEM15_P80_S0	To the Board of Directors and Stockholders of Vishay Intertechnology, Inc.
103730_18_ITEM15_P81_S0	We have audited Vishay Intertechnology, Inc.'s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2017, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (2013 framework) (the COSO criteria).
103730_18_ITEM15_P81_S1	In our opinion, Vishay Intertechnology, Inc. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2017, based on the COSO criteria.
103730_18_ITEM15_P82_S0	We have also audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States) (PCAOB), the consolidated balance sheets of Vishay Intertechnology, Inc. as of December 31, 2017 and 2016, and the related consolidated statements of operations, comprehensive income, stockholders' equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2017, and the related notes (collectively referred to as the "financial statements") and our report dated February 16, 2018 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.
103730_18_ITEM15_P83_S0	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company's internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
103730_18_ITEM15_P83_S1	We are a public accounting firm registered with the PCAOB and are required to be independent with respect to the Company in accordance with the U.S. federal securities laws and the applicable rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the PCAOB.
103730_18_ITEM15_P84_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the PCAOB.
103730_18_ITEM15_P84_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
103730_18_ITEM15_P85_S0	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
103730_18_ITEM15_P85_S1	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
103730_18_ITEM15_P86_S0	A company's internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
103730_18_ITEM15_P86_S1	A company's internal control over financial reporting incudes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of the financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of managements and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company's assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
103730_18_ITEM15_P87_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect material misstatements.
103730_18_ITEM15_P87_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to provide future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
103730_18_ITEM15_P88_S0	Vishay Intertechnology, Inc. ("Vishay" or the "Company") is a global manufacturer and supplier of semiconductors and passive components, including power MOSFETs, power integrated circuits, transistors, diodes, optoelectronic components, resistors, capacitors, and inductors.
103730_18_ITEM15_P88_S1	Semiconductors and electronic components manufactured by the Company are used in virtually all types of electronic products, including those in the industrial, computing, automotive, consumer electronics products, telecommunications, power supplies, military/aerospace, and medical industries.
103730_18_ITEM15_P89_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States ("GAAP") requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes.
103730_18_ITEM15_P89_S1	Actual results could differ significantly from those estimates.
103730_18_ITEM15_P90_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Vishay and all of its subsidiaries in which a controlling financial interest is maintained.
103730_18_ITEM15_P90_S1	For those consolidated subsidiaries in which the Company's ownership is less than 100 percent, the outside stockholders' interests are shown as noncontrolling interest in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
103730_18_ITEM15_P90_S2	Investments in affiliates over which the Company has significant influence but not a controlling interest are carried on the equity basis.
103730_18_ITEM15_P90_S3	Investments in affiliates over which the Company does not have significant influence are accounted for by the cost method.
103730_18_ITEM15_P90_S4	All intercompany transactions, accounts, and profits are eliminated.
103730_18_ITEM15_P91_S0	The Company recognizes revenue on product sales during the period when the sales process is complete.
103730_18_ITEM15_P91_S1	This generally occurs when products are shipped to the customer in accordance with terms of an agreement of sale, title and risk of loss have been transferred, collectibility is reasonably assured, and pricing is fixed or determinable.
103730_18_ITEM15_P91_S2	For the portion of sales where title and risk of loss passes at point of delivery, the Company recognizes revenue upon delivery to the customer, assuming all other criteria for revenue recognition are met.
103730_18_ITEM15_P92_S0	The Company historically has had agreements with distributors that provided limited rights of product return.
103730_18_ITEM15_P92_S1	Consistent with industry practice, the Company also has a "stock, ship and debit" program whereby it considers requests by distributors for credits on previously purchased products that remain in distributors' inventory, to enable the distributors to offer more competitive pricing.
103730_18_ITEM15_P92_S2	In addition, the Company has contractual arrangements whereby it provides distributors with protection against price reductions initiated by the Company after product is sold by the Company to the distributor and prior to resale by the distributor.
103730_18_ITEM15_P93_S0	The Company records a reduction of revenue during each period, and records a related accrued expense for the period, based upon its estimate of product returns, scrap allowances, "stock, ship and debit" credits, and price protection credits that will be attributable to sales recorded through the end of the period.
103730_18_ITEM15_P93_S1	The Company makes these estimates based upon sales levels to its distributors during the period, inventory levels at the distributors, current and projected market conditions, and historical experience under the programs.
103730_18_ITEM15_P93_S2	While the Company utilizes a number of different methodologies to estimate the accruals, all of the methodologies take into account sales levels to distributors during the relevant period, inventory levels at the distributors, current and projected market trends and conditions, recent and historical activity under the relevant programs, changes in program policies, and open requests for credits.
103730_18_ITEM15_P93_S3	These procedures require the exercise of significant judgments.
103730_18_ITEM15_P93_S4	The Company believes that it has a reasonable basis to estimate future credits under the programs.
103730_18_ITEM15_P94_S0	Shipping and handling costs are included in costs of products sold.
103730_18_ITEM15_P95_S0	Research and development costs are expensed as incurred.
103730_18_ITEM15_P95_S1	The amount charged to expense for research and development (exclusive of purchased in-process research and development) aggregated $67,153, $66,842, and $64,193, for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016, and 2015, respectively.
103730_18_ITEM15_P95_S2	The Company spends additional amounts for the development of machinery and equipment for new processes and for cost reduction measures.
103730_18_ITEM15_P96_S0	The provision for income taxes is determined using the asset and liability approach of accounting for income taxes.
103730_18_ITEM15_P96_S1	Under this approach, deferred taxes represent the future tax consequences expected to occur when the reported amounts of assets and liabilities are recovered or paid.
103730_18_ITEM15_P97_S0	The provision for income taxes represents income taxes paid or payable for the current year plus the change in deferred taxes during the year.
103730_18_ITEM15_P97_S1	Deferred taxes result from differences between the financial and tax bases of the Company's assets and liabilities and are adjusted for changes in tax rates and tax laws when changes are enacted.
103730_18_ITEM15_P97_S2	Valuation allowances have been established for deferred tax assets which the Company believes do not meet GAAP criteria of "more likely than not" to be realized.
103730_18_ITEM15_P97_S3	This criterion requires a level of judgment regarding future taxable income, which may be revised due to changes in market conditions, tax laws, or other factors.
103730_18_ITEM15_P97_S4	If the Company's assumptions and estimates change in the future, valuation allowances established may be increased, resulting in increased tax expense.
103730_18_ITEM15_P97_S5	Conversely, if the Company is ultimately able to utilize all or a portion of the deferred tax assets for which a valuation allowance has been established, then the related portion of the valuation allowance can be released, resulting in decreased tax expense.
103730_18_ITEM15_P98_S0	The Company and its subsidiaries are subject to income taxes in the U.S. and numerous foreign jurisdictions.
103730_18_ITEM15_P98_S1	Significant judgment is required in evaluating the Company's tax positions and determining its provision for income taxes.
103730_18_ITEM15_P99_S0	During the ordinary course of business, there are many transactions and calculations for which the ultimate tax determination is uncertain.
103730_18_ITEM15_P99_S1	The Company establishes reserves for tax-related uncertainties based on estimates of whether, and the extent to which, additional taxes will be due.
103730_18_ITEM15_P99_S2	These reserves are established when the Company believes that certain positions might be challenged despite the Company's belief that its tax return positions are fully supportable.
103730_18_ITEM15_P99_S3	The Company adjusts these reserves in light of changing facts and circumstances and the provision for income taxes includes the impact of reserve provisions and changes to reserves that are considered appropriate.
103730_18_ITEM15_P100_S0	These accruals for tax-related uncertainties are based on management's best estimate of potential tax exposures.
103730_18_ITEM15_P100_S1	When particular matters arise, a number of years may elapse before such matters are audited by tax authorities and finally resolved.
103730_18_ITEM15_P100_S2	Favorable resolution of such matters could be recognized as a reduction to the Company's effective tax rate in the year of resolution.
103730_18_ITEM15_P100_S3	Unfavorable resolution of any particular issue could increase the effective tax rate and may require the use of cash in the year of resolution.

103730_18_ITEM15_P112_S0	GAAP prescribes a quantitative method for determining goodwill impairment.
103730_18_ITEM15_P112_S1	The Company has the option of performing a qualitative assessment before performing the quantitative impairment test.
103730_18_ITEM15_P112_S2	If it is determined, on the basis of qualitative factors, that the fair value of the reporting unit is not more likely than not less than the carrying amount, the quantitative impairment test is not required.
103730_18_ITEM15_P112_S3	If it is determined that the fair value of the reporting unit is more likely than not less than the carrying amount, the quantitative impairment test is required.
103730_18_ITEM15_P113_S0	The Company determines the fair value of the reporting unit and compares that fair value to the net book value of the reporting unit.
103730_18_ITEM15_P113_S1	The fair value of the reporting unit is determined using various valuation techniques, including a comparable companies market multiple approach and a discounted cash flow analysis (an income approach).
103730_18_ITEM15_P113_S2	If the net book value of the reporting unit were to exceed the fair value, the Company would recognize an impairment charge.
103730_18_ITEM15_P114_S0	The carrying value of long-lived assets held-and-used, other than goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets, is evaluated when events or changes in circumstances indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable or the useful life has changed.
103730_18_ITEM15_P114_S1	The carrying value of a long-lived asset group is considered impaired when the total projected undiscounted cash flows from such asset group are separately identifiable and are less than the carrying value.
103730_18_ITEM15_P114_S2	In that event, a loss is recognized based on the amount by which the carrying value exceeds the fair market value of the long-lived asset group.
103730_18_ITEM15_P115_S0	Fair market value is determined primarily using present value techniques based on projected cash flows from the asset group.
103730_18_ITEM15_P115_S1	Losses on long-lived assets held-for-sale, other than goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets, are determined in a similar manner, except that fair market values are reduced for anticipated disposal costs.
103730_18_ITEM15_P116_S0	See Note 3 for further information on the impairment tests performed in 2016 and 2015.

103730_18_ITEM15_P146_S0	On December 22, 2017, the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (the "TCJA") was enacted in the United States.
103730_18_ITEM15_P146_S1	The TCJA represents sweeping changes in U.S. tax law.
103730_18_ITEM15_P146_S2	Under GAAP (specifically, Accounting Standards Codification ("ASC") Topic 740), the effects of changes in tax rates and laws on deferred tax balances are recognized in the period in which the new legislation is enacted.
103730_18_ITEM15_P146_S3	The total effect of tax law changes on deferred tax balances is recorded as a component of income tax expense.
103730_18_ITEM15_P147_S0	In response to the TCJA, the Staff of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission issued Staff Accounting Bulletin No. 118 ("SAB No. 118") to provide guidance to registrants in applying ASC Topic 740 in connection with the TCJA.
103730_18_ITEM15_P147_S1	SAB No. 118 provides that in the period of enactment, the income tax effects of the TCJA may be reported as a provisional amount based on a reasonable estimate (to the extent a reasonable estimate can be determined), which would be subject to adjustment during a "measurement period".
103730_18_ITEM15_P147_S2	The measurement period begins in the reporting period of the TCJA's enactment and ends when a registrant has obtained, prepared, and analyzed the information that was needed in order to complete the accounting requirements under ASC Topic 740.
103730_18_ITEM15_P147_S3	SAB No. 118 also describes supplemental disclosures that should accompany the provisional amounts.
103730_18_ITEM15_P147_S4	The Company has applied the guidance in SAB No. 118 to account for the financial accounting impacts of the TCJA as of December 31, 2017, and has provided the applicable supplemental disclosures in Note 5.
103730_18_ITEM15_P148_S0	In May 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606) .
103730_18_ITEM15_P148_S1	The ASU is the result of a convergence project between the FASB and the International Accounting Standards Board to clarify the principles for recognizing revenue and to develop a common revenue standard for GAAP and International Financial Reporting Standards.
103730_18_ITEM15_P148_S2	The ASU removes inconsistencies and weaknesses in revenue requirements; provides a more robust framework for addressing revenue issues; improves comparability of revenue recognition practices across entities, industries, jurisdictions, and capital markets; provides more useful information to users of financial statements through expanded disclosure requirements; and simplifies the preparation of financial statements by reducing the number of requirements to which an entity must refer.
103730_18_ITEM15_P148_S3	The ASU is effective for the Company for interim and annual periods beginning on or after January 1, 2018.
103730_18_ITEM15_P148_S4	The Company intends to retrospectively adopt the ASU effective January 1, 2018.

103730_18_ITEM15_P167_S1	The calculated results are evaluated for reasonableness using comparable company data.

103730_18_ITEM15_P168_S1	These estimates and assumptions primarily include, but are not limited to: the selection of appropriate peer group companies; control premiums appropriate for acquisitions in the industries in which the Company competes; the discount rate; terminal growth rates; and forecasts of revenue, operating income, depreciation and amortization, and capital expenditures.
103730_18_ITEM15_P169_S0	Due to the inherent uncertainty involved in making these estimates, actual financial results could differ from those estimates.
103730_18_ITEM15_P169_S1	Changes in assumptions concerning future financial results or other underlying assumptions could have a significant impact on either the fair value of the reporting unit or the amount of the goodwill impairment charge; could have a significant impact on the conclusion that an asset group's carrying value is recoverable, that an indefinite-lived asset is not impaired, or the determination of any impairment charge if it was determined that the asset values were indeed impaired.

103730_18_ITEM15_P196_S0	On December 22, 2017, the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (the "TCJA") was enacted in the United States.
103730_18_ITEM15_P196_S1	The TCJA represents sweeping changes in U.S. tax law.
103730_18_ITEM15_P196_S2	Among the numerous changes in tax law, the TCJA permanently reduces the U.S. corporate income tax rate to 21% beginning in 2018; imposes a one-time transition tax on deferred foreign earnings; establishes a participation exemption system by allowing a 100% dividends received deduction on qualifying dividends paid by foreign subsidiaries; limits deductions for net interest expense; and expands the U.S. taxation of foreign earned income to include "global intangible low-taxed income" ("GILTI").
103730_18_ITEM15_P197_S0	The TCJA represents the first significant change in U.S. tax law in over 30 years.
103730_18_ITEM15_P198_S0	As permitted by SAB No. 118 (see Note 1), the tax expense recorded in the fourth fiscal quarter of 2017 due to the enactment of the TCJA is considered "provisional," based on reasonable estimates.
103730_18_ITEM15_P198_S1	The Company is continuing to collect and analyze detailed information about the earnings and profits of its non-U.S. subsidiaries, the related taxes paid, the amounts which could be repatriated, the foreign taxes which may be incurred on repatriation, and the associated impact of these items under the TCJA.
103730_18_ITEM15_P198_S2	The Company may record adjustments to refine those estimates during the measurement period, as additional analysis is completed.
103730_18_ITEM15_P198_S3	Furthermore, the Company is continuing to evaluate the TCJA's provisions and may prospectively adjust its financial structure and business practices accordingly.
103730_18_ITEM15_P199_S0	As a result of the TCJA, the Company recognized a provisional tax benefit of $74,816 to remeasure its net deferred tax liabilities at the lower, 21% rate.
103730_18_ITEM15_P200_S0	The TCJA transitions the U.S. from a worldwide tax system to a territorial tax system.
103730_18_ITEM15_P201_S0	Under previous law, companies could indefinitely defer U.S. income taxation on unremitted foreign earnings.
103730_18_ITEM15_P201_S1	The TCJA imposes a one-time transition tax on deferred foreign earnings of 15.5% for liquid assets and 8% for illiquid assets, payable in defined increments over eight years.
103730_18_ITEM15_P201_S2	As a result of this requirement, the Company recognized provisional tax expense of $215,558, and provisionally expects to pay $180,000, net of estimated applicable foreign tax credits, and after utilization of net operating loss and R D and FTC Credit carryforwards.
103730_18_ITEM15_P201_S3	These previously deferred foreign earnings may now be repatriated to the United States without additional U.S. federal taxation.
103730_18_ITEM15_P201_S4	However, any such repatriation could incur withholding and other foreign taxes in the source and intervening foreign jurisdictions, and certain U.S. state taxes.
103730_18_ITEM15_P202_S0	Due to the changes in taxation of dividends received from foreign subsidiaries, and also because of the need to finance the payment of the transition tax, the Company has made the determination during the fourth fiscal quarter of 2017 that certain unremitted foreign earnings in Israel, Germany, Austria, and France are no longer permanently reinvested, and has recorded provisional tax expense of $213,000 to accrue the incremental foreign income taxes and withholding taxes payable to foreign jurisdictions assuming the hypothetical repatriation to the United States of these approximately $1,100,000 of available foreign earnings.
103730_18_ITEM15_P202_S1	Due to the existence of the foreign cash taxes payable at the source, the Company expects to actually repatriate these amounts at a measured pace over several years, and may decide to ultimately not repatriate some of these amounts.
103730_18_ITEM15_P203_S0	There are additional amounts of unremitted foreign earnings in other countries, which continue to be reinvested indefinitely, and the Company has made no provision for incremental foreign income taxes and withholding taxes payable to foreign jurisdictions related to these amounts.
103730_18_ITEM15_P203_S1	Determination of the amount of the unrecognized deferred foreign tax liability for these amounts is not practicable because of the complexities associated with its hypothetical calculation.
103730_18_ITEM15_P204_S0	During the fourth fiscal quarter of 2015, the Company recognized income tax, including U.S. federal and state income taxes, incremental foreign income taxes, and withholding taxes payable to foreign jurisdictions, on $300,000 of foreign earnings.
103730_18_ITEM15_P204_S1	This tax expense was recognized in 2015 following an evaluation of the Company's anticipated domestic cash needs over the next several years and the Company's most efficient use of liquidity, and with consideration of the amount of cash that could be repatriated to the U.S. efficiently with lesser withholding taxes in foreign jurisdictions.
103730_18_ITEM15_P204_S2	The Company repatriated $38,000 and $46,000 pursuant to this program in 2017 and 2016, respectively.
103730_18_ITEM15_P204_S3	Prior to the enactment of the TCJA, the related deferred tax liability for the 2015 repatriation plan was $118,887.
103730_18_ITEM15_P204_S4	The Company has terminated the 2015 cash repatriation plan and recorded a provisional income tax benefit to reverse this deferred tax liability, which was replaced by the liability for the transition tax and foreign income and withholding taxes described above.
103730_18_ITEM15_P205_S0	The deferred tax liability related to these unremitted foreign earnings is based on the available sources of cash, applicable tax rates, foreign currency exchange rates, and other factors and circumstances, as of each balance sheet date.
103730_18_ITEM15_P205_S1	Changes in these underlying facts and circumstances result in changes in the deferred tax liability balance, which are recorded as tax benefit or expense.
103730_18_ITEM15_P206_S0	The Company has elected to account for GILTI tax in the period in which it is incurred, and therefore has not provided any deferred tax impacts of GILTI in its consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2017.
