103730_18_ITEM15_P226_S0	Long-term debt consists of the following:
103730_18_ITEM15_P227_S0	The Company maintains a credit facility with a consortium of banks led by JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A., as administrative agent (the "Credit Facility").
103730_18_ITEM15_P227_S1	On December 10, 2015, the Company entered into an Amended and Restated Credit Agreement, which provides an aggregate commitment of $640,000 of revolving loans available until December 10, 2020.
103730_18_ITEM15_P227_S2	The credit agreement initially became effective December 1, 2010 and was first amended and restated on August 8, 2013.
103730_18_ITEM15_P227_S3	The Credit Facility, as amended and restated, also provides for the ability of Vishay to request up to $50,000 of incremental revolving commitments, subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions.
103730_18_ITEM15_P228_S0	Borrowings under the Amended and Restated Credit Facility bear interest at LIBOR plus an interest margin.
103730_18_ITEM15_P228_S1	The applicable interest margin is based on Vishay's leverage ratio.
103730_18_ITEM15_P229_S0	Based on Vishay's current leverage ratio, borrowings bear interest at LIBOR plus 1.75%.
103730_18_ITEM15_P229_S1	Vishay also pays a fee, also based on its leverage ratio, on undrawn amounts.
103730_18_ITEM15_P229_S2	The undrawn commitment fee, based on Vishay's current leverage ratio, is 0.35% per annum.
103730_18_ITEM15_P229_S3	The previous credit agreement required Vishay to pay facility fees on the entire commitment amount.
103730_18_ITEM15_P230_S0	The Amended and Restated Credit Facility allows an unlimited amount of defined "Restricted Payments," which include cash dividends and share repurchases, provided the Company's pro forma leverage ratio is less than 2.25 to 1.
103730_18_ITEM15_P230_S1	If the Company's leverage ratio is greater than 2.25 to 1, the Amended and Restated Credit Facility allows such payments up to $75,000 per annum (subject to a cap of $225,000 for the term of the facility).
103730_18_ITEM15_P231_S0	The borrowings under the Credit Facility are secured by a lien on substantially all assets, including accounts receivable, inventory, machinery and equipment, and general intangibles (but excluding real estate, intellectual property registered or licensed for use in, or arising under the laws of, any country other than the United States, assets located outside of the United States and deposit and securities accounts), of Vishay and certain significant subsidiaries located in the United States, and pledges of stock in certain significant domestic and foreign subsidiaries; and are guaranteed by certain significant subsidiaries.
103730_18_ITEM15_P231_S1	Certain of the Company's subsidiaries are permitted to borrow under the Credit Facility, subject to the satisfaction of specified conditions.
103730_18_ITEM15_P231_S2	Any borrowings by these subsidiaries under the Credit Facility are guaranteed by Vishay and certain subsidiaries.
103730_18_ITEM15_P231_S3	The Credit Facility also limits or restricts the Company and its subsidiaries, from, among other things, incurring indebtedness, incurring liens on its respective assets, making investments and acquisitions, making asset sales, and making other restricted payments (assuming the Company's leverage ratio is greater than 2.25 to 1), and requires the Company to comply with other covenants, including the maintenance of specific financial ratios.
103730_18_ITEM15_P232_S0	The Amended and Restated Credit Facility also removes certain restrictions related to intercompany transactions.
103730_18_ITEM15_P232_S1	These changes are expected to enable the Company to streamline its complex subsidiary structure and provide greater operating flexibility.
103730_18_ITEM15_P233_S0	The Credit Facility also contains customary events of default, including, but not limited to, failure to pay principal or interest, failure to pay or default under other material debt, material misrepresentation or breach of warranty, violation of certain covenants, a change of control, the commencement of bankruptcy proceedings, the insolvency of Vishay or certain of its significant subsidiaries, and the rendering of a judgment in excess of $25,000 against Vishay or certain of its significant subsidiaries.
103730_18_ITEM15_P233_S1	Upon the occurrence of an event of default under the Credit Facility, the Company's obligations under the credit facility may be accelerated and the lending commitments under the credit facility terminated.
103730_18_ITEM15_P234_S0	At December 31, 2017 and 2016, there was $486,211 and $490,136, respectively, available under the Credit Facility.

103730_18_ITEM15_P235_S0	Vishay currently has three issuances of convertible senior debentures outstanding with generally congruent terms.

103730_18_ITEM15_P237_S0	Prior to three months before the maturity date, the holders may only convert their debentures under the following circumstances: (1) during any fiscal quarter after the first full quarter subsequent to issuance, if the sale price of Vishay common stock reaches 130% of the conversion price for a specified period; (2) the trading price of the debentures falls below 98% of the product of the sale price of Vishay's common stock and the conversion rate for a specified period; (3) Vishay calls any or all of the debentures for redemption, at any time prior to the close of business on the third scheduled trading day immediately preceding the redemption date; or (4) upon the occurrence of specified corporate events.
103730_18_ITEM15_P238_S0	The convertible debentures due 2042 became convertible subsequent to the December 31, 2016 evaluation of the conversion criteria, remained convertible subsequent to the April 1, 2017, July 1, 2017, and September 30, 2017 evaluations, and remain convertible subsequent to the December 31, 2017 evaluation due to the sale price of Vishay's common stock exceeding 130% of the conversion price for the applicable periods in the fourth fiscal quarter of 2016 and first, second, third, and fourth fiscal quarters of 2017.
103730_18_ITEM15_P238_S1	The convertible debentures due 2040 became convertible subsequent to the September 30, 2017 evaluation of the conversion criteria, and remain convertible subsequent to the December 31, 2017 evaluation due to the sale price of Vishay's common stock exceeding 130% of the conversion price for the applicable periods in the third and fourth fiscal quarters of 2017.

103730_18_ITEM15_P301_S0	The plans' expected return on assets is based on management's expectations of long-term average rates of return to be achieved by the underlying investment portfolios.
103730_18_ITEM15_P301_S1	In establishing this assumption, management considers historical and expected returns for the asset classes in which the plans are invested, advice from pension consultants and investment advisors, and current economic and capital market conditions.
103730_18_ITEM15_P302_S0	The investment mix between equity securities and fixed income securities is based upon achieving a desired return, balancing higher return, more volatile equity securities, and lower return, less volatile fixed income securities and is adjusted for the expected duration of the obligation and the funded status of the plan.

103730_18_ITEM15_P360_S0	Many of the Company's products require the use of raw materials that are produced in only a limited number of regions around the world or are available from only a limited number of suppliers.
103730_18_ITEM15_P360_S1	The Company's consolidated results of operations may be materially and adversely affected if there are significant price increases for these raw materials, the Company has difficulty obtaining these raw materials, or the quality of available raw materials deteriorates.
103730_18_ITEM15_P360_S2	For periods in which the prices of these raw materials are rising, the Company may be unable to pass on the increased cost to the Company's customers, which would result in decreased margins for the products in which they are used.
103730_18_ITEM15_P360_S3	For periods in which the prices are declining, the Company may be required to write down its inventory carrying cost of these raw materials which, depending on the extent of the difference between market price and its carrying cost, could have a material adverse effect on the Company's net earnings.
103730_18_ITEM15_P361_S0	Vishay is a major consumer of the world's annual production of tantalum.
103730_18_ITEM15_P362_S0	Tantalum, a metal purchased in powder or wire form, is the principal material used in the manufacture of tantalum capacitors.
103730_18_ITEM15_P362_S1	There are few suppliers that process tantalum ore into capacitor grade tantalum powder.
103730_18_ITEM15_P363_S0	From time to time, there have been short-term market shortages of raw materials utilized by the Company.
103730_18_ITEM15_P363_S1	While these shortages have not historically adversely affected the Company's ability to increase production of products containing these raw materials, they have historically resulted in higher raw material costs for the Company.
103730_18_ITEM15_P363_S2	The Company cannot assure that any of these market shortages in the future would not adversely affect the Company's ability to increase production, particularly during periods of growing demand for the Company's products.
103730_18_ITEM15_P364_S0	Certain raw materials used in the manufacture of the Company's products, such as gold, copper, palladium, and other metals, are traded on active markets and can be subject to significant price volatility.
103730_18_ITEM15_P364_S1	To ensure adequate supply and to provide cost certainty, the Company's policy is to enter into short-term commitments to purchase defined portions of annual consumption of the raw materials utilized by the Company if market prices decline below budget.
103730_18_ITEM15_P364_S2	If after entering into these commitments, the market prices for these raw materials decline, the Company must recognize losses on these adverse purchase commitments.
103730_18_ITEM15_P365_S0	Recently enacted rules in the U.S. on conflict minerals, which include tantalum, tungsten, tin, and gold, all of which are used in the Company's products, could result in increased prices and decreased supply of conflict minerals, which could negatively affect the Company's consolidated results of operations.

103730_18_ITEM15_P371_S0	Vishay is a global manufacturer and supplier of electronic components.
103730_18_ITEM15_P371_S1	Vishay operates, and its chief operating decision maker makes strategic and operating decisions with regards to assessing performance and allocating resources based on, five reporting segments: MOSFETs, Diodes, Optoelectronic Components, Resistors Inductors, and Capacitors.
103730_18_ITEM15_P371_S2	These segments represent groupings of product lines based on their functionality:
103730_18_ITEM15_P372_S0	Metal oxide semiconductor field effect transistors ("MOSFETs") function as solid state switches to control power.
103730_18_ITEM15_P373_S0	Diodes route, regulate, and block radio frequency, analog, and power signals; protect systems from surges or electrostatic discharge damage; or provide electromagnetic interference filtering.
103730_18_ITEM15_P374_S0	Optoelectronic components emit light, detect light, or do both.
103730_18_ITEM15_P375_S0	Resistors and inductors both impede electric current.
103730_18_ITEM15_P376_S0	Resistors are basic components used in all forms of electronic circuitry to adjust and regulate levels of voltage and current.
103730_18_ITEM15_P377_S0	Inductors use an internal magnetic field to change alternating current phase and resist alternating current.
103730_18_ITEM15_P378_S0	Capacitors store energy and discharge it when needed.
103730_18_ITEM15_P379_S0	Vishay's reporting segments generate substantially all of their revenue from product sales to the industrial, automotive, telecommunications, computing, consumer products, power supplies, military and aerospace, and medical end markets.
103730_18_ITEM15_P379_S1	A small portion of revenues are from royalties.
103730_18_ITEM15_P380_S0	The Company evaluates business segment performance on operating income, exclusive of certain items ("segment operating income").
103730_18_ITEM15_P380_S1	Only dedicated, direct selling, general, and administrative expenses of the segments are included in the calculation of segment operating income.
103730_18_ITEM15_P380_S2	The Company's calculation of segment operating income excludes such selling, general, and administrative costs as global operations, sales and marketing, information systems, finance and administration groups, as well as restructuring and severance costs, goodwill and long-lived asset impairment charges, and other items.
103730_18_ITEM15_P380_S3	Management believes that evaluating segment performance excluding such items is meaningful because it provides insight with respect to intrinsic operating results of the Company.
103730_18_ITEM15_P380_S4	These items represent reconciling items between segment operating income and consolidated operating income.
103730_18_ITEM15_P381_S0	Business segment assets are the owned or allocated assets used by each business.
103730_18_ITEM15_P382_S0	The Company also regularly evaluates gross profit by segment to assist in the analysis of consolidated gross profit.
103730_18_ITEM15_P382_S1	The Company considers segment operating income to be the more important metric because it more fully captures the business operations of the segments.

103730_18_ITEM15_P392_S1	Accordingly, the debentures are included in the diluted earnings per share computation using the "treasury stock method" (similar to options and warrants) rather than the "if converted method" otherwise required for convertible debt.
103730_18_ITEM15_P392_S2	Under the "treasury stock method," Vishay calculates the number of shares issuable under the terms of the debentures based on the average market price of Vishay common stock during the period, and that number is included in the total diluted shares figure for the period.
103730_18_ITEM15_P392_S3	If the average market price is less than $12.95, no shares are included in the diluted earnings per share computation for the convertible senior debentures due 2040, if the average market price is less than $17.75, no shares are included in the diluted earnings per share computation for the convertible senior debentures due 2041, and if the average market price is less than $11.02, no shares are included in the diluted earnings per share computation for the convertible senior debentures due 2042.

103730_18_ITEM15_P394_S0	The fair value measurement accounting guidance establishes a valuation hierarchy of the inputs used to measure fair value.
103730_18_ITEM15_P394_S1	This hierarchy prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value into three broad levels.
103730_18_ITEM15_P394_S2	The following is a brief description of those three levels:
103730_18_ITEM15_P395_S0	Level 1: Observable inputs such as quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
103730_18_ITEM15_P396_S0	Level 2: Inputs other than quoted prices that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly or indirectly.
103730_18_ITEM15_P396_S1	These include quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities in active markets and quoted prices for identical or similar assets or liabilities in markets that are not active.
103730_18_ITEM15_P397_S0	Level 3: Unobservable inputs that reflect the Company's own assumptions.
103730_18_ITEM15_P398_S0	An asset or liability's classification within the hierarchy is determined based on the lowest level input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
103730_18_ITEM15_P399_S0	The following table provides the financial assets and liabilities carried at fair value measured on a recurring basis as of December 31, 2016 and 2015:
103730_18_ITEM15_P400_S0	In accordance with ASC Subtopic 350-20, and as described in Note 3, the Company performed nonrecurring fair value measurements of its indefinite-lived Siliconix tradenames as of the last day of its third fiscal quarter of 2016.
103730_18_ITEM15_P400_S1	As a result of the fair value measurements, the Siliconix tradenames with a carrying value of $20,359 were written down to their fair value of $18,800, resulting in an impairment charge of $1,559, recorded in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations for the year ended December 31, 2016.
103730_18_ITEM15_P401_S0	The Company's nonrecurring fair value measurement of its Siliconix tradenames is considered Level 3 measurements.
103730_18_ITEM15_P401_S1	See Note 3 for further information on the measurements and inputs.
103730_18_ITEM15_P402_S0	The Company maintains non-qualified trusts, referred to as "rabbi" trusts, to fund payments under deferred compensation and non-qualified pension plans.

103730_18_ITEM15_P402_S2	The marketable securities held in the rabbi trusts are valued using quoted market prices on the last business day of the year.
103730_18_ITEM15_P402_S3	The company-owned life insurance assets are valued in consultation with the Company's insurance brokers using the value of underlying assets of the insurance contracts.
103730_18_ITEM15_P402_S4	The fair value measurement of the marketable securities held in the rabbi trust is considered a Level 1 measurement and the measurement of the company-owned life insurance assets is considered a Level 2 measurement within the fair value hierarchy.

103730_18_ITEM15_P406_S1	The carrying amount of the cash approximates its fair value.
103730_18_ITEM15_P407_S0	The Company holds available for sale investments in debt securities that are intended to fund a portion of its pension and other postretirement benefit obligations outside of the U.S.
103730_18_ITEM15_P407_S1	The investments are valued based on quoted market prices on the last business day of the year.
103730_18_ITEM15_P407_S2	The fair value measurement of the investments is considered a Level 1 measurement within the fair value hierarchy.
103730_18_ITEM15_P408_S0	The convertible senior debentures, due 2040, due 2041, and due 2042, issued by the Company on November 9, 2010, May 13, 2011, and May 31, 2012, respectively, contain embedded derivative features that GAAP requires to be bifurcated and remeasured each reporting period.
103730_18_ITEM15_P408_S1	Each quarter, the change in the fair value of the embedded derivative features, if any, is recorded in the consolidated statements of operations.
103730_18_ITEM15_P409_S0	The Company uses a derivative valuation model to derive the value of the embedded derivative features.
103730_18_ITEM15_P409_S1	Key inputs into this valuation model are the Company's current stock price, risk-free interest rates, the stock dividend yield, the stock volatility, and the debentures' credit spread over London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR).
103730_18_ITEM15_P409_S2	The first three aforementioned inputs are based on observable market data and are considered Level 2 inputs while the last two aforementioned inputs are unobservable and thus require management's judgment and are considered Level 3 inputs.
103730_18_ITEM15_P410_S0	The fair value measurement is considered a Level 3 measurement within the fair value hierarchy.
103730_18_ITEM15_P411_S0	The Company enters into forward contracts with highly-rated financial institutions to mitigate the foreign currency risk associated with intercompany loans denominated in a currency other than the legal entity's functional currency.
103730_18_ITEM15_P411_S1	The notional amount of the forward contracts was $100,000 and $100,000 as of December 31, 2017 and 2016, respectively.
103730_18_ITEM15_P411_S2	The forward contracts are short-term in nature and are expected to be renewed at the Company's discretion until the intercompany loans are repaid.
103730_18_ITEM15_P411_S3	We have not designated the forward contracts as hedges for accounting purposes, and as such the changes in the fair value of the contracts are recognized in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations as a component of other income (expense).
103730_18_ITEM15_P411_S4	The Company estimates the fair value of the forward contracts based on applicable and commonly used pricing models using current market information and is considered a Level 2 measurement within the fair value hierarchy.
103730_18_ITEM15_P411_S5	Due to the timing of the renewal of the forward contracts, the value of the forward contracts were immaterial as of December 31, 2017 and 2016.
103730_18_ITEM15_P412_S0	The Company does not utilize derivatives or other financial instruments for trading or other speculative purposes.
103730_18_ITEM15_P413_S0	The fair value of the long-term debt, excluding the derivative liability and capitalized deferred financing costs, at December 31, 2017 and 2016 is approximately $1,071,200 and $860,600, respectively, compared to its carrying value, excluding the derivative liability and capitalized deferred financing costs, of $379,033 and $367,049, respectively.
103730_18_ITEM15_P413_S1	The Company estimates the fair value of its long-term debt using a combination of quoted market prices for similar financing arrangements and expected future payments discounted at risk-adjusted rates, which are considered level 2 inputs.
103730_18_ITEM15_P414_S0	At December 31, 2017 and 2016, the Company's short-term investments were comprised of time deposits with financial institutions that have maturities that exceed 90 days from the date of acquisition; however they all mature within one year from the respective balance sheet dates.
103730_18_ITEM15_P414_S1	The Company's short-term investments are accounted for as held-to-maturity debt instruments, at amortized cost, which approximates their fair value.
103730_18_ITEM15_P414_S2	The investments are funded with excess cash not expected to be needed for operations prior to maturity; therefore, the Company believes it has the intent and ability to hold the short-term investments until maturity.
103730_18_ITEM15_P415_S0	At each reporting date, the Company performs an evaluation to determine if any unrealized losses are other-than-temporary.
103730_18_ITEM15_P415_S1	No other-than-temporary impairments have been recognized on these securities, and there are no unrecognized holding gains or losses for these securities during the periods presented.
103730_18_ITEM15_P415_S2	There have been no transfers to or from the held-to-maturity classification.
103730_18_ITEM15_P415_S3	All decreases in the account balance are due to returns of principal at the securities' maturity dates.
103730_18_ITEM15_P416_S0	Interest on the securities is recognized as interest income when earned.
103730_18_ITEM15_P417_S0	At December 31, 2017 and 2016, the Company's cash and cash equivalents were comprised of demand deposits, time deposits with maturities of three months or less when purchased, and money market funds.
103730_18_ITEM15_P417_S1	The Company estimates the fair value of its cash, cash equivalents, and short-term investments using level 2 inputs.
103730_18_ITEM15_P417_S2	Based on the current interest rates for similar investments with comparable credit risk and time to maturity, the fair value of the Company's cash, cash equivalents, and held-to-maturity short-term investments approximate the carrying amounts reported in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
103730_18_ITEM15_P418_S0	The Company's financial instruments also include accounts receivable, short-term notes payable, and accounts payable.
103730_18_ITEM15_P418_S1	The carrying amounts for these financial instruments reported in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets approximate their fair values.
103730_18_ITEM15_P419_S0	On July 6, 2010, Vishay completed the spin-off of its measurements and foil resistors businesses into an independent, publicly-traded company, Vishay Precision Group, Inc.
103730_18_ITEM15_P419_S1	Vishay's common stockholders received 1 share of VPG common stock for every 14 shares of Vishay common stock they held on the record date, June 25, 2010, and Vishay's Class B common stockholders received 1 share of VPG Class B common stock for every 14 shares of Vishay Class B common stock they held on the record date.
103730_18_ITEM15_P420_S0	Following the spin-off, VPG is an independent company and Vishay retains no ownership interest.
103730_18_ITEM15_P421_S0	Following the spin-off, VPG and Vishay operate separately, each as independent public companies.
103730_18_ITEM15_P421_S1	Vishay has no ownership interest in VPG.
103730_18_ITEM15_P421_S2	However, Ruta Zandman solely or on a shared basis with Marc Zandman and Ziv Shoshani, all of whom are members of Vishay's Board of Directors, control a large portion of the voting power of both Vishay and VPG.
103730_18_ITEM15_P421_S3	Marc Zandman, Vishay's Executive Chairman of the Board and an executive officer of Vishay, serves as the Chairman of VPG.
103730_18_ITEM15_P421_S4	Ziv Shoshani, CEO of VPG, serves as a director of Vishay.
103730_18_ITEM15_P421_S5	Additionally, Timothy V. Talbert, a member of Vishay's Board of Directors is also a member of the Board of Directors of VPG.
103730_18_ITEM15_P422_S0	In connection with the completion of the spin-off, Vishay and its subsidiaries entered into several agreements with VPG and its subsidiaries that govern the relationship of the parties following the spin-off.
103730_18_ITEM15_P422_S1	Among the agreements entered into with VPG and its subsidiaries were a transition services agreement, several lease agreements, and supply agreements.
103730_18_ITEM15_P422_S2	None of the agreements have had nor are expected to have a material impact on Vishay's financial position, results of operations, or liquidity.
103730_18_ITEM15_P422_S3	Some of these agreements have expired and have not been renewed.
103730_18_ITEM15_P423_S0	The license granted VPG the limited, exclusive, royalty-free right and license to use certain marks and names incorporating the term "Vishay" in connection with the design, development, manufacture, marketing, provision and performance of certain VPG products that do not compete with any products within Vishay's product range as constituted immediately following the separation and certain services provided in connection with the products.
103730_18_ITEM15_P423_S1	The license cannot be terminated except as a result of willful misconduct or liquidation bankruptcy of VPG.
103730_18_ITEM15_P424_S0	Until the spin-off, VPG was included in Vishay's consolidated federal income tax returns and with Vishay and/or certain of Vishay's subsidiaries in applicable combined or unitary state and local income tax returns.
103730_18_ITEM15_P424_S1	In conjunction with the spin-off, Vishay and VPG entered a tax matters agreement under which Vishay generally will be liable for all U.S. federal, state, local, and foreign income taxes attributable to VPG with respect to taxable periods ending on or before the distribution date except to the extent that VPG has a liability for such taxes on its books at the time of the spin-off.
103730_18_ITEM15_P424_S2	Vishay is also principally responsible for managing any income tax audits by the various tax jurisdictions for pre-spin-off periods.
103730_18_ITEM15_P424_S3	Vishay has fully indemnified VPG of tax exposures arising prior to the spin-off.
